15 hours in and struggling a bit, i love factory builders, but this doesn't give me that same satisfaction that others do.

I think its really down to the tedious parts that are novel at first when its just a few machines or parts, but when you start really wanting to build a mansion or automate, you quickly just find yourself doing a ton of ferrying runs just to collect parts to build, something like a system for ordering components and having them either delivered or picked up on a pallet would negate much of this.

Then the progression, it feels less like large strides and more just filling the same order but BIGGER, with no endgame (that i saw) goal that's unachievable from your little teir 1 setup, i think im just gonna leave this one for another time.

Great game! Relaxing and challenging. I bought this over a year ago, never really touched it and just got into it recently. Watching You-tubers breaking the game kind of put me off playing. You can create some really big hilarious problems for yourself and sure, the grind is real in this one, but getting through the early game and setting yourself up with automation is the way to go. I watched dedicated gamer Hybridsteel on YouTube for some playthroughs and tips. The late game would like to see some high value items to spend the mountains of money you accumulate. Other than that, this game is awesome fun and a well thought out piece of work. The new upcoming DLC looks great too.

Game lacks polishing - a lot of it. The mechanics aren't intuitive even though it has been under development for years already. Personally, I've tried it a couple of times, decided to not refund it and let time tell... well, time is telling it's not worth it.

A few games to compare this game is farming simulator and Astroneer (I would know because I play those). It's an enjoyable and especially goofy mechanics so it keeps the game enjoyable.

Based on videos online, I thought this would be a fun automation simulator.  When it started off fully manual and intentionally frustrating I thought that would just increase the value of the automation.  But the wiki is poorly documented, in-game objects misbehave (and I can't tell if it's a glitch or intentional because, again, wiki is useless), and the entire experience is just an unpleasant slog.

By the time I realized this was a turd, it was past my return period.  Don't waste your time.

### Edited to Reflect Current Thoughts with the DLC on the way ###

The Pros:
1. The offspring of Minecraft and Satisfactory. It's exactly what you think.
2. Map is perfectly sized for the gameplay; a rarity in this day and age.
3. A complete, enjoyable experience with tons of room for the memes, before the upcoming DLC.

The Cons:
1. Doesn't have a proper multiplayer.
2. Starting grind is tedious.
3. Quests to see the king require large scale harvesting/collection systems.
4. "I've only got these two machines for sale, but you can make more of them in Icehelm."

My Experience:

I started off panning for iron and gold nuggets in my local creek. I then made enough money to buy my first drill and grinder. Proceeded to use this setup to build a conveyor line with twenty drills that all feed into the one grinder. Made millions of hydro coins, then proceeded to help townspeople with their fetch/make quests. Made one man a beautiful gold and sapphire necklace which he promptly threw onto the ground because the sapphire was one weight unit heavier than he wanted. Proceeded to boop him over to my plot of land and buried him alive. Then bought all the available land in the area, and nuked every square corner of it. Finally, I retired on my humble mountain of ~22,000 weight gold bars like Smaug.

10/10 best game purchase of 2023
THIS IS SO FUN

Not without flaws, but a good game! My only complaint is how tedious it can be to cross the map just to go shopping, which is even worse if you don't know how much things cost, because then have to make multiple trips, and that's assuming you don't forget to bring the money in the first place. Icehelm's interior is the worst culprit of this. The scale of it is neat design-wise, but the walk in and out of it are nightmarishly long to put it nicely. The walk is at least >1-min long, and that's without even carrying a pallet, which stops you from sprinting. And then at the entrance, the elevator is the bane of my existence. Rather than staying where it last was used, it is always in motion, moving up, waiting a few seconds, moving down, waiting, over and over. The elevator is also really slow, and I might just be an unlucky sonofabitch, but I swear, that elevator, always leaves just when I get there. And then I'm left just standing there. Waiting. For. The. Goddamn. Elevator. All things considered, good game! It can seem a little tedious at first, but as soon as you get even a little bit of automation, it feels very rewarding. Manually purchasing and placing things can be a little tedious occasionally, but it feels more satisfying when you finish things because of it. So, my final verdict: A few annoying aspects, but not enough to ruin the otherwise great experience, especially at a very low price.

Took me a while to figure out some of the game play, but enjoying it overall! I sometimes think the overall progression for things is too slow, but that is also what makes it challenging to keep saving up, and figuring out efficient ways to build everything.
at a whole its very good

I really liked this game. But I just got banned by the developer from the forums for basically calling the developer out for their shady practices. 

The developer recently posted a response to the massive backlash they received for making a predatory DLC that costs 2/3rds the amount of the game. It also is an isolated DLC, essentially being a secondary game. They are being scumbags in t hat, they're forcing you to buy game 1 to play game two. Then, the developers say they're dooing this predatory tactic because they undercharged for Hydroneer, thus; It's our fault and we have to pay the price for their decision making. 

I also pointed out that there's not much to the game. There's a severe lack of game balance. And the developer just keeps adding predatory F2P game mechanics to the game, ie tokens (seperate currency) that just ruins balance more. 

Now, beside this little drama let's give a real review to the game: 

The game is interesting, but has absolutely no direction or goal. The developers were going to add quests/npcs to give it a full story, but the community universally said that was a bad idea. So.... their idea was instead of introduce something else... create a DLC and charge people.

When you make stuff, it's all on a pipe, and as long you have it connected to the pipe you have 'power'. The machines and the whole system can get somewhat complicated but tends to be pretty simple to figure out.

The Energy items (basically items that can be powered by electricity instead of water , requiring a separate connection setup.)

The farming is complete crap, boring, and poorly balanced through-and-through. 

In the game you can experience everything the game has to offer in about 5 hours. They introduce a F2P secondary (and teriary) tokens system. With the tokens, you can change that to 4 hours. It was supposed to extend the play ability, but reduced it. 

They have vehicles that are poorly implemented. The digging vehicle is just absolutely unwieldy. I tried to do level lines and just couldn't do it for the life of me. The "Discover Ores" truck is useless, the helmet does a better job and is cheaper/easier to use. There's 4 of the same style truck with just different colors that are muted. The physics on the vehicles are pretty bad. You take any corner and you risk rolling - with the 4x4 you WILL roll, it's not even a question.

They have 'quests' int he game, which are just NPCS that wonder the world and you have to go find them. They tell you to obtian some item of certain weight/value. This is the moment that feels like there's an actual video game, but then... it's all really relaly boring. The fact you ahve to hunt these people down with no real indication .... AND they move. The rewards are totally imbalanced from them as well. 

The mining guild. I can have access to any item within 2 hours. The farming guild, it takes about 4-5 hours to access everything in farming. WHich is a seperate situation from the mining, it has nothing to do with mining and doesn't integrate well with it. So, I don't include this as part of the game, because it's so bad.

And like I said, there's nothing to do in the game. There's no over arching story. There's no friends to socialize with. There's hardly a community of actual players. Most of the time it's people showing off Not factory builds but aesthetic builds. So, even the comunity is middling at best in my eyes. 



I am going to reiterate this: The developer says he doesn't want to be seen as a shady developer. So, what does he do?
Bans all opinions on the forum that aren't just kissing his ass and calls it 'disrespectful'. I got banned for commenting on his comment of "I don't want to b e seen as a shady developer." I called him shady for these reasons:
Predatory Token System - without the predatory part so ... it just is a poor system ripped from F2P games and not understanding the point of secondary currency isn't to 'add fun' its to obfuscate the amount of money a person will spend on the game. 
Silencing Different Opinions
Silences Criticism of them and their game (that's not insulting or being desrespectful, showing criticsim of a specific thing the developer was concerned about.) 
They're putting out a DLC that costs 2/3rds of the games' value, blaming the customers for the fact they 'undercharge' for hydroneer... which I disagree with there's NOTHING TO THE GAME - there's 5 plots all of which do the EXACT SAME THING (some go deeper than others) there's literally no NEED to buy a seperate plot - you can experience the entire game from the tutorial area - no lie. 
The DLC t hey're charging 2/3rds for is also going to be an isolated area - aka a SECONDARY GAME - thus you have to bay them for BOTH games in order to own the SECOND game. 

This is a shady developer at this point. ANd I will be making a point to report them for being shady... and when my ban is up I will be sharing these with everyone. I will probably also post this on the reddit page, just so people are aware that the developer IS become super shady.

Did you find the grind of chopping wood in skyrim enjoyable but wish it offered more? Kind of what this game is like, everything is an arduous task, you can only carry 1 item at a time, and it's a grind. But all the more satisfying because of it.

Carrying 1 item at a time can be overcome by various means, like a pallet or your truck, but it is refreshing to not have any semblance of inventory management in the usual sense like Minecraft or Factorio.  Similar to Astroneer, all your stuff is just laying around in a glorious pile. This adds a sense of realism, and I always get a chuckle when my poor organization makes my base a giant pile of crap.

Fun game in a charming world, ongoing updates giving a reason to jump back in every few months.
Some parts of gameplay loop slightly tedious and a few somewhat opaque mechanics for a casual player who plays this category to relax.
After nearly 100hrs this game is overall 100% fantastic value for the very low asking price.
this game requires effort and it feels good to progress this game is amazing.

I have enjoyed this game quite a lot - Currently at about 46 hours at the time of this review,
and there are a lot of pros about the game but a few major cons that I didn't much like (but, they might not bother other people)

Pros:
1) The feel of the game is fun, having to do the different jobs is what sim games are about, and this fits that role brilliantly, especially for the early game, you really start with just the bare basics and salvage a pittance to buy your first drill and things and it feels quite rewarding (though, that does quickly die off, admittedly)

2) Planning your build and how you want to set everything up is very fun, it gets the mind working and it is also really cool seeing your planning come to fruition, and planning is also key because of how long-winded it is to buy and transport the parts you want - But remembering the parts you need, taking pressure into account, planning how things will be sorted into their respective items along the way, adding logics with wires, etc. Having all these options available to consider when building an auto-mining thing is fun, and if you do it all right first time round as you envision it, and it works perfectly, I must admit is very rewarding and feels like a 3D schematic that's come to life - Its awesome

3) Having the different vehicles, different patches of land and higher tiers of drills to aim for is also a nice factor to add to the game as you can try different ideas in different areas and work on better ways to make your build more efficient, while yielding results the whole time - There are also more vehicles than I first thought too, with more being found as options to buy in other towns (some with tokens, others with coins) - It would make hardcore grinders have something to show that really shows they have spent hours on the game

4) The very start might feel like a monotonous grind, but actually, it is quite charming to have to pan for different resources and pick up the individual pieces and pop them in a crucible to melt - Making your first weapon is satisfying too. You can make hundreds of swords or daggers from very minute amounts of metal, but they sell for sell (obviously), but having the freedom to mix and match resources when crafting as well as using different amounts of resources is a good touch to the game and if you wanted an RP kind of game, I would wager that it would be more fun with friends

5) Stockpiling resources and forging weapons to sell is quite a fun mechanic, which is charmingly basic and simple to understand - Its also fun to see the highest value item you can make will be (my current record is 1.7 mil, which would have been more, but i was curious and wanted to know so i built it sooner, instead of waiting longer)

6) The furniture and housing parts are a nice touch to the game, it gives you something else to do and each town has different parts available too, so you can mix and match styles in any way you see fit, then pick one of the plots of land that you have, take all the pieces you have loaded into your truck and start building your own homestead

Cons:
1) After some time, the game does feel quite grindy, once you have a good automated system in place, you are basically golden on the money front - I only have about 4 x Tier 2 drills (which remain inactive most of the time) and I already have over 3 Million Hydrocoins, So, now there isn't much I really *want* to do - The game has other currencies in the form of tokens which are earned for different guilds by completing villager requests (the results of which can be used to buy things to make the respective guild requirements easier, like sprinklers for gardening, etc), but the game by no means requires any of them, so you can forgo the extra effort and pain as the results aren't *that* amazing.
It basically makes it so, the only "reason" you need better drills and would want to dig deeper is to get the two better materials, "Cloutium" and "Corestone" to make T2 and T3 respectively, but you don't *need* them... you can do everything with T1 things, the T2 drills also have a different orientation, so you cannot simply substitute your currently build with the new tier drill, it requires an entire rework of your build, which I thought was pretty sucky, tbh

2) Farming is something that is so SO slow, the plants themselves grown quite well, but the game is linked to a grid system, so that things line up nicely (which isn't the issue), however, when a pipe is connected to a water source and is not connected to anything the other end, it trickles a single drop out repeatedly, this drop can be used to irrigate 1 plant hole (Which, when digging, are NOT bound to the same grid system), So, having to have LOADS of pipes to get a large yield of crops is a nightmare, and while the sprinkler solves this issue (i would imagine), each one is very expensive in tokens and would require hours upon hours of growing a plant, waiting for it to grow, destroying the crop, replanting one, waiting, and so on, just to get enough crops to make 1 soup to get 88 tokens, when a sprinkler costs over 2000... And seeing as the only *real* reward from a large plant harvest (after you dont need tokens for maximising efficiency) is just getting more Hydrocoins, you might as well completely forgo that side of the game and favour the mining

3) While novel at first, having to load up a car with each and every single piece of equipment takes a very long time, and there are pallets which somewhat make this easier (and trucks can hold endless stuff as the pieces merge through one another when in that area), it still takes forever to load up the truck with things, especially with pipes (which you always need loads of) or building pieces - I like the feel of going into a shop, picking up the item and placing in the "buy zone" and paying for it, that's a nice touch, but having to pick up, drop, buy, pick up, move to truck, place in truck, and so on, PER ITEM takes an ungodly amount of time

4) I have over 50 drills mining chunks of dirt for processing, and production is great, however, the amount of items that are on the belts (as each lump counts as an item) makes the frames take a serious hit, I have a nice Laptop that can run many games with ease, but the frame rate drops massively to the point where I had to isolate a whole 27 drill segment of my build just to make sure the game ran smoother, which for an autonomy game is annoying

5) Lastly, (and this is just a personal gripe), For some reason, it ALWAYS seems to be night time - You can sleep and make it day time, but night comes around every 15mins, which, in a grind game, (and a game that takes FOREVER to shop en masse for things), isn't much good, because 15mins goes REALLY quickly, without even noticing - But, when night falls, the darkness just makes it next to impossible to see on the land patches, and requires you to sleep (or use an annoying mining helmet for a small circle of light) - Like i said, its a personal gripe, but I've had to resort to shopping in the dark so that by the time i get back it should be light (which it rarely is and still requires a sleep) - I just find it annoying, and as "Sleep" and other survival factors aren't actual mechanics, it wouldn't be out of place to maybe put the option to take the day/night cycle off

Overall, though, I would definitely say that the pros outweigh the cons - Just view the game as a casual play and don't look towards the "End Goal" and the games is so much more fun - The more you try and aim for something, the further and further away it seems, despite steady progress.
So, i will probably still play the game after this review, and I would certainly recommend it too.
If you use the £1 per hour of play system, i have got about 4x my money's worth from this game (purchased at £12.79)
But, If you aren't happy spending that, when it goes on offer, *then* buy it, because it is a well made game and is very fun

...but the dev knows it was too easy to make C in the game, so the dev created another currency(T) that can only be gained by doing pointless quests to the citizens.
These additional currencies adds absolutely nothing to the game - except to slow it right down to a crawl.
You'll have millions to spend... but it's millions that are worth NOTHING - because the majority of the game uses a completely different currency.
The game was 10x better on release, than it is now...  The performance issues are still there - they have just been postponed by these time-wasting additions.

The Graphics of the game is alright no matter what your settings are, how ever i do recommend a DECENT gaming computer if you want to up the ante on your graphics. I would say the to wait for a sale on steam to buy this game, or if you really want it.. then yea if you have some spare money laying around. 

Few hints..
You can dig sand, and then divide the sand by two by scoop the sand, place it down, then you BASICALLY got unlimited sand/dirt. Just scoop, place on ground, take half, place in bucket, take other half, place BACK ON GROUND and its a full pile again.
Second Hint..
Minerals may be bigger and heavier the lower you go and dig, what the game doesn't tell you!!!!! Is that if you BRING the sand back to the top, ITS THE SAME WEIGHT AND RATIO as the level you started on. Don't bring your sand or dirt to the top to wash, do it as far down as you can to get MAXIMUM mineral weight ratio.

Now, I haven't played this game in a while, so take everything with a grain of salt, but

A year (or was it two?) ago, the dev promised multiplayer, which, yes, there technically is multiplayer, but it requires that your friend is either physically beside you or using some sort of remote connection.

The dev is now, instead of delivering what he promised in the first place, making a DLC, which, to be completely fair, adds a lot of content. I can understand wanting some more money from the game, but a DLC that puts large amounts of content behind a paywall is not a good method.

If he instead, y'know, kept his promises, and made some proper progression past the 15th hour, then maybe more people would buy the game, thus resulting in more funds.

I feel, with the current state of things, that the dev cannot be trusted, and even though I, at time of writing, have approx. 120 hours in-game, that I wasted my money.

TL;DR
Dev can't keep his promises, and is focusing on the wrong things

My list of problems:
- You can only carry one object at a time.  Need to run a 100 object length of pipe?  You have to manually grab each piece and place it one at a time.  The only way around some of this is to use something big enough to load items.  Metal bars into pans, pipes into a truck, then carry/drive that container object around.  And items like a conveyor belt wont fit in a pan
- Even your money is physical item, and not a stat, and requires carrying it around into buckets to push buttons to buy stuff with it.
- Expanding is a pain, especially if you want to reuse stuff.  You have to manually take it apart, one by one, then rebuild one by one.
- Starting out is very slow.  Use shovel to dig dirt, put dirt in a pan, get water into pan (with bucket or dump pan in water), use brush on pan, pick ore out of pan, put it somewhere to sell, repeat until you can afford to automate
- Your starting plot can earn enough Hydrocoins in a few hours with 4 digging units to buy nearly everything you could want with Hydrocoins
- Automation units degrade over time, and need repaired with the flimsiest wrenches in the world (single use each!)  Eventually you need water filters to protect any and all drills and grinders, BUT, now the water filters will each break over time, and more often than the working machines!
- You can fish or farm as well now (since I last played), but they're both going to have a lot of manual one by one interactions
- You can't even buy a watering can for farming until you've proven yourself you can grow a plant and feed someone tomato soup.

I feel if you want to play this game like a sane person, and try to do it like a factory game, you're playing it for the wrong reason, as every other well known factory game does a way better of job of this.  If you want to do insane stuff like Josh, then blowing up a million fish with a nuke might be fun.

This is painful, but if [I]Hydroneer[/I] intends to continue in the spirit it's shown me so far, it's a no. Having just rage quit, I don't intend to put any more of my afternoon into it.

This is a game so overtly designed to be as fussy and needlessly slow as possible to stretch out its playtime and it is far too slow to get even remotely going. 

This in itself would not be so bad were it not for the fact that the interface and physics add yet more to the already-frustrating slowness of the gameplay loop - one which becomes tedious rapidly.

That loop seems simple enough: dig four loads of earth... except for no discernible reason these need to first go via a bucket before being put in a pan. This pan then needs submerging in water. Cue furiously scrabbling round after it as it invariably ricochets off the riverbed. Pan wrangled, it's time to brush the dirt out for some meagre nuggets, assuming you can get it to drop on its backside as any real-world pan full of dirt and water would? This one? Upside down, obviously.

The fun doesn't end there. Despite there being both target and drop reticles, these feel oddly imprecise. I was stunned to learn the game [I]wasn't[/I] designed for VR, because it sure as hell feels like it (in all the wrong ways). 

Wait till I tell you that there's no inventory and you can only ever hold one item at a time - of [I]anything[/I]. Lucky enough to not fall asleep with boredom after digging up, panning and filtering twenty nuggets? Enjoy loading them one at a time into your smelter. Sorry, into the crucible that you then have to put into your smelter, because this game likes extra steps. You could try putting them all in a pan and upending it, but half off them will just ding off the sides and bounce off the ground in all directions.

Even as you start to unlock the next gameplay elements of crafting, this is again ridiculously fussy, with conditions needing to be just so and actually against the clock. Even better, when trying to fish ingots out of your furnace, the button for picking them up and [I]picking up the whole damn furnace[/I] is the same.

Have a guess what I spent about 75% of my time doing while trying to aim at a glowing hot ingot in the middle of a similarly-coloured blizzard of particle effects.

This game teases so much promise so early but is absolutely ruined by its poor interface, infuriating physics and deliberately slowed pace. You want to be able to come in of an evening, spend an hour or so getting a gameplay loop going and then get on with your life. This game takes 3 hours to get even remotely started.

There are several interesting mechanics in this game. The game is polished, it's enjoyable for some time, but there is a problem with late game content. What is exactly doesn't feel right:
1. No rewarding end game goals.
2. No way to seamlessly migrate from your factory on the starting field to the extended one.
Because of these 2 factors together, you don't have a strong motivation to leave your starting land plot to build something big on another plot.

To elaborate (1). What might be a reason for you to build a big factory? More resources, more money - but what you will buy with these resources? To clear quests? It doesn't feel rewarding. To create expensive items? For what? Could building a huge factory be a goal by itself? Might be, but not for anyone.

About (2). You have to deliver every part from the shop to your land plot. Even with wooden pallets, it's a lot of manual labor and feels too grindy. There is a problem with game flow, when you deliver many parts to your plot to understand that you forgot something and you have to return to the shop. Also, imagine placing 100 pipes on a pallet one by one, and it is only one part type.

1 could be fixed by introducing well designed end game goals. For example, some meta-game might be introduced, so you can produce items on a larger scale to make a difference for a whole kingdom.
2nd could be fixed by introducing part orders, when you just write a number how many parts of this type do you need, and they are delivered to the desired plot, for some extra money maybe.

As said earlier, the game still enjoyable to some extent, but because of these 2 factors, I feel that it misses some of its potential.

Sometimes, I wish there was a neutral option for the reviews.

I got the game and played it non stop for 2 days. But then I got the point where I was printing money infinitely, albeit slowly, the setup required no maintenance except for the occasional refill of spanners and the next thing would be to make a new setup, next tier of machines for even more profit.

But why? I know these kinds of games are sandbox, set your own goals kind of thing. But as far as I could tell, there was no end-goal. Nothing to truly invest towards to show off your builds.

Factorio has rockets and expanding your factory across an infinite world to increase your rockets/min is the goal, Satisfactory has the space elevator and the Awesome Sink continously counting up your points.

And all of these are resource costing objectives that you always aim for and to be more efficient, get more points, send more rockets you need to expand. But there is no such thing here.

The game is lovely, I like the premise of it. But there is strictly no point to it yet, other than player-defined goals.
You have the quests you get which primarily just give you 2 types of tokens to buy the next tier of machines. But when all that is set up, you just stop playing, or spend the rest of your day perfecting the setups you have. One item at a time, cuz that's the carry limit.

Update: A DLC was announced for the game, which confuses me since I, amongst many others based on the commentsection of the announcement, mistakenly thought the game was in Early Access based on its current state. So it's a bit dissapointing to see a DLC before the base game is what I'd consider "finished"

Got this game in 2020 because I love games about automation. Tried it for a couple of hours, but I didn’t like that there was too much manual work at the beginning.

With the release of patch 2.0, I decided to try to push myself through the slow start and at least automate resource extraction.
After ~5 hours I achieved this.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3139984901
And now, I'm putting this game on the shelf because this whole idea of the player not being able to hold more than one item at a time became tedious very quickly.

I know there is more content, but I'm done with this mechanic. Just the thought that I will need to carry one item after another takes away all my will to play. And I have no desire to build something big like a house or more serious automation in other fields realizing how long this will take.
Even if you use a truck or a cart, you still need to load things one by one and then unload them. It's just pointless busy work.
good game ig

After playing this game around 20 hours, I feel its been long enough to review it. The interface for placing items is terrible without any autosnap function. Moving your character when placing things usually ends up with you falling in a pit and climbing back up to put the item in place. Upgrading pipes is a complete nightmare when you have to remove and replace each piece which includes re-aiming everything. When something doesn't work, there isn't a really clear reason for it or direction on how to fix it. The lack of inventory system besides the bucket is terrible. I should be able to keep a few tools on my character like Minecraft or Satisfactory (of which I have over 500 hours in). This game has an awful user interface. I've recently picked up this game again, after letting it rest for a long time. I bought the game the day after it released for around 7 euro's. It was a fun game but buggy. I remember losing nuggets and tools through the world floor, items being so bouncy with collision issues that they got catapulted out of the world, never to be found again and more.
The common bugs I found are gone now. The free updates and a dedicated dev team made sure of that. Could there still be bugs? Sure, every game has them. Even AAA games, which have usually more bugs and glitches than indie games.

This game is a really fun game that you can pick up when you feel like it. Casual mining, exploring a world, getting money to improve your setup and build your house or whatever you want. It is a sandbox mining game. 
If you dislike grinding, it is probably not the game for you. So think before you buy. Watch some gameplay video's and read up on the game. I dislike grinding in a lot of games but this one is just fun.

I don't really get why people are getting mad because of a dlc. I own around 1200 games and 2000 dlc's. I've seen okay games getting turd dlc's that are really meant for cash grab. Less polished games with a dev team and publisher behind it that don't care about the players, or the game itself. Hydroneer seems, to me, like they care about the game and players. I sure hope that every person understands that making games costs money and to be able to improve on the game they need income or development can't continue. 

If you don't like the dlc, just don't buy it. Keep in mind, if you read this review and many others, that bad reviews that mention the dlc and EA game, are probably over exaggerated. I'd say, be open minded and look up sources of gameplay and decide yourself. 

I know I will buy the dlc after it comes out. Just so I can enjoy new content for this game and to support the dev's.

This game had some interesting ideas, but ultimately I can't recommend it in it's current state. While I was holding out hope that the passionate devs would eventually polish and expand this into something consistently fun, it seems they've run out of funding and are locking future major updates behind paid DLC. On its own this policy wouldn't be too bad considering it will be $10 DLC on a $15 game, but content in the base game feels so sparse and unpolished in its current state it feels like a slap in the face to all who supported the game's development.

Watching content related to this game might have you thinking it's an automation/building game, but the grind to any basic automation is so monotonous and steep and the actual automation mechanics you do get access to are so shallow I can't recommend it to fans of that genre.

Don't get me wrong, I obviously don't hate this game. I'd say it's a very fun sandbox for the price, actually. But I'd say it still feels very incomplete. Instead of seeing progress on the base game's functionality, the developers decide to release a paid DLC.

We need better progression early game. We need better ways to transport items, like an inventory system. We need better ways to repair machines.

Instead we're getting an expansion with more features. Which is fine in some ways, but I worry for the game's future if it plans to keep building onto a foundation that needs work. I don't recommend picking this game up for now unless you're fine with how it looks and feels currently. If so, it's a cheap $15 USD and not a huge loss if you dislike it. But I'm not seeing a bright future.

The interface on this game is unintuitive, clunky and downright exhausting. Intro mining is overly complex, there's no character inventory for anything, not even the 'coins' which are easy to lose in the ground cover if you drop them and they don't fall where you were pointing.. When dropping anything (which aside from coins is always quantity 1) you have to determine/guess where the shadow pointer on the target surface is and many such surfaces do not allow  said pointer to be visible. The only thing I've seen stack thus far is coins. value calculations for quests and sale prices are based on 'weight' but you are unable to determine the weight of an item.. It's just a mess. Creating a base, is even worse.. the grid pattern is weird and will often place things well above ground/surface level. and until you can buy a special tool, you can easily accidentally pickup a piece of your base and be unable to place it back where you picked it up from. For a production/factory/automation game, it is just lousy  3/10. Because the toony graphics are arguably amusing.

I enjoy this game in small spans. I would say any time I feel the desire to play, I do so for maybe 1-2 hours for about a week before I get bored. This game's 'progression' is a bit shallow where it really only offer's the same options for production, but 'faster'. At some point they did add some interesting new items and features, but those are more for 'fun' than they are for expanding the options you have.

My biggest gripe is that this game would be SOOOOOO much better with good multiplayer (I'll explain more in a bit), as this would take away from the weird, awkward loneliness that creeps up as you repetitively do the same thing, as well as make it more interesting with the couple plots of purchasable land. This is probably the biggest miss that keeps me from booting the game back up.

For anyone looking at this game seeing the [Shared/Split Screen Co-op] tag, this game does not have traditional multiplayer. It has local split screen co-op only. You may ask then how you are meant to play with your friends online. Well, the developers rely on Steams 'Share Play' feature. For those who don't know how this works, essentially one of you is actually playing the game on your computer, and another is invited to play the game through a sort of 'shared screen' format. You will see both of your screens, like back when we played the campaign in Halo. You will have to annoyingly configure control setup, meaning if you both with to play Keyboard and Mouse, one of you will need to change all of your keybinds, or you will both be controlling the same character (This means the 'best' way is for one controller player, and one KBM player). And then there is the latency issue. If both players have good internet, aren't too far from one another, and the host has consistent upload speeds, then this is not an issue. However, in almost every case I've experienced where I have tried this with a friend, the connection and lag is too much to enjoy the game.

TLDR:
The game is 'fun'. Technically speaking the gameplay has enough content to warrant it's price point. Personally, I cannot recommend a logistics, sandbox game that does not have complex logistics and/or good multiplayer.

This game is a lot of faffing about for not a lot of progress.

Start of the game has you manually panning for resources for about an hour or two. Alright, a slow start, whatever. Then you get your first automation and you start to set things up and you are earning some decent coin, but you start running into the faffing problems.

You can only carry one item at a time. The game is all about placing pipes, conveyor belts, foundations, etc. A basic sorting build is about 20 items. You have to manually pick them up at a store, load them onto your car one by one, then unload them and place them at the correct space. In something with similar amount of leaning on realism and pipework, that would've been 5 minutes of work. In this, it's a half an hour job. And that's the simplest most basic setup for automation.

Want to move to a new plot and build something bigger? Hope you have hours saved up because you will be manually placing one foundation at a time. Want to dig some nice looking mine with straight walls and floors? Nope, you mine in round-ish clumps, you are basically sculpting with an ice cream scoop. Good thing foundations and wall can cover everything up oh wait that's an hour to just cover up your mess...

Want to do some cool crafting with all the ores you've picked up? Great, you can make a dagger out of the iron, and if you're feeling fancy you'll spit that one bar into two and make an axe. If you are pro, you will split it into three parts and make a sword! It's not much harder, you're not using extra resources, and the result yields you more money so why isn't that some kind of default...

Oh, and hope you don't miss-click and dump a bucket of ore on the floor instead of going into a furnace. If you don't have a magnet wand to pick things up you will spend some good time fixing your mistake one nugget at a time...

All in all, I want to like this game, and it's come a long way since I originally bought it when ti first released (by giving you more convenient access to basic automation soon after the game starts). But we need some kind of inventory system to lower the tedium.

Fun in theory, but there are too many design decisions that make it incredibly frustrating in practice. For example:
-You have a cursor, but it doesn't correlate to where you're placing objects; for *that,* you have to refer to your *second* cursor, which is actually a shadow effect and is therefore really hard to see on certain surfaces.
-Your machines break down. A lot. This doesn't add anything fun, it just means you have to buy a single-use(!) wrench and click at them sometimes. It's a time tax, in a genre whose whole appeal is making assembly lines and letting them run without intervention from you.
-In the early game you'll be panning for ores manually. The pan can hold several shovel loads of dirt--but only if you put that dirt in the bucket first and empty the bucket into the pan. If you try to fill the pan with your shovel directly? Then it only holds a single scoop of dirt. *Why.*
-You can only carry one item at a time. So for example, if you want to do some fishing, you can't carry your fishing rod and bucket at the same time; hope you enjoy loading everything you own onto a slow-moving wheelbarrow or vehicle, because that's what you'll be doing in situations like this.
-Likewise, your various currencies exist as objects in the world instead of just being tied to your character. So if you want to run to town and buy a single item, well, hope you brought your vehicle with you, otherwise you'll be leaving your cash at whatever store you were shopping at. And if you end up with multiple piles of coins and want to combine them, you can't do that while the coins are in a cart or pan or whatever; you have to drop the piles on the ground--good luck aiming with that wonky shadow-cursor by the way--and then pick them back up.

On that note, the thing that finally made me give up on this game for now: when items are added to a container, like a vehicle or pan or whatever, they cease being physics objects. There are good reasons for this, it makes hauling large loads of items easier, and I imagine it helps performance a ton. However, it also creates situations like the coin-stacking bit mentioned above--and more frustratingly, it makes using crucibles an absolute pain in the backside. If you accidentally add ores to a crucible when it's not *quite* hot enough, does it auto-melt the nuggets when it gets to the right temperature? Of course not, the nuggets aren't in the physics anymore, so they just sit there in the crucible like they would in a pan. But unlike in a pan, you can't tip the crucible over and empty them out; the only thing you can pour out of a crucible is liquified metal. So if you accidentally drop a whole pan full of nuggets in a crucible that's not at the melting point yet, you now have to pick each of them out one by one and drop them back in the crucible. And because of the "your cursor matters for picking things up but not for putting them down" design decision, you have to point at a single nugget, pick it up, then turn like forty-five degrees to the left to drop it into the crucible. Over and over again, potentially dozens of times.

And yeah, sure, you could use a magnet on a stick to pick up all the nuggets at once instead, but that's slow and tedious, not particularly accurate since, again, the actual pile of stuff isn't where your cursor is, and more to the point: instead of using a wonky in-game item to circumvent a frustrating design choice, the frustrating design choice just shouldn't be in the game to begin with.

This is not the fun kind of jank, this is just refusing to take cues from the last thirty years' worth of video games. This game is updated pretty regularly, so maybe some of these frustrating choices will be ironed out eventually and I will probably reinstall in a year to see what's changed, but I really doubt they're going do anything as major as adding an inventory system or changing how cursors work at this stage in development.

I loaded into the tutorial to properly get into this game, picked up my first tools and immediately quit when I couldn't handle the first task thrown at me: Fill water and mud in a pan and scrub it for minerals:
I had to drop the bucket in the water for anything of the sort and pick up from there, then I missed filling mud in the pan about 5 times because the crossair aims center but the actions seems to take place in the bottom of the screen.

Same thing happened with the water. After furhter 5 unsuccessful attempts, dropping the bucket in the river, fishing it out of it, then missing the pan (because hit box is so far off-center) I quit.

I usually give indie devs the benefit of the doubt and I understand some game purchases can be a bit hit and miss, but this annoyed me so much, I wasn't going to put up with this to check if it gets any better. I immediately saw how this game wasn't about automation like Satisfactory or Factorio, but rather about overcoming janky controls like Getting Over It or Jump King. No inventory in a management game is also a complete no go in my opinion. I expected a lot more polish at the 3-year anniversary stage of the game.

I was genuinly looking forward to this but instead I already quit out of the tutorial and requested a refund. Get it for the memes if you truly want to, but don't expect it to deliver as much as the trailer promises.

I actually like the game itself; the gameplay loop and progression seems quite balanced, it's relaxing game for people who likes mining and increasing production, without any stressing elements or threats.

I can't recommend it though, because the pain points are just too many and way too severe.

* Tutorial is helpful, but not enough. There is not any description anywhere on how things work, so you will be spending a lot of time searching internet for answers, and stumble across spoilers.

* While trying to figure out the game, my computer crashes three times. It have never crashed once since I bought it. It's a gaming desktop computer, the type that launches all new triple AAA on high quality, never have to check system requirements. Casing is hot enough to fry eggs. Reduce video settings twice to see if it helps, it still crashes. Removed side panel, running with open casing, and that's the only way the game will run for me. What are you doing with the GPU??? It's an RTX 3080, should be more than enough...

* Gameplay is far from polished and non-fun elements are shoved in your face. You spend more time on these non-fun elements than on any game progression. For example, there is no inventory. You can only carry one item at a time, forcing you to drag a wagon around everywhere. Pulling the wagon reduces your speed, so you will often opt to still run with one item to semi-close locations instead of taking the wagon/vehicle... just to realize to grabbed the wrong thing by mistake, or any other arbitrary reason forces you to run back and forth again to change items. "Should have just walked slowly with the whole wagon instead". The "immersion" with this design choice is far, far, far, from making up for the non-fun pain that it adds.

* You actually do get a vehicle that you can drive with to locations further away. All fun and convenient until you run out of water the first time (it uses water as fuel), and you realize that the only way for you to refuel it is to WALK all the way back to your base, pick up a bucket, then WALK all the way back to the vehicle again, misclick when pouring the water so you have to WALK to the closest river you can find and fill up the bucket again.

* You could actually just buy a bucket in the closest (still not close) village instead of running all the way back to the base, buckets are cheap. Oh, forgot that there's no inventory and your coins are also back at your base...

* Other than that, driving the vehicle is smooth, other than OH, THE ONLY AVAILABLE MAP IS A SEPARATE IN-GAME ITEM. At least I thought of bringing the map with me. Lucky me, the navigation is now as simple as PARKING YOUR VEHICLE, GET OUT OF THE VEHICLE AND GO TO THE TRUNK, LOOK AT THE MAP, TRY TO REMEMBER THE TURNS, PUT THE MAP BACK IN THE TRUNK, ENTER THE VEHICLE, DRIVE AGAIN. Next crossroad you see a tower, "wonder what that is", LET'S CHECK THE MAP... OH GOD WHY

* All quests I found wanted items of particular weight. Only problem is that there is no scale anywhere, or so it seems. Visiting all villages and all stores, nothing (also get to experience vehicle running out of water far from home, yay), gave up and searched on internet if there is any scale anywhere. Turns out that there is only one store in one particular village (not really walking distance from starting base) that has a scale to sell. All this pain just to figure out how to complete a quest.

* Finally, got the items of correct weight to complete quests. Only problem is that quest givers don't accept the items I bring. Tried four quests with different items in different locations, none worked. Then realized that the scale that I bought had snapped below ground, with the weight display not visible. I was watching the price display, interpreting that as weight. Nice to spend hours trying to figure that out.

* Finally got my drill in place, starting to produce enough materials to craft some more advanced items on the anvil. PAIN. Sometimes works, sometimes not, never know why. Seems I need to put the bars exactly right? Seems like I need to be faster so that the bars are still hot? Seems like some combinations of materials doesn't work? Seems like there is some minimum size of bars? I don't know, there is no feedback, no message, nothing. It just doesn't work and never tell my why. Repeat enough times and it does work. Clueless.

* FINE, I'll just craft simple items that do work on the first try so that I can farm some money for a harvester and extra drill, let me get some production going. Moving back and forth, getting into the flow. Umm... feeling dizzy.... want to puke... am I motion sick? Looking it up online again, apparently there are many reports on motion sickness with this game. Last straw.



I'm five hours into the game, experience is nothing but pain, even though I think the game is fun in the moments that I actually get to play it. It's just that there is pain everywhere and if I am to struggle through the pain to get to the good parts, then I want to do it without motion sickness on top of it all. Plus I am a bit afraid that it will fry my GPU.

There's the saying that perfectly sums up this game: "Wide as the ocean & deep as a puddle." 

Yeah, the initial premise seems fun, but then... Like, the game lacks content and does so massively: youonly  have 4 metals & 4 gems to mine which are basically all available at the start of the game (it's the ratio that will be improving as you play) to craft 5 types of items (while there's 3 of them which there's no point in crafting, like at all).

Is there really a point going though the quirky & awkward controls and UIX in order to automate the items you can play with from the very start of the game? Personally, for me: no, not at all. I really couldn't find any reason for myself to stay in the game, there's simply no goal or proper progression here like in other crafting & automation games. The "farming" part they've added simply adds the width with the same shallow outcome.

A shame, really, cause the potential is definitely present in this game :(

Here's a bit more "pushed" review.

Overall, this game could have been good. But it ain't. It ain't at all.
Firstly, it's poorly optimized : when Satisfactory is looking absolutely fantastic and can handle thousand of stuff roaming through your coveyor, Hydroneer just can't and will sometimes stack, without reasons your ressources, making your game crash.

The quest tokens (guild and farm) are absolutely horrible to farm and what they get you is for the biggest part... useless.
Only one vehicle really is optimal, it being the hydrotruck (MK.I and II), the others : useless. Shoutout to quest vehicles (to dig the ground) being the worst of them all.

Farming crop is useless, not fun, long.

Farming ressources is pretty much the same but your machines keeps breaking every 15 minutes, making the "automatisation" part your worst nightmare. Best of all ? If you install a mod to get rid of this horrible breaking feature, you won't get any success.

And once you start getting a lot of ressources, there's nothing more to do. It bad. Just, don't.

I really enjoy this game, but I will note a few glaring issues in it's current state. Not accounting for bugs which like all new games, will be removed over time. 

The thing this game lacks, is the WOW factor that keeps you coming back. to clarify, there are things to do, but little reason to do them, once you have an initial set-up the game becomes a money printing machine where your only progression is in the time taken to achieve those things.

The progression in the beginning is quite slow and the manual process gets very tedious very quickly. on the other hand however, once you get fully automated the game again becomes fairly tedious so there is only that bit in the middle where you are "improving" your factory that really feels engaging and fun.

The world is big but not too big so you get a range of locations to explore and exploit but you seem to spend an unnecessary amount of time ferrying things to and from your factory which makes the game feel even more tedious.

Not a game breaker for many here but the multiplayer being locked to local only seems weird, any game involving construction is asking to be shared with others, we all want to show our build to someone, so open it up to true online multiplayer functionality to get that experience.

What the game needs, IMO, is purpose. It needs a reason to buy an additional plot of land, such as locally specific resources, a reason to improve the factory, more than just desire, like time constraints on some of the construction requests. a tangible and Incorporated progression system, currently there are three guilds with independent currency which seems disjointed, maybe use a simple reputation system to lock items for progression but segregated commerce doesn't feel like the way it should work. finally, a reason to want to play, after only nearly 50 hours of in game time, i started to run out of things to do, this shouldn't be something gimmicky like another faction with independent coins but something progressive.
this game seems to be an interesting blend of factory and farming sim but in my honest opinion, it needs to decide on what it's long term aim is going to be. 

it is for the reasons above that i cannot with honesty leave a thumbs up, I would not in my experience value this game at the amount it is currently priced at (£12.79 GBP) although it is a fun game, there simply isn't enough to keep me coming back right now, but i hope that this will change with future updates.

This game is almost good. It has a fun build mechanic and requirements making factory building fun. But it suffers hard in 3 major areas:

1. When you leave your dig site and come back, there's a 90% chance your machine got clogged up somehow. It appears to happen consistently when using sorters, but other machines suffer from it as well. It's not something you can build around, as it's simply "a sorter has a 5% chance to not process the material and leave it in the way". When this happens to 5 minerals, suddenly nothing is processed. 
2. They slow you down via quests, which give you unique currency instead of money. While this can be a good approach to extend the life of the game, picking up and turning in the quests is miserably slow. When you see a quest that's not worth your time, too bad. It's permanent until you complete it.
3. The biggest limiting factor is how your character can only pick up 1 thing at a time and do 1 thing at a time. Imagine Factorio, where you had to craft all your conveyor belts at 1 location, and then run them over one by one to place them. A pallet helps minimally. This can be fun to start but please make some sort of "butler" robot that you can request things to be built and it'll build them. It can cost 1 million dollars. Or 10 million. But something to strive for to ease the manual suffering.

[Edit as of 11/18/2023]

Unfortunately, due to the controversy surrounding the banning of JoseFaction from the Hydroneer community, I have to say that this game is losing its spark. The modding community is pretty much dying, and players are liable to be punished by having achievements disabled just for using mods that add depth, fix bugs or add QOL features.

As far as cozy games go, this one just isn't fun anymore. I may reinstall it at some point, if I see some major updates that add depth, or if JoseFaction is allowed to return. Until then, it's just wasting space on my SSD that I need for other games.

If you want to be frustrated for 10 hours while you try to fight the janky controls play this game.

Basically a scam because everything in this game tries to stretch out your gametime and there is no purpose in Playing it except for maybe playing the creative mode and messing around with it. The devs also dont really listen to feedback and just copy paste a premade answer under comments with criticism. 
This Comment From another user represents my view on it perfectly:
Very little info about the items, you'd need to use their wiki, but the wiki asks for help to write articles on every single item, so no help there either.
Basically, devs are too lazy to write documentation. I wonder how messy their project is...

Then regarding the content: there is not much to discover, also there is not really any reason for you to progress after you automated the first drill, I mean... you will always do the same, you get more money, but what would I need the money for anyways? To buy more machines that give me more money and then what, use that money again to buy more machines? It's a boring game loop. There is no endgame content worth the time spent on this game.

I'm not even going to argue regarding the game mechanics, I don't like them much because everything is tedious and feels like grinding. Automated some stuff? cool... you still will have to use the stupid trucks or carts and struggle to place stuff on it to go forth and back between your digging site and shops. Pretty much everything feels like it's just there to stretch your playtime. But again, that's up to personal taste I guess.

3 years ago I gave this game a somewhat eh. 
After a bunch of updates its much more polished, but can still be a little ruff around the edges.
I however enjoy it a lot more then previously. 

This is in part due to watching streamers (letsgameitout and a few others) brake the game in funny ways. 

I also took up mining for crystals as a hobby, and this game helps scratch that itch when its too cold to do so. 

While building is semi limited, a number of options have been added in to be able to create not only automated mines or farms, but homes as well. I have not delved into this too much yet as im still trying to get a proper mine up and running, but throughout cottage, greenhouse iron, stone, and other building materials I hope to build a Victorian style mansion fit for a mad scientist. a pipe-mancer if you will. 

It still has issues, and some design mechanics I mildly dislike, but it is a good game.
That said, all items are held (expect hats) so its one item at a time and can be a little bothersome for building larger things. pallets, truck beds, and carts exist to help this, but if you need something in bulk its a lot of lugging things back and forth in one format or another. an inventory, or backpack even if it just holds one item at a time, would be nice. Admittedly however if this is a problem, there is a creative mode that allows item duplication.

T0 to T1 is a good grind but T2 and above can be a bit of a grind. in some cases drills can be placed in areas they cant produce stuff in, with the only real restriction being that T1 drills cant produce corestone no matter the dirt. the advantage to this is that drills do not deplete dirt unlike prospecting yourself, but do still need to be on dirt to work. its pretty easy to get a sorting system set up, but the majority of the things you are going to find are gems, gold, and iron. there are two other metals that you need for crafting, a rare gem, and shards. Shards supposedly bring pressure up when used in specific pipes, but iv yet to see them make that big a difference. higher water pressure equates to more speed, but there seems to be a bit of a curve where its diminished returns at some point where the best option is to over pressure pipes as much as possible to compensate. you can add in tanks and shards,, but pipes do not seem to care about flow direction so connecting multiple sections and back pressuring things seems to work. One more aspect to deal with is fixing stuff, but filtering pipes with 5x filters before the water hits the system prevents degrading of the drills. the filters themselves take damage insted, but it is a little esior then having to run around fixing the drills or harvesters individually, being a lot more useful when connected to a lot of things. most things however like convayer belts do not degrade. Thankfully the different pipe types do not seem to matter, its just about pressure loss, the most significant difference being in the intake pipes of different tires. 

At the point im at automation wise, money is no longer an issue, but to mitigate this there are two other currency you can only get by completing NPC quests... as far as I can tell. Its still been pretty fun, but repairing filters and waiting for rare materials to accumulate can stagnate a bit after a while.

"Hydroneer," a captivating video game developed by Foulball Hangover, has emerged as a shining beacon in the vast sea of gaming experiences, captivating players worldwide with its unique blend of creativity, exploration, and resource management. One of the most remarkable aspects of the game is its unparalleled sense of freedom; players are thrust into a sandbox world where they can shape their destiny, making it an ideal playground for those who relish autonomy and creative expression. The game's immersive graphics, characterized by vibrant colors and stunningly detailed environments, serve as an inviting canvas for players to unleash their imagination. Furthermore, "Hydroneer" excels in its innovative gameplay mechanics, allowing players to experiment with various mining techniques, from traditional pickaxe mining to advanced machinery operation, all in the pursuit of uncovering valuable resources. This diversity not only caters to players with different playstyles but also fosters a sense of accomplishment as they master each method. The game's intuitive controls and user-friendly interface enhance the overall gaming experience, making it accessible to both newcomers and seasoned gamers alike. Additionally, the developers have shown an admirable commitment to engaging with the community, actively listening to player feedback and continuously refining the game based on user suggestions. This responsive approach not only strengthens the bond between the developers and players but also ensures that the game evolves organically, staying relevant and exciting. "Hydroneer" also shines in its multiplayer mode, encouraging collaboration and friendly competition among players as they work together or compete to amass wealth and build impressive mining operations. This social element adds depth to the gameplay, fostering a sense of camaraderie and camaraderie among players. The game's expansive world, filled with hidden treasures, challenges, and opportunities, ensures that every gaming session is a unique adventure waiting to unfold. In essence, "Hydroneer" stands as a testament to the endless possibilities of the gaming medium, offering an immersive, dynamic, and endlessly enjoyable experience that captivates the hearts and minds of players, making it a true gem in the gaming landscape.

[h1]Misleadingly Advertised Early Access Game[/h1]
I've given this game a pretty solid crack over the years and unfortunately I can't recommend it at all anymore. I was cautiously optimistic that the game would improve and the developers would polish it into a finished product but my patience is exhausted and my faith is lost. This game is incredibly buggy and this review has been edited multiple times. Some of the bugs mentioned may no longer apply but I'm confident they'll be replaced by new bugs. This has been an ongoing trend for years.

Kind of worse, the developer has been reworking a bunch of mechanics from the "1.0" release. The game has changed significantly in some ways since I first picked it up. Which makes this review scarily relevant even after all those years. This is still an EA game, masquerading as a finished product.

[h2]The Good[/h2]
Don't let some of the negative reviews about the core mechanics put you off. This is a [b]fascinating[/b] game that makes some bold design choices. The core limitation of only being able to carry one item at a time is extremely immersive and is executed pretty well. I loved the low-poly visuals, and the world feels beautifully designed. This is a great game to play casually when you've got a lot of time to kill and want a relaxing experience. Throw on some chilled music and enjoy.

[h2]The Bad[/h2]
This game is very rough in places. The sound design is just plain awful but that's the least of its problems. Though I strongly suggest muting the soundtrack unless you want brain damage... A major major issue is the physics. It's hilarious how bad it is. There are plenty of physics collisions which will send things flying into the sky. [i]Drove over that tiny rock a bit too fast? Welcome to the stratosphere. Something on top of that bucket you picked up? Well it's now flying away at terminal velocity.[/i]

Vehicle handling is just generally terrible. This wouldn't be such a major issue if hauling items with vehicles wasn't such a major party of the game. I've got used to saving my game for fear of being stuck in an infinite reset loop which throws me into the air the moment I reset, and lands me somewhere I can't move. It's happened fairly regularly every time I've played this game.

A game breaking issue is that you can build things under the ground. Not ground you can dig mind. This in itself isn't a problem but if you can't see the item anymore you can't pick it up. I once lost a stack of 14,000 coins because I accidentally placed it [b]under[/b] the ground when I meant to put it [b]on[/b] the ground. Now that wasn't a big deal since I bet on this happening and split my six figures worth of coins into lots of stacks. Can you imagine this happening if you didn't? Just lost all of your coins? Too bad. That could seriously have ruined hours of play time...

In my latest play through I managed to break sprinting in under 5 minutes of play. The sprint key just wouldn't work. It required a game restart to fix it. I've had enough... I've come back to this game with renewed optimism so many times, only to be beaten down with completely stupid bugs, that I'd class the relationship as abusive.

Game performance is utterly abysmal for what it is. I've run this game on both my mid range gaming desktop and my high end gaming laptop and... it sucks. The frame rate will regularly drop to single digits for a few seconds at a time. There have been serious memory leaks in the past which required a system restart to resolve. The game's practically conditioned me to not use lamps as it one point they would tank the frame rate too. Graphics memory usage has also been crazy at times...

[h2]The Ugly[/h2]
As my title suggests this game is being falsely advertised. Development is still actively underway with new features and bug fixes being intermittently released. Combine that with the aforementioned issues the game has and it's fairly clear that this is still very much Early Access and not a full release. I'm not sure why the developer didn't label this as Early Access other than to give a false impression that it's more finished than it really is.

I recently built a site up to full-scale automation again. What shocked me the most is how many machines have been removed from the "1.0" game, only to be replaced by subtly different ones in "2.0". What was the point exactly? Just leave the old machine in the game and make a new one. I think this may have been why some of my Steam cloud saves just disappeared. Presumably they weren't compatible with the new release. I don't know if there's a "3.0" planned but I expect that to blat my saves too.

All of the new changes feel forced and stilted. Dirt has invisible tiers now. You get to a point where Tier 1 equipment won't work anymore. Pickaxes and miners will just spark. The dirt doesn't look different mind. You just spark instead of going deeper. Pipes can now hold more than 100% pressure and have pressure caps that aren't given in description texts. Does a pump or pipe going over 100% pressure sound stupid? That's because it is. Change % to a pressure unit and it would suddenly make sense. Use bar, PSI, Pa, or even make up your own... These might sound like nit-picks but I think it's a sign the developer doesn't really care. The tier's are an afterthought to artificially pad game time.

[h2]Bottom Line[/h2]
I didn't request a refund for this game because I thought it was kind of fun, and I suspected I'd come back to it fairly regularly. I had hoped that if the vehicle and building mechanics were fixed, along with the performance issues, then I'd give it a thumbs up. Now though... I regret this decision. 

The developers have had a lot of attention via YouTube. They've had a lot of people pay for their game. Years have gone by and it still feels like an Early Access bug fest that's being regularly reworked. Sure there's more content but the game has bugs and an apathetic developer eating at its core.

Don't buy this game. Unless you are happy to put up with a lot of infuriating bugs and a developer who's clearly out to get one over people.

[h1]Edited Review (25th Oct 2023 @ 205h)[/h1]
Over two years have passed and since then there have been a few updates and achievements that I wanted to unlock, which is why I started this game again. Unfortunately, the developers still haven't fixed the blocking resources; the only way to remove them is a button in the pause menu that deletes all unprocessed resources. It's not as bad as it was at the time of my original review, but it still happens regularly.
Since there is no inventory, all items have to be transported by cars (or carts in the early game). But if you put a not particularly large amount of items on the loading area, the game starts to lag when you drive. Buying the items one by one is already a farce, and unfortunately so is transporting them, even if you ignore the physics errors when driving at low FPS.

Another problem is money. As soon as a halfway large setup has been built, money problems no longer exist, you don't know where to put all the resources, since once the setup is in place, only the filters need to be repaired every now and then (or the spanners need to be refilled once the repair has been automated). With the last updates, two other currencies were introduced in addition to the normal money. You only get these through quests, which NPCs give you. I assume that this was to curb this abstruse overflow of money by reducing the amount of money that the player can earn in a certain amount of time, because the quests don't spawn very quickly and only give limited money. Unfortunately, this makes the whole game even slower than it already is, since important items for the farming aspect can only be bought with this new currency. Especially the prices for farming equipment are completely idiotic. A single sprinkler (to water plants) costs almost as much as a vehicle that can harvest and sow plants. Additionally, nothing can be automated to obtain these new currencies except for gathering large amounts of the basic resources. You always have to pick up the quest, create the random item and bring it back to get a marginal amount of money. 

All in all, I can only say that the game is a real pain without mods. Unfortunately, mods lead to Steam Achievements no longer being unlocked, which is why you have to go through the whole thing at least once if you want to get the Achievements. In principle, I would say that the most useful feature in the future would be an inventory system, and I'm not sure I'd bother playing the game again without one. I also stand by my conclusion from the original review: the early game is fun, but the mid to late game is unpolished. Unfortunately, my hopes that this game would be better were not fulfilled, which is why I changed my review from a "would recommend" to a "would not recommend".

It's not even that the game is bad, but the mechanics break it.

[h1]Old Review (16th Feb 2021 @ 35h)[/h1]
So the first few hours are really fun, from digging by hand to getting the first automated rigs. However, there are a few things that fall apart when your rigs get bigger and the amount of goods you get exceeds some amount.

I just have 35 rams that dig on the surface, all dirt gets processed, the goods get filtered and smelted. All works without a problem until the smelting part. Ores get stuck at the side of the conveyor belts, at the exit of the sorter, the melting plants, the logic smelting plants and even in the funnels. If you do not catch that immediatly thousands of ores will be blocked because of that one stuck ore and any attempt to remove that blockade will either drop your FPS way below 1, crash the game or spread all the ores over the whole island as the physics just 'explode' the ores when touching one of them.
So I am sitting there on the "South Hope" field and can not even use all of the 35 rams (which is nothing compared to the size of the field ) as 1 blocked ore can already destroy everything. All of these rams would easily fit on the first field so I do not really see the reason to buy a bigger field except to dig lower and get bigger ores.
Maybe it would already be enough to join the ores like the dirt does at the moment and to not cap the ore size but to do it like the bars which do not grow in size after some point but get heavier. That would reduce the problems caused by the stuck ores (as that would stay 1 ore but bigger and way heavier) and might even reduce lag when handling ores by hand if anything happens. Keep in mind that bigger ores are already a thing when mining deeper so it would only make sense to be able to join smaller ores.
Another point of trouble is the magnet. While it does help a lot collecting all of the ores that flew over the whole island even after dropping all the ores it keeps lagging until i do not hold the magnet in my hand anymore. When I pick it back up the lag returns though. Same thing happens with the world save, after some time the game gets laggy which can be fixed by quiting to the game menu and loading the world again. 
Another thing that annoyed me is that you need to check your filter every now and then which is okay, but in my opinion it happens way too often and with the basic filters the water damages your machines if unfiltered water gets in some machines. Especially since you need five of them in early game but only one powered filter later on. The powered filters stops the water flow if the filter breaks so it gets better in the 'mid' game (there is some automatic repairing logic in late game) but it could be better.
Also the money should be no item that you literally need to carry around. While I understand the reason it just makes everything so much slower, a money system outside of physical items would be way better (but is fairly subjective so I understand if there are people prefering the current money method).
All in all it is a fun game but the mid to late game seems unpolished, the bugs I encountered are game breaking and should not exist in a full release. Maybe the developers thought one would get the better drill fairly early and instead of going on a large scale with small ores one would go smaller scale with big ores in the lower parts of the fields.

Those are the problems I encountered apart from some minor physics shenanigans and apart from those I really enjoyed the game. It is fun and has an awesome setting which kinda reminds me of minecraft in a more realistic and 'advanced' world than minecraft itself. So while this review might sound negative I want to stress that I really enjoyed this game and want to see what happens with it in the future. I would rate it with a 6.5-7.5/10 in its current state but it can clearly get way more than that in the future.

It's a super fun, light hearted, mining/automation game. The beginning stages, while slow going, are relaxing. Later stages with automation and sorting systems are equally as satisfying. This game is as simple or as complex as you want it to be. I personally have enjoyed doing both the early game numerous times, and giant automated mining complexes multiple times. 

Updates are also done fairly often for this game and have been pretty meaningful over the period that this game has been available. A lot of quality of life improvements, performance improvements, and gameplay changes since I first started in early access. 

If you like slower paced automation games I would recommend.

Honestly, This isn't usually the type of game I play. It isn't dynamic, there's no survival aspect, nothing that adds a sense of urgency to the game. It's well and truly a sandbox game. However, that's not to say that the game lacks anything in any of those departments. There's a sense of realism, albeit not entirely, that Makes the game somewhat charming. There's no fast way to do anything, which I think is wonderful. You're forced to take things slow and be methodical about the processes you use, whether it be manually mining ores and gems to clean and refine, or creating massive foundries to automate the work for you. The lack of an inventory adds to the realism, making it so you can't just load yourself down with countless materials and machinery, expediting a process that doesn't really have an end goal. In short, if you have the patience to just relax and allow yourself to be carried by the pace the game sets for you, this is a wonderfully perfect game to wind down with and just chill for a few hours. Enjoy the greater feeling of accomplishment when you accomplish something, no matter how long it took, and remember that there is nothing pressing in this game. Have fun, wind down, and enjoy.
