Having played Hydroneer for more than 80 hours, I can give a solid opinion on the game. I've played probably every factory-style game there is extensively over the last 20 years.

Positives:

-Nice graphics and a good color palette.
- Runs well if you stick to basic mining setups.
- Can be fun to begin with building your mining and drilling operation.
- The open world is pleasant, not too big, not too small.
-Good for people who just like to build stuff and see how it works, a sandbox for messing around with no necessary aim, just to build better systems and bases. Those who don't care for the story or any meaningful objectives.
-Better with mods; if you're into modding, then you will be happy to know these improve the base game significantly.

Negatives:

- No inventory; you have to pick up and drag everything around one by one like real life. But unlike real-life backpacks and logical ways to carry tools don't exist for some bizarre reason. You have a useless cart and a tractor that are difficult to load items onto; that's it. This becomes a serious pain in the butt and is a great example of why an inventory is revolutionary to video games. This game mechanic means everything takes 50% longer than it really should, a nice cheap way to inflate the gameplay time. Lugging large drills and machinery around from one corner of the map to the next is just awful.
- Grinding repetitive gameplay.
-Picking up and dropping items is very poor, you have a poor marker displayed where things will land. No logical way to just place an item down gently, all items are thrown like you are controlling an angry Neanderthal man. 
-No proper map or UI; the in-game map is a ridiculous joke.
-Severe lag when you get to mid-game; the game limits what you can build as it cannot handle a few items on conveyor belts without having a nervous breakdown. This makes the game ultimately pointless if you are restricted to small builds but lots of plots and lands to build on that cannot be used.
-No real objectives or goals in the game; your job is just to build and mine and have stacks of money you can't buy anything useful with. You have tasks from citizens to build daggers, swords, or cook foods, etc., that are basic and repetitive, and that's about it; no story, no competition from other miners. Nothing!
-There are only 6 resources: Iron, Gold, cloutmium, corestone, shards, and gen stones. No option to make or manufacture other ore or metals; that's all you get, which is a very small amount compared to other factory games and gets boring fast.
-The playable character seems to find it impossible to put items down, and you have to do a little jump and then press the drop button before he is willing to let go; he constantly makes an 'umm, umm umm' noise to tell you he cannot understand how to let go of an item. This gets very annoying after a while. Perhaps having a playable character that has an IQ below 40 isn't advisable!
-The need to use pipes everywhere becomes a chore; I know it's the base of the game being 'hydroneer,' but it feels unnecessary that every part needs a pipe running through it.
-Limited machines and variety; you have a drill, pipes, grinder, and conveyor belts. You have three tiers of these items, which are a chore to reach.
- The item snapping is very poor; the game should automatically detect which way to place something, but you have to manually rotate each and every piece.
-'Logic,' which was added in later updates, isn't particularly necessary, and you only need to use a fraction of it.
- Poor tools; no proper terraforming options. The pickaxe and shovel, etc., are just awful to use and take huge amounts of time to dig. You can't select terraforming sizes or anything; a huge negative.
- Vehicles are useless; awful controls and diggers and terrain levelling vehicles are frustrating and a waste of time.
- No true automation; things break and need repairing no matter what, even when using logic auto fixers, which need restocking with tool bags (which is a huge pain).
-Farming that has been added to the game is interesting but really just the same as mining and just as irritating.

All in all, I would rate this game a 5.5 out of 10. Mildly interesting, but gameplay gets boring, the mechanics are frustrating, and it has a lot of bugs and lag that ultimately make the game unplayable after mid-game. Probably the worst factory-style game I've played in several years.

A bit confused about how anyone finds this greatly enjoyable, but I guess it has a niche audience, those who prefer grinding and messing around types of games and see poor controls and mechanics as a challenge.

Like the game.  It is a nice, balanced mining/farming/fishing game (if you go for the full King's quest).  I only have one complaint.  The DEVs need to come up with a better way of tracking individual ores/fish/gems.  Grab a bucket of ore with a couple hundred ores in it and even a good computer will start acting like a 386 and starting chunking along on the graphics.  I made the mistake of letting the emeralds accumulate for too long.  Dumped them into the gem compressor.  My screen has been frozen for over two hours processing all of the gems.  I have been watching the Task Manager just to be sure that it did not lock up.  Just for reference, I have a 3.7 GHz i9 overclocked to 50 GHz, 32GB of RAM overclocked to 40 GHz, two NVMe drives and an RTX2070 Super, so the system is no slouch.  Highly recommend setting up automation to reduce the item counts as much as possible.  Run ores directly into Smelters, gems directly into gem compressors and chopped vegetables directly into the Cut Veg Stacker.  It is soooo much easier moving around a 2000 weight iron bar than moving around 2000 iron ore.  You have been warned.   :-) 

Update:  At 2 1/2 hours it finally finished.  I am now the proud owner of a 10,000 weight emerald.  Don't do this.  lol

Rating: ★★★★☆

"Hydroneer" is a delightful sandbox simulation game that allows players to dive headfirst into the world of small-scale mining and entrepreneurial ventures. Developed and published by Foulball Hangover, this game offers a unique and relaxing experience that lets you build your mining empire from the ground up.

The premise of "Hydroneer" is relatively simple: you start with a small patch of land, a few basic tools, and a dream of striking it rich in the world of mining. The game's open-world sandbox environment provides you with the freedom to dig, mine, and explore to your heart's content. As you gather resources like gold, gems, and precious metals, you can refine them and turn a profit to expand your operations.

One of the game's most notable features is its impressive physics system, which adds a layer of realism to your mining endeavors. Using various tools and machinery, you can dig, excavate, and transport materials in a way that feels satisfyingly tactile. The sense of progression in "Hydroneer" is incredibly rewarding, as you gradually upgrade your equipment and expand your operations to tackle more challenging mining sites.

The game's visual style is charming, with a bright and colorful aesthetic that contrasts nicely with the gritty world of mining. The world is filled with interesting locations to explore, from picturesque valleys to underground caves. The day-night cycle and weather effects also add to the immersion, making each mining expedition feel unique.

While "Hydroneer" offers a relaxing and enjoyable experience, it's not without its challenges. Managing resources and optimizing your mining process can be complex, and the game doesn't hold your hand. It encourages experimentation and learning from your mistakes, which can be both rewarding and frustrating at times.

Multiplayer mode is another highlight of "Hydroneer." Playing with friends can turn mining into a cooperative and enjoyable experience, as you work together to tackle larger mining operations and share the rewards.

In summary, "Hydroneer" is a hidden gem in the world of sandbox simulation games. It offers a refreshing take on the mining genre, combining a relaxing atmosphere with satisfying gameplay mechanics. While it can be a bit daunting for newcomers, the sense of accomplishment and the joy of building your mining empire make it a worthwhile investment of your time. If you have a penchant for entrepreneurship and don't mind getting your hands dirty, "Hydroneer" is well worth exploring.

This game is really fun, but there 2 things that really stick out as a problem. As expected of a game of this type, it's a grindy resource management game that allows you to build creative, yet basic factories which at the late game allows you to fully automate and provides new tools for your mine/farm to make you're job much easier. it doesn't hold your hand and let you explore and learn how to play at your own pace however, here comes the problem, there's no real payoff to your work and while it's fun to build and try to maximize your profits, there's little to no incentives available to do so, especially with the lack of a story or other overarching challenge system. outside of just a lack of incentive, the grind is incredibly real, it provides a real problem as the controls are clunky and you have specific rules you have to follow when transporting materials, even worse you can't carry more than one item, and the physics of the game with an off-center drop marker make it challenging to progress without spending hours just getting materials in and out of buckets with each tiny piece of the ore having to be moved 1 by 1. I would not suggest the game to most people, however those who like the grind and don't need a major pay-off to enjoy themselves, then this game is still a really fun game. in the end, I will have to put a thumbs down, but I have to say, I will likely play more of it waiting for some updates or messing around with workshop items.

I give up. I've put several hours into Hydroneer but I cannot stomach investing any more time.

This is a survival / crafting / open world game. You dig, you buy + sell, you build. It's exactly the sort of game that I spend most of my time with. However, it is critically flawed: there is no inventory. You can hold just one thing at a time. The developers have provided carts + trucks that you can use to move items in bulk, but they're clumsy and slow. 

The core mechanics of the game are good, but the lack of an inventory system dooms players to wasting a non-trivial portion of their in-game time on tedious / pointless make-work exercises. I _like_ digging + building. I do not like picking up 30 pipe pieces at the store, one at a time, dropping them into a cart, and then unloading them, one at a time, at my dig site. I'm only a few hours in; I've set up a tier-1 auto-digger. I've read online that the time wasted on clumsy handling of items only increases as players progress in the game.

It's a real shame, but the 80% fun of the game is inseparable from a miserable 20% that devolves directly from the lack of an inventory system.

Thumbs down.

Title: Hydroneer - A Tranquil Sandbox Gem for Budding Prospectors

Hydroneer, developed by Foulball Hangover, is a unique and relaxing sandbox game that invites players to immerse themselves in the world of small-scale gold mining. As someone who has spent hours panning for gold and crafting intricate machinery, I'm excited to share my review of this charming indie title.

Gameplay (4.5/5):
Hydroneer's gameplay centers around the art of gold mining, offering a serene and surprisingly addictive experience. You begin as a humble prospector with basic tools like a shovel and a gold pan, but as you dig deeper into the earth and uncover the precious metal, you can expand your operations with increasingly complex machinery.

The game's progression system is well-balanced. It encourages you to start small, learning the ropes of prospecting, before gradually advancing to more efficient and automated methods. The satisfaction of discovering a valuable nugget or a rich deposit of gold is immensely rewarding.

Graphics and Sound (4/5):
Hydroneer adopts a minimalist yet visually pleasing art style. The environments are colorful and serene, with clear water bodies reflecting the surroundings beautifully. The physics-based interactions, such as digging and water flow, are well-executed and add to the immersion.

While the game's sound design is functional, the soothing music and ambient sounds contribute to the relaxing atmosphere. The gentle sound of running water and the hum of your machines create a tranquil backdrop as you work on your mining endeavors.

Crafting and Machinery (4/5):
One of Hydroneer's strengths is the crafting and machinery aspect. As you progress, you can design and build intricate contraptions using a variety of components. From water pumps and sluice boxes to conveyor belts and heavy machinery, the options for customizing your mining operation are extensive. Experimentation is encouraged, and watching your creations come to life is immensely satisfying.

The crafting system is intuitive, with a straightforward interface that allows you to assemble and disassemble components easily. The sense of creativity and problem-solving it offers is a highlight of the game.

Community and Modding (5/5):
Hydroneer benefits from an active and creative modding community. Players have developed a wide range of mods, adding new content, machinery, and even additional gameplay elements. This extends the game's longevity and provides a platform for players to share their creative mining setups.

Conclusion (4.5/5):
Hydroneer is a delightful and relaxing sandbox game that offers a unique take on the world of gold mining. Its serene atmosphere, satisfying progression, and extensive crafting possibilities make it an excellent choice for those seeking a tranquil and creatively engaging gaming experience. Whether you're a fan of simulation games or simply looking for a game to unwind with, Hydroneer shines as a gem in the world of indie gaming.

I wanted to like this game so much because the gameplay videos make it seem like it's right up my alley - but you have to line up your items and drop them into the pan instead of just clicking on it? Same way with anything else, it's so counter-intuitive it hurts. Tutorial is also lacking. The guy who wrote the tutorial is assuming the player that just bought the game has some sense of the game so it's frustrating to try and understand what's going on. Physical money that's tiny and you have to actually carry it around? Why? Yet another thing that just doesn't make sense!! Final part of the tutorial you put down a water pipe and a conveyor belt but sike you can't rotate the pipe or belt to actually fit it to the machine. I know this game could be so great and it's why I'm upset. I've been looking at the game for a while and finally decided to pull the trigger but this dev is playing Rodman-like defense making sure I don't enjoy the game.

Edit response to the developer:

While I appreciate the speedy response I won't be changing my review.  You don't have to hold someone's hand to make the game make sense.  You're taking away basic essential parts of literally every other game in the sake of being "different." 

I read every text in the tutorial that I could, sometimes the text changed quickly from task to task so I totally could've missed something.  Multiple times I was looking into the controls menu but couldn't find what I was looking for so I was left pressing random buttons on my keyboard.  Is that not a problem? I've been gaming for 20 years and if I'm having this much of an issue, inside of a tutorial, that's an issue.  I know I'm harping on this one thing, but the whole idea of a beginners guide... is to guide a beginner slowly through each aspect of the game so they can enjoy everything you've worked so hard on, correct?

I realize you're not going to change your entire game because of one review, but the mindset of "it's fun because it's hard!" is a sad way to think.  Quality of life can co-exist with difficulty.

Again, I really wanted to enjoy this game and I would love to try it again in the future. I don't leave comments or reviews hardly ever, but felt so strongly about this one that I had to.  I appreciate your effort crafting the game and your quick response to any criticism.

Arghhhh. this game is brilliant, but at the same time it literally makes me grind my teeth. The user interface is clunky to say the least. I'm recommending it but....

the start grind is fine, the graphics are nice, the way you make your own items later in the forge etc, is fine and the way you approach the landscape and the challenges is also fine. but the UI!    urghhh easily the worst I have seen in a game with this quality. so many frustrations that do not need to be there. that have grown worse as time has gone by because the developer seems to think that a flaw can be fixed by added further tedium! 

problems:
the buying items malarchy;
when you get into buying later on, it literally is a horrible system - placing items on a pad, placing coins in a bucket then buying them, then filling your vehicles is such a chore. why can't i just select what i want - how many i want and then have the chap I am buying them from auto load my vehicle? its cute to throw things around at the beginning but after a while it just annoys me - make a shopping list and just do away with the silly pick up put down pick up put down nonsense. even an upgrade is fine - so what if I have to have to buy an 'order list maker' or a 'load my truck for me' machine - just make it straight forward!

Constantly pressing the wrong control;
Placing items and rotating them is fraught with the constant pressing of the wrong button because there is no in game consistency and you move something that you didn't want to and then it won't go back - yes I know there is a locking hammer - but there's my point entirely. If you want to lock a design down so you don't accidentally move it, you are just putting a plaster on a rash and making it itch more! if the answer is running around hitting everything to stop it being picked up, The problem is, it shouldn't be that simple to pick something up in the first place so close to all the other key or mouse presses. so many construction games have this right, this game however does not.

I can't help but think that an item shaking visually- and then say holding for a couple of seconds to pick it up properly, so you have the realisation when you 'don't want to pick it up' that you can stop holding the key or the mouse to let go, is a better solution than adding more and more plasters every time the game seems to have an irritation that then becomes a major wound. It requires a major fix to the core interface to solve these issues - not more plasters or further tedium.

Making items feels like my hands are made from potatoes!;
the visual chalk on the anvil that's a pain to get your head around, then the fact you need a hammer - but, get the right hammer not the other hammers that do different things! lol its so daft. here is a solution: you go to the anvil, you select what you want from a floating menu. you add your ingredients because the menu tells you what you need, you have them nearby in a vehicle because you brought them already and thats what a vehicle gives you as an advantage over you not having one. You transfer them to the anvil via the menu. you then tick make item and bam - it uses up the ingredients, you get your item placed in the vehicle. So much easier! i'm constantly dropping bars on the floor on the scale or the anvil to eyeline a dot that sometimes is there and sometimes isn't and sometimes is affected by physics and sometimes isn't, arggh frustration. I understand the dev doesn't want a traditional 'inventory' because you can only carry one item, but the vehicles lend themselves to being that very inventory this game so badly needs anyway, nah, I'll just keep balancing things on things that are skinny to make things I then 'run' to the shop with, because loading and unloading a vehicle is so irritating I tend to just avoid it all and walk to a shop. 

Damn, I love the concept of this game and the tier mechanics and even the exploring, so I still recommend it, but I can't help be be frustrated by the 'originally' flawed UI not being fixed over and over by rethinking it somewhat rather than just adding things like a lockdown/unlock hammer, when there are several different hammers already! its almost laughable how the issues are all solved by adding more issues. 

I keep coming back to it - because I want it to be right but the UI literally gives me jaw ache when it frustrates me sooooo much. i don't want to run up and down a street, jumping higher and higher in my truck bed trying to add things that clash with things already in it!. Slap a canvass roof on it and make the contents 'virtual' if it is an issue with bounding boxes. To the game does it really matter if i want to take something from a to b? that it stays fixed awkwardly in the back of a truck and has zero physics? - that i have to bounce myself with space in the truckbed with the annoying 'duh' noise grates me soooo much more! yes its me thats stupid, duh!. if throwing things even added to physics I would tolerate it - but it doesn't, because physics is only there to annoy you sometimes when you drop a water bucket, its not there to be fun, and it doesn't add to the gameplay.  I drive into a bucket at 100mph and my truck stops dead - did i mention the bucket is in the air because I overloaded the truck 10mins earlier because I jumped too high to get it in the back last drop off? If physics was a thing, that items being a thing too makes it fun - imagine pushing the items you bought with the truck into the mine or store you just made?. You can't sadly - so why the physical item in a world where it does nothing but add to the repetitiveness of loading unloading bouncing and dropping. I only need a real item that is unaffected by physics, when I come to build with it. It smells like an original idea that was kept for the wrong reasons and as time has gone on, its a smell that follows you around, actively mocking you.

buy it because at its core it is a brilliant game and a great idea - but please moan about the same things that annoy you, because they will never get fixed unless the developer realises they could do this in a way that is much more fun and much more usable.

Hydroneer is a cautionary example of why trying to be too many different things at once means you succeed at none of them.

Hydroneer wants to be a mining and exploration game. Except there is effectively nothing to explore worth noting and the mining is rudimentary "right click-make block disappear".

Hydroneer wants to be a construction and creative sandbox building game. But the items they give you to work with are bland, limited and have had almost nothing done with or added to them since their initial introduction back in the beta.

Hydroneer wants to be an automation and factory game. But there are no production tiers or choices. Every single setup makes the same production line of drill>harvester>>gem polisher>smelter/gem crusher. There is no variation and almost no thought that goes into it.

Hydroneer wants to be a prospecting game. But the prospecting is bland, rudimentary and monotonous. Money is extremely difficult to acquire early on in the game spending hours panning and prospecting for tidbits of materials. Then, at a specific point of progress you reach a critical mass and get your first automated mining production line set up. Money instantly transforms from being your most hard fought and won commodity into being completely worthless as you begin generating literally millions of coins a minute automatically. Nothing costs anywhere near that much either.

Hydroneer wants to be a farming simulator and an RPG, but it was built off the engine designed for mining and automation with farming being inexorably tied to RPG questing. The process is even more tedious as crops use a separate currency where you have to run to villages who ask for arbitrary recipes with exact amounts of specific vegetables and offer amounts of tokens so small they often don't cover the cost of what they ask for, let alone be worth your effort to fulfil their request.

I'm half expecting the next big update to try and introduce FPS elements. In short, the game doesn't know what it wants to do with itself and none of it is fun. Let this game serve as a cautionary tale. Try to do everything and you will succeed at none of it.

A unique take on an industrial game; it has no UI, and instead you carry items by hand, cart, or vehicle. The crafting is very basic and you won't need to craft much other than product to sell. Pretty simple to get into once you get used to it. You start with a pickup truck which is all you really need, but there are different utility vehicles available. Basic automation is simple, but needs maintenance (which can be made   trivial by more advanced automation). The game speeds up very quickly once you have your first real setup. There are no dangers as far as I've progressed, so it is a very relaxing experience with no combat.

I played this game soooo much and I had such a blast. Mining to get that next tier, down to the next level, automate one more thing. Fishing was great trying to get that best fishing pole. Farming was okay, but was WAAAY more tedious because crops yield so little and the token quests very quickly ramp up to require no many tomatoes and carrots. You hate it because you have to make such a huge farm with no real way to automate it. Sprinkler range sucks so you have to rig a drip system to water plants and with a huge farm being a necessity so is the lag from 1000 drops falling. Having to tear up and replant after each...and...every... harvest is so.... UGH!

Then one day it hits you, farming is actually the best part of the game because it takes soooooo long to max out. You suddenly realize that your mining has been automated for a while and the only thing left to upgrade on it is to get corestone pipes from grinding quests, but what's the point? Your tier 1 and 2 pipes have been mining the whole time you've been fishing and setting up a massive farm. By the time you get back to maxing mining you have literally 1,000,000 kg of bars sitting in your smelter to use on quests. Why do you need faster pipes? So you go back to fishing, only to realize that once you have the max level fishing pole there's nothing else to do. Not to mention the max fishing pole really doesn't make any difference and only took about 30 mins TOPS to aquire. Aside from catching slightly larger fish it does nothing. By this time there's no point to catching larger fish because your mine has already allowed you to sell a 500k gold bar, 50k corestone, 250k emerald necklace and you're sitting on a million+ hydrocoins. Now all that's left is farming and the lag from your drip system makes it unbearable.

In short this game was super fun and absolutely worth the cost. I had such a blast!!! I highly recommend it to people. But it is very bittersweeet. I want to keep playing, I want to unlock new stuff and make a different type of mine, but there's no point. It's like playing a game in creative now and the mechanics of logic are WAAAAAAAAAAY too convoluted to make machines. Seriously YouTube logic setups and see how ridiculous even simple machines are. I saw older videos of content that I wish was still in the game. The wall of items you have to build to unlock the next was nice, make that and let that be the way that you unlock tier 2 and 3 equipment, instead oif just putting it behind a VERY easy to achieve coin cost. Using your resources to upgrade the towns and add new npcs or unlock a progression tier or materials to build with would be great. How about locking the purchase of all the mining areas and forcing people to do one at a time, each with its own unique challenge instead of just a cosmetic difference. Give fishing an actual point, give us fishing quests, require fish for upgrading stuff/nps/towns. 

Again I love the game, absolutely recommend, just be warned once you gets to tier 3 dirt and put down your first mining drill, the game is over.

Rating: Highly recommended!!!

So glad they put in achievements within the game.  Understandably they were hesitant as it is a sandbox at heart, but the achievements guide you through all aspects of the game.  After 100% completing, you will get to experience everything from (almost) the deepest levels of mining, numerous vehicle types and capabilities, NPC interactions, 3 different currencies, all the different mining locations, cooking, and fishing.  Btw, a big hint on the fishing master achievement ... it's all in the rod. ;)

If they ever make a hydroneer 2, things I'd love to see include: all the things in hydroneer 1, lab research and related unlocks, different engine that handles the number of resources generated better (gem compressors and smelters in your conveyor belt line are your best friend!), and deeper NPC interactions.  They have a nice store to help support them, but I'll be in take my money mode in a few years if they build on this one even further.

Absolutely masterly crafted game, forged from the hands of the best indie developer I've ever seen. Hours of content and exploring can be found within the mere boundary's of this game. The NPC's voice lines really bring them to life. One of my favorite voice lines is "One day I'll buy a shiny new truck!" Truly inspiring words. Every area has its own design and that's what makes them stand out. It's almost as if they have their own personality which is what sets this game apart from any other grindy game such as this one. It keeps me interested and entertained with a hook of bait Mr. Krabs would be destined to fall for. Money. That's what drives this game to it's full potential. With a few sets of drills and other equipment, map exploration, different plots of land, trucks, and much more, this game is addicting, creative, and sometimes comical and goofy. (Flashbacks of sending NPS's into the void with my truck) 10/10 game. should definitely buy for sure.

I wanted to enjoy it but I just couldn't. The controls are really bad - you have no inventory and can only pick up one item at a time. When you want to drop this item (either to set it down or pick up a new one), you have to make sure its hitbox isn't currently colliding with any object or part of the world, otherwise you'll get an annoying "nuh uh" sound. For a game that's built around mining in cramped, close-quarters tunnels, this gets extremely frustrating extremely fast. There isn't much content either - after the horribly tedious early game phase of scrubbing dirt from buckets, you instantly hit the end game of conveyors and a mining machine. Would not recommend purchasing if not on sale for $4.99 or less.

You would be better off playing Factorio. If you really want a 3D automation game you should check Satisfactory or Minecraft with Buildcraft mods. There is nothing streamlined about this game. You waste time on tedious tasks that detract from the already clunky automation system.

Ladies and gentlemen, gather 'round and prepare yourselves for a mining adventure like no other! Welcome to the hilariously entertaining world of "Hydroneer," where digging for gold and resources has never been more comically rewarding!

First things first, let's talk about the developer, Max, and those vlog update videos. I mean, who needs stand-up comedy when you've got Max giving us the latest updates in his unique style? It's like watching a mining-themed sitcom, complete with hydro-powered machines and primitive tools duking it out for the best gags! Bravo, Max, bravo!

Now, let's dive deep into the game itself. Hydroneer isn't just about digging; it's about digging with style! With a state-of-the-art voxel terrain system, you'll be creating cave networks, quarry pits, and even mud mountains! It's like Bob Ross meets Minecraft in a wild, artistic adventure. Happy little mining machines, everyone!

And hold your prospecting helmets, folks, because this game ain't just about digging mindlessly! Oh no, Hydroneer is a true tycoon-style experience. Build structures, manage hydro pipes, and control pressure like the mining maestro you were always meant to be. Who knew mining could be so sophisticated? adjusts monocle

But wait, there's more! Hydroneer introduces NPC and farming mechanics, turning your mining venture into a thriving community of soup-cooking, jewelry-crafting villagers! Move over, Gordon Ramsay, because we've got miners-turned-chefs in the house!

And let's not forget the latest updates, folks! We now have Ore Veins, making resource hunting more thrilling than ever! I can see it now: miners racing against each other, shovels flying, and a massive gold rush ensues. Hilarity guaranteed!

Oh, and how about that Hydro Mole? No, it's not an underground spy agency, though it might be as sneaky! This versatile digging machine has locked angles for easy navigation, perfect for digging up, down, or even straight into a comedy gold mine!

And hold your pickaxes, there's a mainline quest too! Progress through Bastion Keep, complete a quest for the king, and get a pretty sizable reward! It's like an epic quest wrapped in a humor-infused mining frenzy. Are you laughing yet?

But wait, there's even more! Over 50 Steam Achievements to unlock! Achievements like "Gold Digger Extraordinaire" and "Master of Soup" will have you ROFL-ing as you conquer the mining world with your wit and charm.

All in all, Hydroneer is an absolute gem of a game! With its active development and Max's vlog antics, it's like a never-ending comedy show that keeps on giving. If you enjoy laughing your way through mining mayhem and hydro-powered hilarity, do yourself a favor and grab Hydroneer now. It's gold, Jerry, gold!

Tried the game again in 2023. What I think still stands.

I thought that I'd like it but I guess I was wrong.

Pro:
- You can build machines that do your the job for you
- You can build houses (for whatever reason)

Cons
- Not having an inventory sounds good on paper but makes this tedious busy work
- You are building objects on a grid but the landscape is not grid based which results in shoveling dirt around until something fits
- Money is a level object like everything else which means you have to carry it around to buy stuff (which sounds real) but imagine you can only carry 1 item at a time even money unless you use buckets or something

My main issue with this is the lack of inventory. It makes everything bothersome. Since you can only carry one item in your hands that means you constantly have to drop and pick up items that roll around in the level with physics. You can drop stuff in buckets or on a pallet if the physics decide to play along.
When you want to make a shopping trip you have to put the money in the back of the truck, drive the jelly truck to the shop, put the money in the wood bin, pick up whatever you want to buy from the shelf, drop it on the buy area one by one, push the buy button, pick up the bought items one by one from the buy area onto the back of the jelly truck, pick up the money again, and drive the jelly truck back home. Repeat for unloading and building.

I accept that the dev does not want to use an inventory but I decided that its just not for me then. I wait until there is an inventory either by mod or patch or drop the game entirely

Overall: 8/10
Pros:
This is a fairly simple game compared to other automation type games like Satisfactory. Makes it easier to pickup and run with. Create a simple design then scale it. 
The addition of farming and fishing elongate the playtime and are enjoyable for a time.
Using Achievements as goals. The game doesn't have a set structure or growth path (could be pro or con based on preference).
A simply good time waster.

Cons:
I'm getting close to 100% achievements and have no use for Tier 3 drills. Maybe this will be addressed in further updates, but a well scaled Tier 2 setup is more than sufficient.
The simplicity can make it seem shallow at times. 5 ores. 4 gems. These all come from the drills and can be sorted using splitters. Even at Tier 1 with 8 spliters you have automated almost the whole mining portion. Tier 2 adds a new ore, which amounts to same basic design but with another splitter. 
Fishing has no automation at all. The fishing pots found what I needed for an upgraded rod or two, but that's it. 
Farming has automation but is prohibitively expense and uses exclusive tokens. 2k for sprinklers, guess I'm drip watering everything. 2.6k for the combine. Will probably be worth it. However, I'm already setup 6 rows of 10, a row for each crop. Not sure it is worth destroying everything for the cool toy.

This game has come a long way in the three years it's been here. I originally gave it a poor review but the devs have seriously improved this to the point where it's downright addictive. 

It takes a special mindset because it's mostly physics based rather than snap and click, even dropping something into a pan requires you to actually aim for the pan or it winds up bouncing on the ground. And there is no inventory, so the world is your playground, there's no ready crafting of tools and storage. You buy the building blocks from storekeeper NPCs. You sell your "harvest" be it mineral or plant, buy more equipment to automate it better and fuller.  They added a quest system and some logical unlocks which gives you some direction, though very open ended because, well, you're doing whatever you want. There's plenty of frustration getting things to work the way you want and enough dopamine reward as you progress to make it worthwhile. 

However there's also no health, no fatigue, no hunger, no stats whatsoever. You are constrained by a semi-real physical environment but you aren't going to die, or freeze, or get eaten by bears, or starve. It's just you and a world of resources constrained by game physics. The addiction part is not unlike the infinite clickers that just continue to go up. Except you're building something. Kind of.

This game is great alone but saying it has multiplayer is borderline scamming, its split-screen only and its horrible to try to play.

I like that I can play this game either mindlessly or intensely, depending on my mood. The building is satisfying. The environment is charming. The NPCs are entertaining in various ways. All in all, this is a very enjoyable game.

Update: After 55 hours of playing Hydroneer, I still cannot stop thinking about, and playing, it! I am brand new to PC gaming. The past 37 years of gaming has been on consoles. You'd think I would be eager to see and play a variety of games on PC, especially genres I could not play on console, but no. I just want to play Hydroneer. I mentioned in the first paragraph that this game can be played mindlessly or intensely, and I think that still holds true. Sometimes I just run about completing villager wants. This doesn't require much thought, so the game is more casual for lack of a better term. Other times I am tinkering with logic and/or working out more efficient ways to mine, farm, automate and produce. To spend hours attempting a build and then see it work is wildly satisfying. Occasionally, a project doesn't work as intended and that is still fun because I get to continue hunting for the solution. There is always a solution (if you think within the confines of the game). Gameplay aside, the game is beautiful and charming. The world isn't large, and it doesn't need to be because you can lose yourself in builds that have small footprints. Additionally, the close proximity to towns is a plus because you will be frequently running to the shops for supplies, tools, and equipment. The building mechanic is pretty good. For the most part I can place items without frustration. The best part of the building mechanic is how everything just seems to line up, which I believe is thanks to the three-dimensional building grid. This is very helpful for a new player of building/automation games such as me. I can put something anywhere within the build area and I know it will connect. It may look ugly, but it will work. Well, I have gone on long enough. If you are considering playing this game, I highly, highly encourage you to do so. I don't think you will be disappointed.

While I find the game relaxing and have some enjoyment, I can't see myself telling others to play this game because it has some features that will turn away the majority of people. For example:
-Having to pick up and carry currency around to drop in buckets to pay for things is quirky but also tedious.
-Not all items in the game can be placed down, some are just dropped from your hand and when dropped they don't fall to the reticle in the middle of the screen, they fall to another reticle that is hard to see unless you edit the graphics settings.
-Not all things can be placed down and it can be difficult to drop them where you want to them to go.
-The day/night cycle is there for "realism" but it doesn't actually add or change anything in the game beyond "its night so its harder to see now"
-The game lighting is not very smooth. If you move away from a lantern you are not facing the lighting will suddenly snap to a darker setting and then if you move closer it will snap back, this is a big jarring to have happen while playing.
Overall, this is a very specific kind of game for a very specific kind of player so it's hard to recommend to other people.

I liked playing Hydroneer but probably won't play much more. The fun for me was in figuring out the oddities of the game and its physics. Once I figured those out (~15 hours), I didn't [i]actually like[/i] the interaction or the systems.

Learning how "the verbs" of this game worked was a fun challenge. But since you can only carry one thing at a time (slowly), actually implementing your plans and blueprints gets [i]really[/i] tedious. Also, the Build mode is [b]unforgivably irritating[/b] and unoptimized.

I really liked finding ways to perfect my gameplay (going to the store with a cart, filling it up with L-Bend Pipes, purchasing them, Jumping that cart into my truck, filling a second cart with T-Bend pipes, purchasing and Jumping it into the truck, etc.), but that's about the extent of the fun.

The physics are well-realized, but not very realistic and EXTREMELY particular to the Hydroneer universe. The day/night cycle is brutal and the lighting is frankly pretty awful (even with torches/headlamps/etc.) and aggravating.

Overall, I liked learning how to play Hydroneer, but once I was really cruising and raking in the money and guild tokens, I no longer wanted to interact with the janky interface. And that's not true for games like Satisfactory or Hardspace: Shipbreaker.

So be careful! I had fun, but after 15-20 hours, I actively dislike actually engaging with the game.
This game has potential, but it needs better controls... and an inventory.

Hydroneer has all the features you could want in a systematizing , process oriented game. it's a little slow and sadly that bottlenecks the speed at which you can progress along the curve toward the real meat of the matter which as I see it is constructing really interesting processes for organizing production and distribution of materials et all.

Is it worth your money? If you love systems and you have already played out the other games which are, perhaps more "process" focused then yes, it's worth your money on the other hand if you have not played such games as for example "Opus Magnum" (Zachtronics), or "Maybe Dungeon Warfare 2" (which although technically tower defense, can be viewed as a tower defense systematization game) the hold off for a bit and play those first, you'll probably be more satisfied.

All in all I'd  give the game an overall positive rating in spite of the fact that it drags it's ass in places and isn't really brave about the possibilities it creates.

Hydroneer has been a well-worthy investment for the $6.99 I paid back in 2021. The game offers a unique and engaging experience, allowing players to dive into the world of mining and crafting. However, there are some notable drawbacks that hinder the overall enjoyment. The gameplay can feel clunky, and there are certain quality of life fixes that are missing. For instance, the inability to buy or move more than a limited amount of items without experiencing severe FPS drops on a high-end graphics card can be frustrating. Nonetheless, despite these issues, Hydroneer has provided me with over 20 hours of fantastic gameplay at an unbeatable price. I'm eagerly looking forward to returning once the performance and quality of life improvements are implemented.

This game could be fun, but is so, so clunky and unpolished. Every turn, it was like I was fighting with the game to let me play it. Maybe once the game is finished it'll be worth playing, but as-is, it's just frustrating.
 
Some specific issues: There's no inventory. You can hold exactly one item at a time. The map is an item you have to carry with you. Running back and forth to shops takes forever. There's no chest. The game is very resource-intensive. 

Here's the starting gameplay: Pick up your shovel. Dig four scoops into a bucket. Drop the shovel. Pick up the bucket. Walk over to the pan. Try to dump the bucket in the pan. Realize the pointer isn't aimed where you drop things. Get more dirt. Dump dirt in pan. Drop bucket. Pick up pan. Drop pan into river. Pick up pan. Drop pan on ground. Walk over to brush. Pick up brush. Walk over to pan. Click on pan. Drop brush. 
Congrats, you have now earned $8. Repeat 30 or so times before you're allowed to actually play the game at all.

I feel like that game is the very definition of a early access game : there are many features, making the game feel oddly bloated, but with some very confusing progression.
To put it simply, the game is "Hydroneer", so you expect mostly mining and crafting, since this is what the game encourages you to do, and what most videos focused on. But the truth is that, in a similar fashion to Slime Rancher, the mining is only a small part of the game that you will quickly automate anyway, meaning that the "real" core of the game isn't really the mining but rather expanding your activity in several way (fishing, farming, even cooking), with some really slightly building.

And this is the problem : the progression in the game goes from stupid and mindless to really rewarding. You get to set up automated mining, you get better furnaces to work faster, and so on...
But at the same time, you still have to pick up nuggets after nuggets of ore, individually, because there's no Quality Of Life improvement that improves picking up items and manipulating them. I cannot explain that part really well, but to put it simply, if you played Cooking Simulator, you'll have a hard time getting used to Hydrooner.

Overall, this feel like a game that had little ambition at first, but got bloated with features, no clear roadmap, and quite honestly the translations are below turd.
I was sure this was early access since it suffers from flaws that I saw brought up for The Forest, my biggest surprise was that it isn't, and that it's finished, so so much still feel unpolished, to a point that I'm almost getting angry playing it because I can tell it could be so much better.

EDIT : and I forgot, but another proof that the game is meant for its EA audience : the tutorial is a joke, and nothing is explained, you have to figure out how the gem crusher works by yourself.

Hydroneer has a fun and unique take on it's genre that is both refreshing and interesting. It's a little buggy at times, but the developer has shown dedication to updating, patching, and generally keeping the game fun and accessible. I love this little game, and you will as well!

Hydroneer is a great game with fun aspect of strategy, exploration and creativity. When you start off, you are limited with tools to start mining and making money. 

Water is widely used and is a very essential resource that you need, it is used to power your machines! Power by water is Hydroneer's main concept after all!
In the beginning, when you progress in mining and make more money, you can automate to make YOUR mining method more efficient, by buying conveyor belts along with other automating tools, like Drills and more! 

Besides automating, base building is an optional part of this game! You can make your way through your factory more efficient, by buying and placing foundations, steps, ramps and more! Speaking of buying, there are various types of markets you can purchase tools, machines, base-building parts, even furniture from, also Jewelers to sell your goods, such as metals you mine, weapons you make in the Anvil(Weapons are only for selling) and jewelry! 

Logic is a very interesting and tricky aspect of this game! Besides automating your factory, you are able to CONTROL your factory with Logic! Switches, Wires, circuits, more advanced machines for higher efficiency,  BOMBS to blast your way through dirt or MINI NUKE to demolish your old base!
Welcome to Hydroneer! What kind of jaw-dropping mining base will you build?

Update-7/12/23 

Hydroneer multiplayer is not at all what it could be, however due to some technical issues, split screen is only available! I am sure that the dev and his team will eventually work a way around this at some point in the future!

The farming update, as well as tasks certainly adds a lot more to do in Hydroneer! I am really loving it!

The new prospecting update is great with new, advanced vehicles and equipment, like the prospecting helmet!

Game has a lot of potential, I appreciate the automation aspect of it but it's incomplete.  Mining can be automated, but if you do it the wrong way items will build up and cause serious lag even with a reasonably good computer, farming can't be automated, fishing seems like it can be automated but the sorters don't work properly.  In addition some quests require a certain weight of a single item and there is no way to automate that process.  Many quests request something with a decimal (ex. 3.5 weight) and 3 weight is nearly impossible to find so your only option is to hand sort and weight each item until you find one heavy enough.  If fishing could be automated and weight sorting could be automated this game would be a lot better.  Buying things from stores is also a pain as you have to bring each individual item to a spot to purchase, there is no bulk purchasing option.  Mods have been made to fix most of this but overall it just feels to me like a game only partway done.  I recommend Factorio or Satisfactory (still in beta as of this comment 7-7-2023) but its certainly possible that the Dev's are still making updates, I'll try to check back in a year but this game kinda feels like it should still be in beta, lots of potential though,

because bees don't care

stop flying in the house!

a day and hitchhiked around the hive.

- Yeah.

Everybody knows,
sting someone, you die.

  
Don't waste it on a squirrel.
Such a hothead.

  
I guess he could have
just gotten out of the way.

  
I love this incorporating
an amusement park into our day.

  
That's why we don't need vacations.

  
Boy, quite a bit of pomp...
under the circumstances.

  
- Well, Adam, today we are men.
- We are!

  
- Bee-men.
- Amen!

  
Hallelujah!

  
Students, faculty, distinguished bees,

  
please welcome Dean Buzzwell.

graduating class of...

at Honex Industries!

a division of Honesco

  
and a part of the Hexagon Group.

Wow.

  
Wow.

  
We know that you, as a bee,
have worked your whole life

  
to get to the point where you
can work for your whole life.

  
Honey begins when our valiant Pollen
Jocks bring the nectar to the hive.

  
Our top-secret formula

  
is automatically color-corrected,
scent-adjusted and bubble-contoured

  
into this soothing sweet syrup

  
with its distinctive
golden glow you know as...

  
Honey!

  
- That girl was hot.
- She's my cousin!

  
- She is?
- Yes, we're all cousins.

  
- Right. You're right.
- At Honex, we constantly strive

  
to improve every aspect
of bee existence.

  
These bees are stress-testing
a new helmet technology.

  
- What do you think he makes?
- Not enough.

  
Here we have our latest advancement,
the Krelman.

- Oatches that little strand of honey

  
that hangs after you pour it.
Saves us millions.

  
Oan anyone work on the Krelman?

  
Of course. Most bee jobs are
small ones. But bees know

  
that every small job,
if it's done well, means a lot.

  
But choose carefully

  
because you'll stay in the job
you pick for the rest of your life.

  
The same job the rest of your life?
I didn't know that.

as a species, haven't had one day off

  
in 27 million years.

Wow! That blew my mind!

  
"What's the difference?"
How can you say that?

  
One job forever?
That's an insane choice to have to make.

  
I'm relieved. Now we only have
to make one decision in life.

than you and I will see in a lifetime.

  
It's just a status symbol.

You grab that stick, and you just

the more I think about it,

  
maybe the honey field
just isn't right for me.

That's a bad job
for a guy with a stinger.

  
Janet, your son's not sure

into honey. Our son, the stirrer!

Let's open some honey and celebrate!

Shave my antennae.

  
Shack up with a grasshopper. Get

- We're starting work today!

Pollen counting, stunt bee, pouring,

Wow!

Updated:
his is an early review, which I will update after I have persisted with the game. Initial impressions aren't great but I am hopping it is a grower.

Pros:
* It's an indy game and a lot of effort has been put into the game

Cons:
* Controls and the clunky mechanism to pick up and drop stuff - Someone please tell me that trying to place things into or onto other things isn't some kind of frustrating mini game!
* Dropping money (because you don't have pockets or an inventory) means it will sometimes clip through the floor and be lost forever to the out of bounds gremlins! I have been unlucky and lost two lots of money after moving it out of my pan to find ores at the very beginning of the game, was searching everywhere - I will persist with the game but jeez this is annoying!
* Why do I turn like I'm dragging the cart if I use a controller (but still need a mouse to access settings and menus, that you must use the escape key to escape from because there is no exit menu icon!)
* What does the tutorial actually do that couldn't be done my having pop-ups in the main game - seems redundant and not very helpful tbh
* Runs like a beast with a bad head, I'm guessing the excitement to develop ideas and features has kicked optimization into a corner

I am genuinely hoping that choosing not to refund was a good choice, but I can see this game being battered for refunds in the first few hours if my experience is anything to go by. 

Update - The pros and cons still stand, however using a steam community controller set-up is a must - the controls are still wonky but at least some of the pain is removed. The game definitely gets more engaging once you are building your first set of machines and the rough edges kinda add to the game's charm. This is a fun title to play and helps scratch the factorio [any other resource / builder type game] itch. As a plus I'm also teaching my partner northern English dialect - take a gander!
The intro could use some more direction, maybe even just a brief NPC introduction. Other than that it's an awesome game once you take the time to learn it.

The modularity of building your own mining system is nice, but the "best" type of machine is still pretty evident.

Some quality of life improvements for buying multiples of items would be welcome.   Even just the tedium of loading things into the truck or wagon gets old.  Paying extra for delivery of common items in the late game would be cool!   This is probably available as a mod, but mods break achievements.......so I'd rather not.
The new update makes things a lot better and easier to move items around, while still keeping the original basic game elements intact

This has amazing potential to be a great game.  I'm not sure which direction the developers will take it next, but Automation in game can be clunky, and the game will freeze for a bit on first save attempt.

So why do I think it's not currently worth it?  Well, I had been playing on a save for several days, working diligently on making the forge into an epic base, when all of a sudden Windows crashes.
Computer reboots, and I get the game started back up, and load my save... to find there is nothing there, it's as what was loaded was a brand new save.
While there is a 'backup system', the backup got updated when I went to exit the game, to check the backup, so even that was pointless.

Sure, the existence of a backup system does appear like it was taken into consideration (possibly), but it is impossible to exit the game without using the save buttons in the menu, or force quitting the game, and even then, it may already be too late to use a backup.  Oh, and there isn't multiple backups, there is only 1.

So, 130 hours pumped into this game, for it to all vanish like waking up from a dream.  It soured my impression of the game greatly.

A sandbox with unique and fun to discover automation / farming techniques. The tutorial teaches you the basics and gives you the rest to explore with. Fun loop, consistent art style, lots of content.

!!! IMPORTANT !!! That being said there are a few things holding this back from being up there with Factorio/Satisfactory/Stardew/etc:

1. Multiplayer coop is splitscreen only. This game would be amazing with friends and seems really strange that this wasnt prioritized over other updates. 
2. Purchasing certain items in mass can only be described as migraine inducing, I dont say this lightly. You should be excited to build your base, it shouldnt be a mundane chore in which loading the truck and unloading is a mess that usually takes longer than actually placing the items where they need to go. 
3. More of a preference but the lack of a tool bar / toolbelt does the game no favors. Having to drop every item on the ground / rack before picking up another item, etc etc gives the game such a sluggish feel to an otherwise fun experience 

The last 2 points are a repellent that does a great job at keeping me from playing this game. I have to really convince myself to put up with the latter in order to enjoy the rest of the game. All things aside Id still recommend it if its on sale, great game for playing casually every now and then.

The economy could definitely use some tweaking, as well as some long term, repeatable goals to keep things interesting once you've got your mine fully automated.

My playtime of over 100 hours is actually 3 play-throughs. Not because I necessarily wanted to start over, I ran out of things to do, but enjoyed the game so much I wanted to start over to give myself goals again.

I have been playing Hydroneer since the early days and its a great game, simple to understand and play, definitely a good time sink if your bored. The developer keeps adding new updates which is lovely to see and I genuinely cant wait to see more content.

Only issue I have is that I find the game too easy, usually I can beat the game within 14 hours without leaving the starting plot of Ember Cradle... after you get your first few drills you can pretty much earn 70'000 Hydro coins in about 10-15 mins which is nice but there's not really much intensive to carry on getting the top tier equipment when you can buy everything in the game at that point.

I mean you can set yourself goals to make as much cash as possible but that gets boring in my opinion, I would like to see more industry added to the game with a focus on using your materials to make things like building materials or make complex parts for ships and vehicles etc... 

But that's just my opinion, I love this game anyway and I will definitely keep playing :)

Got all the achivements so thought it deserves a review. 
This game have so many quality of life improvements that seems to be overlooked. but it set out to build something and what is expected is 100% there.

Its extremely satisfying finishing a setup and seeing it function. 

Its extremely annoying to see my FPS go to 10 everytime i have to buy more than 10 items of anything. 

So for anyone new, Carts can stack things without collisions after they settle. carts can be placed in the back of your truck. Thats how you purchase and transport things the cheesy way. 

Clear improvements of the game i do not understand does not exist: 
1. Plots having a purchase and delivery station, spawning items without collision on a pallet at your locations (making the pallet remember how many items it has left instead of having to handle 100 individual objects), make the payment of every item 5 times higher to reward players for making something good (and to actually have something to use the millions of coins on)
2. delivery of items is such a pain, make it so people can come pick up their order or something. I want to build not drive around with a soup. 
3. I miss the excavator ... i loved the idea of slowly digging out a plot instead of using the infinete diggers, Even had this cool delivery setup back when it was still in the game. 
4. The anvil ... oh god everyone hate that area, It looks amazing but after you been there once and have to take that damn elevator and transport items you will understand... Quick partial fix, force the elevator to adjust direction to where you are using a trigger. (its always on its way down as your moving around the corner)

But again, in the end its just a chill nice time of a game that rewards you with snowball effects instead of trying to punish you at every corner. which is why ive played it so much and began hunting the achivements.

I wanted to love this game.  I might have loved this game.  Unfortunately it causes such severe motion sickness I have no possibility of loving this game.  By the time I threw in the towel and gave up tweaking different settings to see if it made any difference I already had > 2 hours in it, half of which was idle / tabbed out searching for answers, so couldn't refund it or I definitely would have refunded it.  

Now to go hug a bucket for a while until this nausea passes...

UPDATE:  grandmaMax, yes I did all of the above.  I also turned down every detail setting possible and am pushing 120 fps.   I've been able to play longer session with the FOV set very narrow but I'm still rather ill after playing.  I think part of the issue is that it hitches about once a second when moving so it's just not smooth.  I can play 20 minutes, get up and walk away for 10 and come back.  That's about my limit.

I'm changing my recommendation to yes simply because I'm probably a special case + I'm playing in Linux which may be impacting the engine somewhat, but I play a ton of games in linux on this machine that don't have this issue.  I've also seen community posts about Hydroneer with others having the same issue on a high performance window gaming rig.

After reaching 100% achievements in just under 90 hours, sometimes spending 12+hours a day playing this, I can finally recommend this game to anyone with highly addictive personalities and way too time on their hands. Did I reach the king? yes, but finding that much Onyx is just out of the question right now since I need to get back to my life again :'D

Even with the severe frame drops from carrying multiple resources/items at a time, the game is a great experience if you're the type of person who likes to watch numbers go up and work with a tier system with resources and activities. I especially loved the Yorkshire citizens and have expanded my lexicon of slang to annoy my friends with.

My only real complaint is that I wish vegtables grew faster and the cutting mechanics were a bit clearer. I had to run over Louise about six times to get the frustration of wasting 45.5 tomatoes and what I thought was 28 carrots but turned into 26.2 after cutting. Only for her to follow this up by spitting it out and throwing my bowl of scran on the ground like an ungrateful child. This of course happened after the carrots thing had already screwed me up without me realizing it on someone else, and me wasting about 100 pounds of carrots by forgetting to add the tomatoes before putting them into the soup bowl.

All in all though I did enjoy it and I will be purchasing some merch from the store out of appreciation for both the games and the devs sticking to it for this long when a lot of people tend to abandon their games after about a year of release if even that. I might come back and work out that thing with the onyx but I need to be productive again.

Welcome to the modified Minecraft, where difficulty is synonymous with inconvenience. Thou hast all the tools at thy disposal, provided thou usest only one at a time. Thou canst automate, but ensure all is properly aligned, else thou shalt bring thy PC to its knees. Nevertheless, it is still recommended, and it makes for a fine game whilst thou listenest to a podcast.

Do I recommend to buy this game? Yes. If you can get cheap price, then sure, you can give it a go and have some fun. Graphics are good, mechanics are interesting. It will take roughly 60 hours causal play to finish king quest and I probably will not play this anymore after that. 

Then why I downvoted? Because in my eyes game have been ruined by very bad decisions. In short time of playing player have enough money to buy basically everything he wants. Which is not bad but there should be introduced more stuff player can spend money on. So intstead of fixing this issue, devs decided to create even more problems by issuing new currencies. And blocked access to new blocks behind quests. I don't know what are they thinking, that from now on every new tier of miners will require new coin type and new quest line? It's terrible decision because instead of adding more sandbox, building, automation elements, they are adding more grind that can't be automated at all. This changed the game from small but good automation game to quest grind fest. And I don't think so players wanted that. I didn't for sure.

On top of that game is not balanced at all. For example, you grind tokens to be able to buy Cropper but when you finally do it, then there is no real need to use it because you don't need more tokens. Sure you could buy greenhouse but there is no real need to have one. Why they simply didn't allowed to buy that Cropper for like 100k creds so you can do quests without so big grind wall is beyond me. 
The prices also feels random because you need to pay 2100 tokens for one sprinkler and 2700 per Cropper? How is that? And if you don't believe me that it's bad, then look at numbers: only 0.3% players managed to grind quests to get Cropper. Which is real shame because it's good machine, that you almost will have no need to use.

Another wierd thing is that some devs are working on mods for the game in their spare time. Why they won't add those items to the game is again, beyond me. Using mods prevents you from getting achievements so I don't want to use them and I expect to have everything in game and not as mods.

Overall I still think that game is promising but I doubt that many things will be fixed which is a shame because this game had a chance to be 10/10 but with it's problems and bad decisions is at most 5/10. I would play it more but I can't be bothered to run around and do tedious quests.

Hydroneer is fantastic, and for a full price of $22 NZD, is one of the best value/playtime simulator games on Steam. On top of this, I've never seen such a stable physics based game in my entire life. I'll write this review to be accessible to both Steam tourists and people who've seen hundreds of hours of Hydroneer gameplay on Youtube. 

It's got a steep learning curve with some of the building structure, but once you poke around and explore in the mechanics, it comes naturally. The point of the game really boils down to panning for gold to building monstrous machines that mine resources for you, then min-maxing the efficiency of a machine so it spews out resources like a glittery waterfall. You're also not limited to just mining since in the last half a year, full systems for farming, smithing and fishing have been fully implemented and work like a charm. 

However, you should know before you buy that the developers are very hard-line on their choice to limit automation of machines with the use of machine part breakdowns (for only a few machine parts, but the most essential for automated mining) on grounds that the player should be the most essential tool, and the game can lag something fierce if you overload a bucket with raw resources. 

But, I have a vanilla fix without the use of Steam's Workshop, which disables achievements. They apply at all stages of the game. 

First, lag. Drop resources into auto-smelters and compressors either by hand or with a simple conveyor sorting system. While they are pricey machines at early game, this completely eliminates all lag until very-late game. You can find pretty simple sorting systems on Google and the official Bridgepour wiki that do this for you. 

Second, machine breakdown is a pain in the ass which forces the player to buy and use consumable repair kits to start production again, but Hydroneer has a device called a Spanner Hurling Unit. Point these at your machines and hook it up with logic (electrical) cables. It'll use a consumable spanner to repair the device to full durability. A spanner unit holds 20 consumables. Not enough? Build a conveyor system directly under the Spanner Hurlers and they'll automatically restock from spanner packs rotating on the belt. You'll have to plan this out in advance, but figuring out the weird things in Hydroneer is the core gameplay loop.

There's a lot to like about this game but there's just alot of little things that annoy me that overall makes the experience not enjoyable:

- ATV turns over way too easily. It's supposed to be a fast vehicle but unless you're tapping the turn buttons on the keyboard, you're gonna roll over.

- Night cycle last way too long. The day feels 30% sun, 70% night. Yes, I get there are lights and a bed to deal with this, but why not just make it an option? How does a night cycle benefit a player at all besides being a cosmetic feature?

- Picking up stuff with one hand: This annoys me the most. Your character can pick up a huge, bulky machine but can't pick up more than one tomato?

- Starting a garden and trying to water plants is painful. A bucket and pan can only hold 1 instance of water, and said water can only hydrate 1 plant at a time? Why? I wish I would have just done a bunch of T pipes that drips onto plants but I already used my money to buy seeds and plant them in 4x4 pattern.

- I wish quests just had a job board instead of going around, hunting for speech bubbles from villagers, only to find that kind of quest isn't what I want (looking for Farm Tokens, not Guild Tokens).

- The Forge area is unnecessarily large. Yes, it looks cool from an atmosphere perspective, but it's so, so empty. While I appreciate the conveyor belts to transfer items down, I wish I didn't have to go all the way down and realize I needed a cart and then had to carry items 1 by 1 up to the Forge.

- Some prices don't make sense: Like 425 tokens for a wooden palette vs 85 metal pipes at 5ea?

- I really wish my character was taller or could adjust the height of holding the object in my hand. A bunch of items that I wish I could put in the back of my tractor is juuust low enough where I have to jump just to drop the item in the back. Why not have the game automatically account for this? This would be such a Quality of Life change.

- There's no end goal. It's purely a sandbox game. You make things to buy better version of things and once you do, that's it.

Mary Berry's Banoffee Pie:
Ingredients

For the base

150g/5½ oz digestive biscuits (about 10)
75g/2¾oz butter
For the toffee filling
75g/2¾oz butter
75g/2¾oz light muscovado sugar
1 x 397g/14oz full-fat condensed milk (see tip)
1 tsp vanilla extract
For the topping
300ml/10fl oz double cream
3 small just-ripe bananas, sliced
50g/1¾oz dark chocolate, melted or cocoa powder

Method

Line the base of a deep 20cm/8in spring form tin with baking paper.

To make the base, crush the biscuits to fine crumbs and melt the butter over a low heat. Pour into a bowl and mix to combine. Spoon into the base of the tin and press down with the back of a spoon until level. Place in the fridge for 15 minutes.

To make the filling, heat the butter and sugar in a small non-stick saucepan and stir over a low heat until combined. Add the condensed milk and bring to the boil, stirring for 2–3 minutes – do not over-boil or it will become grainy and fudge-like. Add the vanilla and pour into the tin. Place in the fridge for at least 1 hour.

Whip the cream in a bowl until soft peaks form.

Arrange the banana slices in neat rounds on top of the toffee. Spoon or pipe the cream on top and level. Set in the fridge for an hour.

Remove from the tin, and zig zag the melted chocolate over the top or dust with cocoa powder.

I wish there was a "meh" option to give. Currently the game is just lacking balance. The early game is quite nice, where the effort you need to put into mining generates enough revenue to slowly and carefully expand. However once you get your first few miners down at your second plot, the game is printing money at a rate faster than you could ever spend it. Work towards the T2 and T3 equipment feels pointless because you aren't struggling to purchase anything as it is. 

I will probably come back to this game in a year or two. I know they are still working on it, so we will see if I can change the review to positive at that point. It has a lot of potential, and the 25 ish hours I put into it were fun, but it needs work still.

Probably not for everyone, but for the right kinds of people I think this is the best kind of Game.

It really clicked for me when I was sorting through a massive pile of ore and realized the benefit of the intentional offset with which you hold things in the game.
When you pick things up, they move to the right side of the screen rather than the middle which you'd expect from most games.

But I picked up a pan, walked over to my pile, and started quickly picking through it grabbing gold chunks and dropping them into the pan one by one. 

And you know what? It felt great. 

Just the simple task operating as you'd expect with an almost lifelike fidelity. It's so simple but also so fun. I look forward to the simplest most rudimentary tasks accomplished through the world rather than menus and widgets. 

There are some allowances in very smart places, like ore dropped in a pan becomes 'Stuck" to it so if the pan is accidentally flung around, the ore doesn't go flying. Likewise objects dropped in the cart, in the truck or even dropped on a pallet and put into the truck, it all stays together and in some cases can clip through one another. 
This is a place where quality of life matters more than fidelity and it certainly helps.

But sometimes you end up with a huge, frustrating mess. But then you discover there are tools to help with the mess, with preventing it via automation, and a whole nother world opens up. Then you find farming, fishing, and the questing, additional plots, the little towns....

I look with pride at my muddy plot that I finally managed to arrange a shack the size of a spacious outhouse next to a smithing setup and a tool rack. Something so simple but more meaningful than any tier armor set or weapons in most games. My mud hut and hole in the ground are more meaningful than any boss slain and loot gained, because of the painstaking work that felt like it actually was something and meant something.

My only warning is don't let this game prevent you from getting things done in real life. It really scratches that itch of getting things done!

The game is pointlessly difficult in stupid ways.  It should not be as difficult as it is to put a rock in a bucket, empty a bucket into another bucket,, or drop a shovel. The game is rife with stupidly tedious and pointlessly difficult tasks.

This game contains no more content than what you see in the screenshots. 

If you like repetitive click intensive games with minimal reward, this is the game for you.
