First of all, if possible, I would have given a neutral review, instead of a positive. Further details about the reason below.

I really liked the first few hours of the game. You start with a small plot of land, rudimentary equipment and you have to endure through a fidgety process of getting your first few nuggets to sell them. Which is good because it gives you motivation to upgrade. Then you can eventually buy your first drill and bit later even automate the process when your income starts growing. At this point the game starts to focus on scaling and expanding your production. You hit milestones regularly which keep you entertained (carrot on a stick). 

Most of the game mechanics are poorly or not explained at all. On most items you can press a button in-game and it will open the wiki page (which is an awesome feature). Sadly most of the articles are still stubs and you can't get any further information than its in-game description. The game got a big update recently, maybe thats why the wiki is such a mess. I had to get most of my information from youtube videos.

I started the game when quests were already implemented. It was lucky timing, because without those, I would have stopped playing after a few hours already. Once your production is running automatically, you just stand there and wait for it to output the needed materials for the next milestone (another drill, or higher tier equipment). With quests, you have something to do, while your "factory" works for you.

Which brings me to the point I totally hated about the game: The item system. You have no inventory, you can only hold one item at a time in your hands (exception is containers which can hold a specific type of items). This makes shopping a tedious nightmare: Take your money stack from your truck, place it in the shop, take one item, place it the "selling platform", repeat this for every single item. When you're finished, push the pay button, and take EVERY SINGLE ITEM AGAIN, to put it in your truck. You have to run back and forth so much, it made me furious. I later found out that at most shops you can park your truck partially into the selling zone, so you can put the items directly on it, which prevented me from rage-quitting. I planned a new digsite and had to buy over 100 items, it took ages and was totally not fun. 
Same applies to tools when working: take the shovel, use it, run somewhere, throw the shovel somewhere on the ground, take another tool. Devs please, just give me simple inventory system, let it be a tool belt I can buy and a pouch which holds the different currencies. Its not a unique selling point feature, if it just decreases quality-of-life. When shopping, let me specify how many of that item I want to buy and let me get a stack or just automatically put them in my truck. When unloading the truck the whole process starts again.

Another feature, which makes absolutely no sense and takes a lot of time to get used to, is how items hold are dropped. They are not dropped at the place of your mouse cursor, but somewhere off in your up-right corner of the screen. It displays a faint shadow were your items will be dropped, which is very hard to see most of the time. You frequently drop stuff at the wrong location and you have to pick up every single resource one-by-one (especially placing items on an anvil or a table correctly is a challenge every time). Most of the cases you can use the magnet to fix this mess, but that is also fiddly and not fun.

The steam truck, my lovely steam truck. Its really fun to speed across the map with your Mk. II. Apart from the times, when its not. Every single nook will result in getting you stuck and you have to back up. The streets can be very narrow (or the truck is simply to big). On streets, you will frequently crash into the lamp posts. If you try to build streets or bridges for your truck with building parts, it can easily get stuck on its edges and only deleting those parts can unstuck it. This applies to all vehicles in the game.

Fishing is ok, i guess. It has no influence in game, there are no quests or similar fishing requirements to progress( with one infuriating exception). Early you can earn a bit coins on the side, to boost your income. it becomes inefficient pretty soon (even with the highest tier of fishing rod). [spoiler] I spent two hours fishing for that damn lobster, that you need to complete the last quest to reach the king. To no avail, they were all too small. I quit the game thanks to that damn quest [/spoiler]

Performance can be a problem. You collect 60 minutes worth of crystals in a cauldron, because you dont have auto-smelting yet? Say goodbye to your framerate. You put about 50+ items in the back of your truck while shopping. Goodbye framerate. Game freezes randomly for 1-2 seconds? Oh, autosave. You build a complicated pipe setup (because irrigation upgrade is expensive as hell) to water your crops? The 30 waterdrops hitting the ground will kill your framerate too and the sound effect is annoying as well

Also a new feature added just recently is crop farming. I had no fun at all doing that. The quests for farming (which has an own currency) give way too few coins for the effort and time you have to put in it. The higher tier crops take about 30-45 minutes to grow (or longer, i dont know. I minimized the game and returned after a few episodes on netflix). It literally feels like watching gras grow. Even the harvest machine could not save me from disappointment. It greatly increases your speed at sowing and harvesting, but it does not invalidate the fact, that you have to wait way to long for the crops to grow. The harvesting machine was bumbing around when driving over your crop field which resulting in spilling some of it out your machine. It has a useful output pipe, to put your crops from the machine onto a belt e.g. but somehow it kept "drifting" while doing it, so I had to reposition the machine every few seconds to not miss the belt. 

In summary: I was bored enough to play this game for almost 80 hours (which I spent half of the time idling around and wait for my production to finish). It was more a fight against the game mechanics than actually reaching any goals.At least I had no game breaking bugs, just annoying little problems. 

Still: I see potential for being a very fun game. My suggestions for this to become reality:
- a toolbelt for about 3-4 tools
- a pouch for currencies (with no need to take out the coins, buying automatically takes them from there)
- broaden streets, make truck smaller or let it ignore collision an some world objects, to not getting it stuck an every lamp post
- farming quests reward more coins or farming equipment (especially irrigation hook) gets cheaper
- drop items on cursor position
- items can be bought and moved in user-specified sized stacks
- collision-free storage for building parts (my dig sites quickly looked like scrapyards)
- improve quest system ( e.g. show position of quest giver, maybe make it possible to link a quest roll to an item, so I can see on mouseover who wants this item and where should I deliver it
- create a reason to build T3 except for it having better yield
- map should be available at all time without holding it
- replace RNG based lobster quest
- remove steam truck from start equipment. it takes the fun of thriving for it to improve your mobility.

After 100 hours and all achievements unlocked as of 16/05/2023.. this game.. has me feeling.. indifferent..

Pros,

Cute graphics which are easy on the eye.
Great voice acting which is very relatable being that I am from Frome in Somerset.
A physics engine which is luckily more fun than frustrating.
Easy to learn controls.
Sound design and options are extensive which allow removal of repetitive sound bytes.
Well done achievements which allow coverage of all branches of the content in the game.
Many fun little secrets to discover which can make the grind in this game have some laughs along the way.
A well designed learning curve which allows for several systems which can suit any player.
A positive vibe when it comes to trial and error which is refreshing.
On that note there is an underwritten feeling that you can fail and still learn or have fun.
Some great artistic buildings in the game with more being added frequently.
An extensive and fair amount of items to allow for individuality and creative designs.
A clear yet not forced path for progression.
A great modding community which can adapt the game and remove some frustrations.
An awesome developer who truly loves and cares about this game.

BUT the game is not without some downsides.

Cons,

No actual co-op, this is a massive tragedy and it is such a shame considering how well set up the game is for such a thing.
The dialogue can get repetitive.
There is no major money sink when you start getting into 6 and 7 figures.
Placement in the game can be a little jagged and frustrating sometimes.
Farming and fishing although fun in their own right, just cannot live up in comparison to mining, meaning it is one way or the highway.
I wish more mods were implemented into the game on a more permanent and non achievement removing basis.
There are still some underlying issues hanging around from early access which is understandable due to the limited dev team.
Buying a large amount of items is extremely frustrating and it is a shame you cannot buy things in sets of 5 or 10 or so on.


This is really difficult, I have one major friend that I play games with and recently he has been rather busy which is what made me pick this game up. We tried playing this in the weird Steam co-op mode but it was unplayable in reality, I think the audience for this game would be far higher if it was REAL co-op, I think this is the games biggest downside.

All of the other faults could be overlooked if you were giggling them away with a friend or three.

Even though I 100%'d this game I will keep it installed and come on back to it with major updates.

I just hope it progresses in the same direction that full release is bringing it in.

In short, if you want to play with friends then don't buy it just yet, if you want 100 hours of brain zenning then it is worth every single penny and more, even just to run everyone over and get them stuck in fun places.

Absolutely loving this game so far. Feels different from other factory games. There are a number of challenges besides just building an efficient factory, such as optimizing your trips to and from stores, optimizing transporting items (you can only hold 1 object in your hand at a time, but there are vehicles and containers that can hold many.), optimizing excavation of a new dig site, precision driving and aiming can help speed certain processes along (especially washing dirt at the beginning.)

Somethings to note:
Multiplayer is RemotePlay only! Remote play is where Steam streams your display to a friend and you virtually play Splitscreen. I didn't buy the game for multiplayer and haven't tried it, but just be aware of that situation.

I'm only at 20 hours of gameplay right now but it doesn't seem that the progression is very long yet. Hopefully the developer(s?) keep adding tiers (currently only 3) and more goals to reach. Even if they're ludicrous, games like this are always funner with some kind of goal to strive for.

This game is a bit of a mixed bag for me. There's a lot of pros and cons. Ultimately, I recommend this game with a dose of caution. It is kind of a slow grind in the beginning, or at least it was for me. If you don't have the patience for that, then this game isn't for you. I've played other crafting games that have a slow start (mostly of the survival variety) but this one feels particularly slow and grindy for a while. Admittedly, I got a little bored and frustrated with the progress a few times, made worse by the fact that you can only carry ONE thing at time, and your freaking currency is one of the things you must carry to and from places. And there's multiple currencies. That's my biggest gripe, honestly. But once I got passed all of that and got my first mining operation up and running, it was smooth sailing. The game got so much easier and enjoyable at that point because you can afford things that make your life easier and your operations more efficient. Even carrying multiple items at a time became easier. 

My absolute favorite aspect of the game is the logic cables and machines. There's a lot of really cool things you can do with them to automate your repair, smelting, and compressing processes that I had a fun time trying to figure out. Personally, I found that building a system that worked just the way I wanted it to was more rewarding than the money I was making off my mine. That's the game's biggest strength, in my opinion. Its biggest weakness--despite the fact that being able to hold only one thing at a freaking time was super annoying in the beginning--I would have to say is the game's builder. It's meh. It's not terribly flexible. Everything must snap to a grid at right angles to any of the axis and the way specific build pieces snap to this grid makes the placement of other pieces look a bit weird. Example: walls and wall decorations. If you snap your walls to the interior of the floor gridbox, your wall decorations like sconces will partially clip through, hiding the base of the sconce. This is also true of furniture like beds and tables placed up against the wall; the edges will clip into the wall. Snap the wall to the exterior and you now have a weird lip over your foundation (which can be hidden with other walls or floors or what have you) but also at the top where the roof connects to the wall. Dives. Me. Batty. It's frustrating.

ADHD side note: I found this game to be particularly jarring to my ADHD. First because it was boring and grindy which nearly made we lose interest entirely the day I bought it, and then because the logic system was so engaging and interesting that I hyperfixated on it for days. Just a heads up for fellow ADHDers. This game can be exhausting.

It's a fun game you can sink a few hours into, but far from complete.
Don't let the "Version 2.0!" fool you, the game is still very much early access, and pretty much everything that was 
"fixed" in 2.0 is either still broken, or broke something else.
Realistically, this game should still be categorized as early access.
Updates on the game are very slow, so it might take the game a few more years to get to a state where I could recommend it.

TL;DR
It can be a very satisfying game when it works, but it rarely does.
Buy on sale or in a few years when it's more complete.

EDIT: Looks like they're actually putting some content and effort in the game now, so I feel like my review above does not apply anymore.
I wouldn't call the game finished or bug free yet, but I can definitely recommend it more than before.

If you want to buy this game because you are into Mining and/or Automation. Don't. This game isn't about that. 
It's more like a Darksouls kind of game... you know... that kind of game that only people play that want to suffer. 

So i will give you the positive(+) things in this game, and the negative(-).

- The Building mechanic in this game is the worst in every single game i have ever seen. 
The controls mainly function with Mouse1 and E. if you press E in the wrong moment prepare to fix your machine for the next 20min because E picks things up without any animation or cooldown or anything. 

Especially awful since E is "use" in about every other game on the planet. Here, "use" is Mouse1. 


- For a physic simulating game, the physics are nothing more than a joke. 
Things flying all over the map when you look at them wrong happened more often then I cared to count. 


- Your only real "Goal" is Money. But Money is useless. After about 10hrs you will have about 100k easy and from there you no longer need any more money. After 17hrs, I am a multimillionaire and don't know what to-do with it. It would take me longer to spend the money then to earn it back. 

- If you need a specific item, good luck finding the right shop for it. Since some items are only sold at some places. This is extremely terrible in your early 5-8hrs of the game. 

- The Icehelm? Or what ever it is called, the place where you craft your Miners and some other things is a literal hell to navigate. You need to drive to it for 2min. Go inside, which takes about 3min, and then go back out for another 3min. The elevator does not even have a button and travels randomly up and down randomly. So be prepared to miss it and wait for another 20sec until it comes back down. 
That's at least 5-7min every single time you need to craft something. And you need to craft something more often than you like. Since that's the only place for the miners and grinders. 

- Optimization is something the devs properly never heard of. If you have a bucket or other container with too many items, your frames are now no longer existent. It drops from 100+ to 5fps whenever you hold the container. This counts for Vehicles too, not only your hands. 

- The sound design is made specifically to torment your ears. I ended up muting the game entirely after about 3hrs. 

- there is no Inventory. You can only hold 1 Item at a time. (why????????????)
Not even your Money is in the Interface... no. Money/coins is an Item that you need to take with you.
Just imagine this with any other game... like? Minecraft, for a lack of a better example.... Imagine you need to drop your Pickaxe to take a single piece of cobblestone with you every time you mine one. 

That's kind of what it feels like, anyway. 

- The Bugs. There are many. Like Cyberpunk2077 on release kind of many. 
Things just flying everywhere, things dropping straight into the ground never to be seen again. 
and don't dare to drive too fast over that rock if you don't want to end up on the moon. 

And so much more.....
Like there is no endgame, no goal, not even a reason to advance your machine... just make an easy automatic machine and go AFK until something breaks. (or just go into creative... why take a game serious when not even the devs do.) 

After I had my things' setup I played it more like an Idle game than a mining game, sit and wait, and every 10min repair everything. Repeat. And you don't even want to make a cool new machine or setup on a new plot because the building system is so trash. There is literally no enjoyment in this. Even though, the premise of the game is good. 

Oh... and have I mentioned that you don't drop things by looking where you want to drop them? Oh no, there is a small circle next to you.... that's where things drop. (Except the shovel, you need to jump to drop it 99% of the time)

This had to be made with the intent to be as unintuitive as possible. No sane person could think of a system like that. 

Well. Now to the good things. 

+ The Graphics and Models look kinda good most of the time. Not RDR2 level, but still better than most games of this kind. That doesn't explain the terrible performance though.


TL;DR Not even close to justify the price. Good Potential, bad execution.

Weird puzzle game. Find the method for rate of return. The game has no value at all if you have watched a play through (letsgameitout). Off the cuff? Extreme linear progression. Turn metal or fish into x amount of money. Exchange 2x money for auto miner and auto sifter. Regress -1.9 steps for repairs. Incrementally purchase slightly more automation for a slightly greater increase rate of return. Repeatedly rebuild the ever increasing mechanical abomination of dirt-directed and aqua-powered contraptions, that gets re-directed through a very specific set of goals. Eventually you perfect your squid like abomination and the game effectively ends. Except now some of the machines break, so hit all of those machines with an expensive wrench on occasion... Or it is impossible to finish because the wrenches are collectively more expensive than the breaks, which turns the game into an idle game as (completely on your own) you watch random youtube videos waiting for your machines to break like some kind of mobile android/apple game. Then the game kind of ends.

Give me something to spend my piles of cash on, even if it's just valheim-style decorative money piles for the love of god!

Okay, that outta the way, I feel like the direction this game went isn't really compatible with what it built itself on. Sure, probably way back when you'd still need to do most everything manually the process of (mostly) moving things one by one and making yourself a nice, square house next to your hole would have been deeply satisfying. But as it is currently, I believe the idea is to incentivize us as players to build, and all that jazz, but building is kinda tedious. There's a point while playing where I just switched from risking losing sleep over this game for how engaged I was to just hopping on to tinker for a bit before moving on with my day and that's not of my own free will. I just can't get as invested currently, because outside of finding the things in each dig site there's nothing to do, and I have enough money to just throw tnt at the problem until it goes away. Anything I would do would be for its own sake, but that's not what I want to play it for. I want to have a drive, to have the next thing. 

So yeah, economy REALLY needs a rebalancing because once you automate production it's kinda fucked. I'll still recommend this game, because the 50 hours of figuring it out and the work to get to where I am was fun, and I'm certain once the dev "discovers" (this choice of word will never not be funny to me in this context) a physics engine that allows proper co-op it will be a thoroughly enjoyable deal, Kudos on the multi-monitor splitscreen though. Good idea.

Awesome game with a cool community and committed, attentive developers. Updates come out regularly and the game has come a very long way in the few years I've owned it. If you find a bug, you can report it directly to the devs on discord and its normally fixed very quickly. 
Honestly I recommend getting the game now because I think it will end up being worth far more than the current £12 price with the trajectory of improvements being made.
And by supporting small indie studios like this (3 people I think?) you're actively improving the gaming space by giving indies the ability to produce top quality projects, which puts pressure on larger developers to focus on quality as well.
Game itself is fun as hell. its worth checking out the remote-play Co-op with a friend because it can be hilarious if you can look past the split-screen.

I'll leave my original review because this game was really janky to play at first, but after sticking with it for awhile you learn to work with it and the game has a lot of charm to keep things fun. It still is on the fence for me but it's leaned over to positive, they do seem to be making QoL changes still.

**Original Review**
This game is definitely a Meh, it rides on the fence but I lean towards negative because of their updates. I do appreciate that they are releasing new content, at a pretty decent rate. The problem is seeing them releasing new content makes me realize that the annoying things baked into the foundation of the game are there forever.

There is no inventory, you can't even put money in your pocket, you have to carry it around like every other item. There are ways to carry more things like carts and vehicles, but having to physically take your money from the cart and put it in the appropriate bin is annoying. It probably wouldn't be as annoying if money stacked well, but trying to get two different stacks to combine is an act of frustration in itself. Admittedly it is kind of charming at first, but it gets old extremely fast.

There's also a mass amount of jank that probably won't ever be addressed considering they're focused on bringing in new things. Throwing explosives is insanely random, my characters seem to throw it behind himself more often than not, destroying some of my production line. I'm constantly using the Unstuck command because trying to dig in any sort of reasonable pattern is impossible.

There are NPCs now but they are so soulless and bot like I would rather they had none like before. They changed the gameplay loop to now you have to do the sorriest quests from NPCs to get a different currency for higher tier equipment. On the plus side, hitting NPCs with a vehicle is the funnest part of this game, it's also the most rewarding, which probably isn't good.

Any reward I feel from increasing my gains is easily wiped out by realizing the next step is going to be so aggravating just to control everything through, it's not worth it. It's also worth mentioning how much trial and error is required because there is literally no in game explanation. There is a tutorial that gives you the basics, but you hit wall after wall of unexplained problems. It all reads as very amateur.

TLDR; The machinery in game all seems to function well and is rewarding, but the gameplay mechanics are so bad, it makes setting up any machinery a miserable experience.

Con: Clunky UI, and mouse aim doesn't work

Don't let the list below think I did not like the game.
All the other reviews focus on what you can do, but I focus on things that I found lacking:

[spoiler]
Cons:
- There does not seem to be a goal or reason to continue after you have tried out every device,( or I did not reach that stage yet?)
- Core game play seems to be repeating:setup automation for T1 to get T2 mats to get T3 mats.
- Building is... strange, you either snap, or you go certain distance away to place it where you want in 3D. This needs more fine adjustment options
- Bulk buy. you got to move every single item, think 20 blocks,200 pipes etc. 
- You get money real quick and there is nothing to spend it on besides devices/construction.
- I know this is mining game but more decorations/building pieces would be nice.
- Vehicle handling is wonky AF :D 
- The starter vehicle and T2 vehicle ( truck/tractor) trunk is too small, barely fits some of the construction pieces.
- T1 and T2 does not seem to have any differences besides the paint job, but then again it costs peanuts, after 1h you can buy almost every vehicle.
- Some performance issues when there is bunch of chunks in the bucket, or when you put too much items in the trunk cus you decided to build a house and don't want to drive 10x back and forth.
- The magnet tool is very rubbery, and you need to do 120 FOV to see anything it moves.
- There are no tool tips when you aim at stuff, only when you pick it up, which is bad because everything needs to be sourced and brought to your place of construction in cart/truck and if you have too much stuff there: good luck picking the part you want... oh took a wrong part, well just litter it around everywhere.
- When you pick up conveyor belt it picks up pipe too, which is weird and disrupts everything.
- Stuff can only overlap in the truck trunk/cart, so you end up using carts for storage of excess parts and you can only buy 1 roof at a time since those don't overlap on buy counter either( you can buy more if you jump or cheeze more on top each other)
- Left and right conveyor spliter is is swapped? goes right but says left...
- Then there is occasional crashes that lock the desktop and only way was to restart.
- Stairs are 1 block, but walls, doors, roof is 2 squares... so no aligning possible :(
- The sky is very strong in contrast to ground especially in sunset/sunrise, to the point you can not see ground without additional light source (because the dirt is just pitch black at that time). The sky also seems to be a dome, that said its the same in west and east during sunset/sunrise.
[/spoiler]

I REALLY LIKE THIS GAME! It can be fun and its great to lose yourself in.

However, optimization, control precision, and design choices seem pretty bad. And the lack of content. Unless your a masochist, beyond elden ring masochism, I wont recommend this game.

TLDR 
Pro, Its a fun game when working, has nice graphics and flavor. Has some interesting options. 
CON'S shoddy aiming even though your expected to be precise and even when you are precise it may all go horribly wrong, No inventory and can only carry one thing at a time. Impossible to optimize unless they change one of the mechanics of the game, and they won't. Lack of ACTUAL content. If your going to have a mining and crafting game, then you need more then 14 recipes with only 3 usable by you at any 1 time and more then 4 metals, gems, and power crystals to mine. Which you can get all of the resources with your pan shovel and scrub brush. Mining really has only 1 goal. Get a auto mine and smelting setup and then its done. 5 miners, 1 crusher, 5 smelters and some gem sorting. Water pipes, pressure increase and conveyor belts is all you need to get stupid rich and able to make anything. Which most of the time you don't need.
END TLDR

First, optimization. There is none. The game specializes in having tons of tiny chunks of resources laying about. And it can't handle it. They could have made it so that multiple chunks of the same type merge when placed together like the money does. This single action would fix the biggest cause of lag. I left a couple drills running for about 5 minutes. When I got back, the pan had a good amount of resources all ready to go. Until I picked up the pan and got a slide show of 1 frame per 5 seconds. Quality. Later game you can mostly deal with this by using sorters compressors and auto smelters. Can just conveyor belt it all around with no problems, but since the whole point is to start pan mining and to work your way up, that's not a possibility for quite a while. And you will be handling thousands of chunks well before you can stream line it. They did do something with chunks attached to surfaces like pans though. Well, until you pick up the pan. Speaking of the pan, you will mess up at some point and spray hundreds of chunks all over the ground making a huge mess. Which leads to my next point.

Number 2. Precision controls. There are none. Have you ever wondered what it would feel like to have a prosthetic arm thats fully extended at all times forward and to the right and the only way to release the items is from 4 feet up at that exact angle despite where your looking or whether you look up or down? Ever wonder what it would be like to try and place things  carefully with no actual aiming mechanic? Well, you will find out soon. Not to mention, all you get is a small shadow to show where it 'should' go. If your looking at your feet you might see it. Sometimes. Just not what you need precision for. Like pouring a pan of ore into a smelter because you can't see the shadow in the pot. Oh well, 300 gold nuggets spray all over the place as you slightly misjudge and it hits the rim and flies everywhere around you. No big deal. Pick each piece up and try to do the same thing again, with every single piece. 1 AT A TIME. WTF. I suppose there is a 'easier' way. There is a magnet on a stick. Of course, any sudden movements, moving forward, turning, jumping, all of that can cause disaster with your telekinetic floating blob of hate inducing disaster in the making.

Number 3 Design decisions. So the god awful aiming mechanics, the fact that no matter how big or small something is, you can only carry one at a time. Walking simulator whenever you go shopping. Sometimes you can ferry stuff around with a vehicles. Not always. This deep underground forge/store/mining location does not have room for vehicles. The shop is 5 floors... ish from the place you can mine. Even with virtually unlimited money it takes FOREVER to ferry everything from the shop to your work station. To automate 1 miner to a smelter (which would leave you a ton of resources just sitting somewhere, takes well over a hour of walking back and forth. And thats with me walking out the shop, throwing it all over a cliff edge towards my mine. And then jumping over the edge myself so i can start running them all to the next room with my mine and setting everything up. You will do so much pacing back and forth that you will become tired and turn the game off even though you have not physically done any of the walking. Your a blacksmith and miner... and farmer. You create up to 5 items that you can't use. Dagger, axe, sword, ring, and necklace. Those are for missions or money. For yourself, you can make 9 things. Only and they are really only 3 with 3 tiers. Miner, Crusher, and a water pressure increase item. Even though pipes and other items are made out of the different resources, you can't make them. And since you can have unlimited money quick with just the tier 1 items I don't even see the point. Even the late game stuff is just weird ways of doing old things. Often more complicated and less useful in my opinion. Then we have farming and cooking. I have not done much with farming and cooking. Realized it was more busy work and lost interest for now. Dig hole, Plant seed, drop pan in water cause you can't scoop it up. chase it down and go pour the WHOLE PAN OF WATER on 1 plant. Repeat for every plant you want to water. Woo. There may be better tools but they are locked behind special currency that you can only get from farming hundreds of tomatoes because everyone wants a small bowl of tomato soup. Small bowl = small reward. Which means not enough currency to buy stuff unless you grind. 

There is so many design decisions that blemish this game, yet, if they were removed, the game would become start to end maybe a hour if they fixed it. So they left it. Instead of content, the game was built around tedious poor control mechanics. I mean, every NPC says basically 2 lines. 'Ey up lad', and 'I need a bit of scram'. There is a few other phrases but thats the jist of it. There is no survival or fighting mechanics. So it lives on its mining and self made experiences and construction.

Oh... Construction. Every survival game or even other primarily crafting games get construction better. You can't pull items in or push them away when trying to place them. You can't push a button to snap to points, like pipes snapping to the end of other pipes. You cant even choose to raise or lower items. And everything is picked up with the same button. You pick up and drop items with E. Thats for resources dropped on the ground, or if you miss, the floor under them. Until you buy a construction hammer, a tiny misclick can cause massive problems. Remember, you cant raise, lower, recess, pull in or push out the placement of a item. You have to move. Carefully place a block, place other things around it, accidentally click it, and you may never get it back in place.


All that said, I enjoy the game when its not making me go bald. I like calm simple games sometimes. This has a beautiful world, graphics and some great animations and play options. And I know there is more for me to see and do. But, its impossible to look past the MANY flaws. I will continue to play. I have gotten better at the shoddy controls, but every time there is a unexpected resource explosion I like the game a little bit less. I don't recommend the game, because I don't want people to suffer such bad mechanics. Unless your a masochist. Honestly. I get more upset when resources go flying then I do in elden ring after my 20th death to the same boss.

Tried many times to find the game in this game. Nope.
REPEAT NUISANCE ENCUMBERMENT AND MESS GENERATOR.
No inventory or tool bar. Uhh?!!! YES! They left you an easily assumed naked one 
arm, one hand mongo who's only word is "Uhh?" and nickname is "lad" to work with.
He gets stuck on almost every object he interacts with. His AI is non existEnt but 
to make up for it he can pull tons load carts and lift pallets of items that would 
break an industrial forklift but can only carry/interact with one object at a time. 
Supernaturally strong but incredibly dumb. 

TOTAL FAIL.
While you can mine iron, smelt it and craft a very small amount of items, you cannot craft 
tools, pipes, machines etc which I find extra dumb on top of the already dumb options.

TOTAL FAIL.
It's just nuts how many different ways the devs of this game disregards how many other games there are 
that feature mining, machines, conveyor belts, vehicles. Hydroneer is the shameless mong of them all.
The game is utterly broken with the following current persistEnt facts. I literally have no idea 
how it made it past beta/early access stage. Just barge on with the ship the T-Shirts etc with 
the instant NOPE! buggy, messy junk. Terrible game, terrible devs. Total trollface or total fail 
I'm not sure which one, might be both. This game makes a hideous mess of it all on purpose.

EXTREME LAGGY/BROKEN/GLITCHY MINED OBJECTS. THESE ARE NOT RECOGNISED AS BUGS 
BUT PERSISTENTLY MAINTAINED THROUGH THE PATCHES, MANY. 

TOTAL FAIL.
Items (ores, gems, dirt) can merge or pass through each other but at times only randomly it seems.
Only sometimes they are trying to enforce the realism of no-clip collisions and surface interactions.
Items get stuck in sorters then following items start to pile up on stuck item.
Items get stuck on thin air at the end of conveyor belts instead of drop into sorter/pan etc.
Items you are forced to work with? Ores, dirt, gems, shards, tools, machines, conveyor belts, 
pipes, vehicles... they hate you. The devs of this game got carried away with the trollface of 
make the game make a huge mess with glitches bugs and disfunction and leave you to "try" and 
tidy it all up. Eventually with just T1 miners I made highly unstable mining array that paid 
about 75K every 10 minutes in gold/iron/gems. What is that... 10x the gold I need with just T1? I
had 12 t1 mining machines in 1 side of ember cradle. I used the handy but dumb t2 pump/boosters bug(?) 
to keep the entire t1 pipes rig at 175 pressure. 

TOTAL FAIL.
Items roll around a bit too much to say the least. They also turn on/off sticky item effect in often annoying 
times such as piles of ores get stuck on thin air thus blocking your crucible and half what you poured in.
How much code time is each item spending thinking about the ground, it's shape, momentum, pitch and gravity?
How often in terms of miliseconds is each item checking for collisions?
How often is a pan of ores updating it's current wieght and value check? On or off scales?
How come 2 x 150 ore pans in hand/on a vehicle dont lag but 1 x 300 ores in a pan lags to hell?
Are items losing the plot too quick to save CPU? Why are some items acting very differently than others 
or just jamming on air, a surface of a machine, on a conveyor stuck then others get stuck on that item.
Mindless lazy dodgers, incompetence, penny pinching or hideously troll faced devs, not sure which? 
Take your pick, might be all of them. The game does not work because it makes a hideous mess with the 
disfunctional glitchy, jamming, sticky, merge then not merge, gravity ect ignoring mined items.

TOTAL FAIL.
Take your dumb magnet on a stick and replace it with an uninstall click. Problem solved.
(It only adds to mess problems causing huge ore explosions and tags all items with 
hardly helpful "never merge" status.)
A pan with any large amount of ores in it will be nice compact tidy and the items in it will merge no problem.
It will lag to hell your FPS if the items in pan are over 170(in my instance) when you try to carry or move it. 
With 100s of ores in a pan it all sits tidy, flat, compact. Good! 
If you pick up an ore and drop it back in the pan it sits nice again.
However,... if something happens, like you go to pour the pan into a smelter but it already had ores in it 
and instead of you pouring the pan into the smelter it tips the smelter to make an ingot and then pours the 
100s ores from the pan everywhere. Or you go to pour a mixed ores pan into a manual sorter but had not noticed 
just moments before that 1 of your water purifiers had broken and the water was off, you pour the 100s in and 
... mess. Once you use a magnet on a stick to try pull ores they will no longer merge or sit flat with others 
and always repel collisions. They form a huge ball that's useless. They often drag in other stuff to 
the mess just trying to move said mess around in a compact mining operation with dumb magnet on a stick.

TOTAL FAIL.
No inventory. No backpack, nothing. You WHAT M8!?! This is bizarrely off the normal beaten approved industry/mining game track? 
Guess this dev studio just did not have the time or skill to code an inventory or utility/skillbar ect. 
It is worth mentioning that without toolbar or inventory you will be fiddling around and running about a 
HUGE amount with the expected using "the nearby ground" as your storage/work space. Items no-clip through objects and roll around or away too often with said barely ever flat ground.
I fell through the dirt layers in ember cradle a few times onto the bedrock below. No-Clip fail.

GOLD MEDAL FAIL.
The above annoying mechanics completely destroy the game's playability IMO. As part of the above mentioned no inventory thing? You can only carry/use one object at a time...(!!!) Currency is an object. Constantly picking up, moving and dropping items because only carry one item at a time, pick up and drop bucket 15 times because it keeps rolling over and other facepalm generating nuisances as you try to complete objective. Irritating gameplay involving chunky awkward world mechanics, tools and objects with glitchy surface interactions between objects and clumsy object interactions.
Creative mode is the exact same as normal mode only you don't have to pay for items from the shops.
The tutorial is unrealistic, over in minutes but shows the extreme simplicity of the game.
To make the entire game last more than 3 hours they throw a huge amount of hardly enjoyable mess and awkward mechanics in the way.

Hydroneer? IMO It's billions of light years behind Satisfactory/Factorio/Dyson Sphere/NMS/Planet Nomads/Craftopia/Minecraft 
ETC, ETC building and mining games. Played those games for many 1000s hours. This game is utter disfunctional junk. 
Enjoy this awkward, weirdly oblivious game if you get it. 
IMO this one is far too messy and unstable to actually provide the intended 
game play without masses of mess and nuisance in the way.

PS I'm a boss at all Industry behemoth games. This game is far too messy.

Do not buy this game if multiplayer/co-op is on your mind, I personally have been waiting for over two years for this game to come out with any way besides this side by side bullshit. I've even tried reach out to the developer about my problems and my messages have gone without responds for a while now. You come out with farming and quests but when will you actually listen to your community, not a bunch of Youtubers LMAO Sad company, Sad game, I wish it had gone differently.

Edit: The game has a decent story and is an alright single player game but it can't go without being said it can be a rather quiet and lonely game at times. One of my favorite core features in most survival/mining games is the multiplayer aspect where the team get to work together to accomplish amazing goals. Hydroneer has been lacking in the multiplayer since day one and i can't say i wasn't excited when you released "multiplayer". I've been a subscriber on your Youtube channel since like 2020 and have been following the games releases since but i have just been able to tell the lack of care for the current stage in the game. You would really rather add more stuff in the game to do opposed to just taking a few months and getting multiplayer running. I promise you that the day Hydroneer has actual multiplayer it will atleast get a 25% increase in player count if not more. I believed in the game at launch but ever since then my hope for the game has slowly diminished, I truly hope you don't take this to heart Max, as i do respect the game you have created i just think it deserves more love than you are giving it.

From a programming perspective, I am truly amazed at how the developers managed to create such advanced physics in this addictive and time-consuming automation game. Although there are some issues such as peculiar bugs, imbalanced gameplay, and lack of progression, the game is still quite enjoyable and user-friendly. The integration of the Steam workshop is a great feature, and the mods created by some talented developers are definitely worth trying out.

I strongly recommend this game due to the exceptional value it offers at its price point, surpassing the quality that is typically expected. Furthermore, the developers have been diligent in adding new features to the game. While there are some aspects where the game feels incomplete, it is best observed through gameplay rather than described. Fortunately, there are excellent creators who have made videos about the game that can help form your opinion.

Although the game could use some improvements, such as adding multiplayer instead of just remote play split-screen, as well as further customization and progression, it is still a fantastic game as it is.

It's pretty hard to recommend Hydroneer.  Once you get over the novelty of the interface you have kind of done and seen everything the game has to offer.  Yes, you *could* then proceed to build some large scale mining or farming operation or whatever but I don't see why you would.  That's kind of the issue here: there doesn't seem to be a reason to *do* anything.  I guess that isn't, in itself, a problem but check the store page: craft weapons?  It feels very deceptive.  It's true, but only in that its a list of "things that are in the game."  There are weapons and jewelry in the game, but there isn't say, equipment or combat.  Yes there is farming and cooking fixtures, but again, there isn't anything *else*.  Food, like weapons, is just a thing you can sell.  You might be tempted to think these features lead somewhere, but they do not.

It honestly plays a lot like a first gen VR game where the novelty of using your actual hands is supposed to make you ignore that the game isn't going anywhere.  I think this has some merits, contrary to complaints, as the unique control scheme is kind of what the game has going for it.  Remove that and you have any number of other games on Steam.  Even so, I had to double check Hydroneer wasn't actually in early access because it definitely *feels* unfinished.  For example, there's a little indicator that shows where something will drop but it's like... what everyone will want is to point where they'd like to put something down.  That this game has been out for two years and the best it can offer is an alternative precision mode that doesn't work ... well, I gave it seven hours but I would kind of like that time back.

I'm not sure who this game is for, but I can say for sure it wasn't for me.

Ways to improve the game

1: A inventory system.

DEAR GODS you can't even pocket your money?  That is unbelievable and immersion breaking somehow?  Okay so you dont want someone carrying an anvil around in the same slot that a much smaller item would go into on a toolbar, how do we deal with this?
.
..
...
TADA: In Game Backpacks and classifying each object already in game with a size and mass category.  The backpack would only be able to hold so much mass and within that mass, it also would have a size limit.  BUT WAIT, THERE'S MORE!  Different kinds of backpacks.  Farmers Pack which is meant to hold onto a TON of seeds, harvested crops and the like and possibly even upgradable via quests!  A Market Pack whose entire purpose is to bring raw materials or processed materials to the market.  Lots of Small space to fill up.  Then of course the Hauler Pack which would allow a person to carrying one additional Large item.

"But wait!" I hear someone cry out "Thats alot of material to go back and add an extra couple of tags to, the author is clearly working on upgrading the game as it is, get off their back!"  Its really not, but for those of you who don't understand how easy it is to mass add tags to groups of in-game objects, we could go with something else that would add some QoL.

A Purchase Mule at the front of each Plot.  This mule can be an actual donkey, a person or just a cart, but the entire point would be that it has a catelogue of all the things being sold in the game that you have access too, and for a small fee and a tiny bit of time-cooldown, this Mule could let you buy and then deliver objects to the plot you are working on.  This isn't game breaking and could easily be tweaked about, with its own Guild whose quests can be done to upgrade the speed and decrease the delivery cost.

AT THE VERY LEAST THOUGH
If nothing else gets added, if NOTHING else gets added.
PLEASE add a money pouch.  Having to run around with our arms stuck out infront of us holding our money infront of us like some kind  of subway goblin with a pile of Shiny Things they found.  The character wears clothing, it has pockets.  One can be sewn on if need be, its not that hard.  IRL I have crap sewing skills and I could easily make a shit-job-pouch to hold a few coins at least.

*Sigh* and no, stacking a bunch of shit up in a bucket so that it literally stacks and goes static doesn't count as a inventory system.  It counts as a unintended side-effect glitch.  You are not Bethesda,  This isn't a 'quality feature', its a bug.



Now, past the complaining.  The game itself is neat and does everything it sets out to do: Panning for gold, smelt stuff, sell it, use a lego-system to create structures.  Improvements and additional content are constantly being added so its likely this game could mutate far beyond what it currently is.  Perhaps they already have a inventory system in the works but are holding off until other things get updated instead of having to create a system then recreate it for a planned upgrade.  Even if nothing else gets added, its a decent adhd burner though the need to drag objects huge distances can really destroy the appeal for those who like zone into building structures and machines.

"But creative mode!" Do we really need to cheat for some basic QoL functions? Once you start with creative mode the entire purpose of the game for most would be over.  Thats not a suitable solution.

2. A combat mode?  Random creatures and monsters that will wander in from the Surrounding Wilds.  Could include water-machinery turrets that could fire anything loaded into it, from ore chunks to processed materials and even fully made weapons, belt fed of course with a possibility of the 'ammo' being recoverable.  The creatures would of course drop things upon defeat.  They could just be elementals so they drop ore when defeated and their main goal is to get to the biggest hole on the map, jump in and fill it with a self-destruct dirtbomb, which would let starting gear like the shovel be a semi-effective weapon, against dirt golems at least.  it would provide a reason to make weapons and armor, outside of selling it.

Buy it if you like water and simple but addictive automation games. Watomation.
I rate it 7/10 - too addictive and too simple, but it's a fun gold-digging waterpunk game.

In a nutshell:
What this game has  but other games don't – you physically transport currencies, resources and 3-dimensional machines with your flatbed truck from a shop to your quarry. THERE IS NO INVENTORY.
What other games have but this game doesn't: you actually build factories. Here you just build a sorting station and keep adding more drills, pipes and conveyors.

In a game like Satisfactory, expansion requires you to increase raw material production, expanding low-tier refining, mid-tier refining and even high-tier refining, as well as transportation (conveyor belts/pipes/trains/trucks etc) and energy production, and on top of that constructing buildings, but you build with a magical gun.
In this game, expansion requires you to (I'm serious) add miners and water pipes, and connect them to your sorting system with conveyor belts. Energy is free and only requires one pump.

That's the game past the point where you have a sorting system. You can also farm (and you have to in order to finish the quest line).

This is a fun mining game, and has a twist with the way it works, in the fact you have no inventory. This gives the game a very unique feel. So you end up working out how to move everything around using what's available rather than keeping everything in the magic pockets you have in other games.

It's not perfect, there's some difficulty in its placing of items, and the farming is very much a grind compared to the rest of the game. Mining becomes very easy very quickly and you end up with infinite money almost.

There are occasional bugs, but the game is in active development, and most get ironed out quickly.

Would recommend this game to anyone who wants a automation game, that's just that little bit different to everything else.

Extremely fun game with lots of potential however due to a massive number of bugs and performance issues I can not recommend this game to anyone, no matter how powerful your pc. There is a glitch that completely prevents you from unlocking items after placing them and using the build hammer which alone makes the game unplayable but also no matter how much you try to optimise your machines and systems resources WILL get stuck and will cause your game to get super laggy and often crash.

The game is fun to play dont get me wrong. there are just a few annoying bugs that can be frustrating. 

The chunks of ore can lag the game badly. If you have an automated mine they get stuck in the small sorters. then they block the rest from going in and you wind up with hundreds of rocks in a small pile. If you use the maget to dislodge them they literally explode away as each one fights for its own space to exist. Otherwise you have to delete all of them in the menu unless you want to pick them up individually.

The building framework is also cumbersome to deal with. You have to pick up each item (pipe, tool, wall, floor) and put them in the checkout area. After purchase you must pickup them up again and put them in the truck where they can overlap. Moving with 100's of pipes, building pieces, and machines gets laggy. You will need more than a thousand for an automated digsite with buildings. Why not have the parts transferred to the truck like in the dwarven smithy? It means you have to handle every pieces 3-4 times at minimum. I want a way to say "I want 50 of stright pipes in my truck" click, 25 elbows, click, 100 floor sections, click. Also make them bundled so the hundred object in the truck dont ALL have to render while driving.

I enjoy playing and building and get frustrated with the tediousness. 4 out of 5

I dunno, game is alright but I want to talk briefly about the dev responses to reviews. The copy paste messages about the multiplayer is seriously depressing to see. You're telling me you can't even come up with messages that have some degree of emotion in them? Just 'ctrl-c ctrl-v'?

That being said, the excuse for multiplayer is the physics, as if this game is revolutionary in the way the physics function. I'm sorry but saying the game made in Unreal Engine can't have proper co-op because physics is essentially just saying 'Too hard to work around sorry'. As someone else said, solo devs have done better in the same engine with less time for a cheaper price. It's not an engine limitation it's quite literally a skill issue.

TL;DR copy paste responses to criticism and poor excuses for inability to add multiplayer.

Before 2.0 I thought this was just a janky sandbox, great for funny videos but not something I want to mess with. The newest updates changed pretty much everything as I understand it.

I've had fun with it but it feels a little shallow for a 2.0 release. There is only 1 production chain so do yourself a favor and figure out as much as you can by yourself, only get help if you are stuck. Because that 1 production chain is pretty much the entire game.

I see little reason to make mines all over the map, there is no benefit to it. It's faster and easier to make money by making an easily expandable layout and just keep adding on to it. When you figure out how to do it you have beaten the game.

Sure you can play around making cute little houses or try to figure out the terrible logic parts only to create a monstrosity and realize there is almost no benefit to it besides repairing. In the grand scheme of the game everything is priced super cheap so once you have the (semi) automation setup and figure out the mining mechanics there is no more challenge and nothing to work toward. Tier 2 mining and any future tiers will not change that much as the end game is still the same, non-existent.

It's a fine sandbox, if you are into that you will love this game, for the price it's an absolute steal. If you want another Satisfactory keep looking.

I look forward to the planned updates and see promise for a deeper experience.

Farming Update:
The farming mechanic itself is an interesting addition but it feels out of place in a game that was previously just about mining. It can be fun but it's still pretty shallow. Some of the best parts you buy with tokens are useless because by the time you can afford them you want to be done with farming (sprinklers, harvesting vehicle). The NPC's do bring some life to the previously dead world but only a tiny bit. The soup making quests are not fun at all, pure grind.

Tier 3, Prospecting, and Achievements Update:
I started a new game for this to get the full experience. In the end prospecting is completely useless. Ore veins are not useful, just building more drilling machines is way more efficient. I was able to complete all achievements (except farming tokens because the quests are bugged) using only 6 tier 1 drills and 6 tier 2 drills. Letting them run while I did the farming stuff gave me way more than enough coins to buy anything I wanted. There was never a need to make a tier 3 mine.

The quests to get to the king are still just a grind of fetch quests and the reward is only useful if you are a sandbox player.

The updates make it sound like I hate the game but I don't. It's fun and quirky. It's still best for people who really like a sandbox though. Objective based gamers will find it lacking. In this game you do things because you want to, not because the game demands it of you.

This game has fun at the core, but is seriously abusive. There's gameplay friction everywhere. Need to set an item down? Watch it bounce out of position, or even disappear entirely. Trying to build? Run around and around trying to get the position right, because placement is janky and there's no auto snap.

Most of your time in this game is not playing the game, but trying to play the game. Still, if you're willing to put up with it, it can be fun.

Developers, please implement [i["normal"[i] multiplayer. Whatever it was not a split screen, but a normal multiplayer with a host and rooms. Because of this, many people cannot play normally with friends, you lose potential players and customers.
I played this game myself, I really liked it, but it seems to me that the level of development accelerates exponentially, the more devices you put, the faster you start farming millions. Perhaps it is worth making some kind of limiter on the number of miners in one territory. I give this game 10/10

Very  fun game with some unique(ish) game mechanics. You have no inventory so you can only carry 1 item at a time (you do have carts and trucks to help move stuff around). If you're going for the achievements then some of them can be a real pain, catching a lobster and getting 10,000 farm tokens are both a pain, especially since at the time of this review you will get many farm quests that will only reward you with 2-4 tokens, it's essentially broken.
If you don't care about achievements then I strongly recommended playing using mods, at a bare minimum the crate mod which allows you to buy multiple items at a time and easily transfer them around.
Fishing and farming were added (kind of) recently, you will need 2 lobsters if you want 100% achievements they are a pain to catch, very low drop chance.
Despite all these things the game is very fun and I highly recommend giving it a try.



This was a hard call for me but in the end I'm recommending it because for the cost it's not bad.

To me this feels like an early access game and as the developer is still adding content it's possible it will reach where I feel it is a released product.  The tutorial is okay but I'd prefer some pop up help on various things.  

The beginning game and mid game are almost different games and I almost wish they would find a faster way to get to midgame that didn't have you play another game.  You can pan for resources (tedious with okay rewards) or you can fish (less actions but also less money per item)  In the end you will spend an hour or two as a new player before you can start with midgame content.  This is not a new player friendly game.  

Once you have the game mostly figured out and understand how the majority of ths game works there is a very interesting design here.  This is not the massive factory systems you get in other games.  The 4 minable resources are just as avalible in the tedius early game as in the mid and late game.  You are not going to have to figure out complex mixing and processes to get to better content.  The various stages maily get you resources faster and with less manual processes.  

There is something interesting about not being able to interact with more than 1 thing at a time.  You don't materialize components out of thin air.  You have to go buy the parts, transport them where you want, and then install them one at a time.  This level of tedium is interesting and while it may not be for everyone I think a lot more people will like the automation building a lot more than the tedious panning for minerals or fishing.  

Once you get going you begin to see the limit of the current content.  I'd like to see a bit more to the game,m not just in resources or automation options but also in reasons to get the resources.  Once  you are making your components your only real thing to collect resoruces for is quests so you can get the tokens.  And while that does give you next tier stuff it doesn't really deepend the game play.  Id love to see a system to rebuild areas or install a delivery depot on your lands so you can have someone deliver stuff for you.  A new smelter at T3 or T4 that opened you up to alloys.  Farming and fishing are nice deversions but they don't really deepen the game  play for me.  

In the end for the minimal price this game asks for I really can't complain too much.  I do think the mid and late game mining automation are interesting and something new and fun.  Those two are why I recomend this.  It is my hope that either the developer will continue to deepen this game or consider making a Version 2 based on some of the core features of this one.  It's a good but not a great game.  But it has some really intriguing design choices that belong in a great game.

This is a nice simple game that gets complex if you let it.  If you enjoy digging and simply automation, this is for you.  If you like digging, and overly complex automation, this is for you.  I am still working on tier 2 content and haven't even touched the farming aspect, and I am still having so much fun.  This game is able to scratch those itches of creativity and logistics that very few games have been able to hit.

First, this game definitely has a few notable, breaking flaws.  Specifically multiplayer and lag will restrict how you play the game.

Secondly, it's just really interesting.  I love progressing through the dig sites and getting to the T3 ore.  I've been through the game 2 times solo and once with my son.   The quests are a good addition but still need some work.   As long as you don't mind literally running to the store and back quite often you will enjoy the campy, carve out your site feel to the game.

Hydroneer is a unique and immersive sandbox-style mining game that offers players a refreshing and engaging experience. The game's graphics are visually stunning, and its intuitive mechanics make it easy to pick up and play. 

Hydroneer features a vast open world that players can explore, mine resources, and build their own mining operations from scratch. With a range of tools and machines at your disposal, you can mine for gold, iron, and other valuable resources, then refine and sell them to make a profit. The game's attention to detail and good physics make it an excellent choice for anyone interested in growing a mining industry and satisfying gameplay loop. 

Overall, Hydroneer is an enjoyable and addictive game that is definitely worth checking out.

I've owned this game for a few years now and dabbled with it every now and then but never sat down to play for an extended amount of time, now that they added achievements i thought why not give it a good long thorough go, so i did. Roughly 50 hours later i got all achievements and can now give a good report about the game. 

I like it, always been a fan of the factory automation games and this is no exception. 
I must however add that there are still a couple of glaring issues with the game mainly the way new material is purchased which you do by dropping EVERY, SINGLE, ITEM one at a time into the buying zone and then load everything into your truck or cart, this is an incredibly tedious process an i have no idea why the devs have not implemented some sort of bulk buy option yet, i can only hope they will add such a feature to the game more sooner then later.

Secondly i had very big issues with the performance, after my mentioned 50 hour run i ran into massive frame rate issues around my main base which progressively got worse the more time passed to the point where i had to restart the game once every hour or run around at 20 frames, im running a 3080 with a 12 core CPU and 32 gigs of ram so it most definitely ain't me, once again i can only hope the devs take the time to sit down and give that game a good thorough optimization, once both of those issues are addressed i will have no complaints left! 

With that said i can recommend the game, it is a lot of fun and the asking price isnt too bad either, just be careful if you buy it for the sole purpose of coop as it only has a split screen coop mode that also does not run very well so dont buy it for that.

The game is very poorly optimised. If you put too many (~50) items into a bucket, or onto the back of your car, the FPS will drop to ~2. After 50h of gameplay and capturing just one of ~6 available dig sites, the game became unplayable.

[hr][/hr]

The first impression, with no tutorial in the regular game, was rather bad. And then I was told the tutorial is available from the main menu - as a separate scenario where you lose everything you do.

Then I had 20-30 hours of fun, doing things by hand, then building up, automating, and so on.

The lack of any kind of interface is an interesting approach - there is no inventory or any kind of information displayed on the screen, all items are objects that have to be carried around; checking the weight of an iron bar requires putting it on a scale; and so on.

And then came the end game which is again rather poor:
[list]
[*] Big purchases become problematic, as you still have to move items one by one
[*] Very poor logic circuits:
[list]
[*] Logic circuits are non intuitive and have no tutorial whatsoever - e.g. sending signal 0 and not sending a signal at all are two different things.
[*] Despite ~30 different logic blocks, very little can be actually automated (no automation for fishing, picking plants, taking bars/gems from the smelters/compressors, crafting items on the anvil).
[*] Even the simplest circuits take a huge amount of space (and blocks to move).
[*] No modulo operator - have fun building a circuit of ~20 blocks for something that should be possible with just one. 
[/list]
[*] Conveyor belt sorters sometimes glitch and let the wrong items through.
[*] You and your vehicles often get stuck - and using the “unstuck” option often moves you or your vehicle to another stuck position.
[*] Clean up option that removes all loose piles of dirt from the map actually removes them from the sorters as well.
[*] There are two pointers - one for aiming and one for dropping held items, but there are inconsistencies which one is used by the item held - e.g. emptying the bucket will use the dropping pointer, but pouring a soup into a bowl will use the aiming pointer.
[*] Scale has a display on the wrong side - you have to put the item on its left side, but the display is on the right side. Putting the item using the dropping pointer, which is on the right side, therefore you cannot immediately see the weight of the item you just dropped.
[/list]

[hr][/hr]

I really thought I'd enjoy this game but only after about 6 hours I feel like there is no point in continueing even though I haven't really even explored the map or most of the features.

The start was interesting, short amount of grind to purchasing my first things, meaningful improvements in my operation with almost every item bought. The gameplay also changes from all-manual to mostly automated gradually. Going around the map to find there are more items to find in a bigger town is also nice, I like it that there is motivation to pick where you want to build.

However, this is where the game ended for me. It looks like from here on all I need to do is wait, buy more drills, wait, dig 1 level lower, build the exact same setup with tier 2 and repeat. There are the relics to find, but it seems like a trivial side quest rather than actual content. There is farming and some new machines but ultimately I could basically leave the game running for a day on my tier 1 starter setup and end up with enough money to not make anything else relevant. I'm sure that people with more creativity than me will find arbitrary goals to set and get more out of the game, but for me it severely lacks depth.

Aside from the lack of content, the world feels dead with a few NPCs with very basic quests, nothing really moving aside from myself. The building feels rather clunky and aiming to drop things inside buckets and similar felt similarly annoying.. I understand each piece of dirt and rock has physics but it'd be nice to be able to throw them into a bucket 10cm away rather than just hold in your hand and let go wherever it falls.

I realise that the game never promised to have an objective being a sandbox, but for a sandbox it feels there is very little to do for the price. I got it on a discount, but I couldn't recommend it for more than £5 to be honest at the moment.

In the current state, if you mine too many ore nuggets into a bucket, then try to pick up that bucket, it will chunk out to about 1 frame per 2-3 seconds. Then when you try to dump that bucket out, the game just locks up.  The programmers need to do a lot of work on eliminating the performance issues. I run a 3090 on a 16 core system so it aint me.

Otherwise, it is a pretty neat game that has a ton of potential

Extremely janky, charming game. One of those games that has its own logic and limitations. 

Pros:
- Extremely open-ended play your way experience.
- Neat mechanics
- Wide variety of gameplay
- Very unique feel
- The jank.

Cons:
- The jank.
- The whole "carry 1 item at a time" thing. It's a neat concept, but turns every single goddamn thing into an exercise in patience, especially buying items from a shop that does not have vehicle access. Have fun running from buy pad to drop point 50 times.
- NO MULTIPLAYER. Come on, where's it at?! I've been following this game since launch, and it would be SO much better with up to 4 in some co-op.
- Illogical mechanics sometimes. Want to build your conveyor system this orientation? Sorry, the splitter conveyors only push one way even when spun about, so your entire contraption must be altered because of this.

Final Thoughts:
7/10 exercise in patience. When it works it works BEAUTIFULLY. When it doesn't, it's rage inducing and makes me regret having not refunded it. The lack of being able to do A N Y T H I N G fast is just atrocious. Structures go up slow, they get torn down slow, and when things don't work it's just a huge mess that is slow to clean up. And it's not even like the pieces can be gathered into a centralized location or into a storage container, nope, just giant piles of pipes, and pyramids of conveyors.

Amazing looking game.  The initial parts of the game can be a bit tedious, and outside of a short tutorial on mining and using the anvil, there is absolutely no hand-holding here.  The economy does kinda need a bit of a re-work, because once you get past the initial poverty phase and start a semi-automated mining and smelting system, money (hydrocoins) really become a non-issue.  The logic store in Bridgepour has a ton of items and minimal descriptions, so building full automation circuits is it's own puzzle game in a way. Day/Night cycle can DIAF...it feels like it's night-time more often than not. Sadly, using the "hourglass" from creative mode to stop time, will prevent achievements.

A grindy, simple game that becomes more and more about design and your creativity and flexibility as you play. I'm enjoying the building, and the way the game slowly opens up new options for you as you play. Feels similar in ways to idle incremental games such as evolve, or trimps, but in 3d and with interations.

Worth a buy on sale for sure. Has pretty good controller support, but picking up objects with a joystick (due to the precise control needed), is kind of a hassle.

Appreciate that the dev has continued support for some time. Game would definitely be better with some more polish, and definitely a more obvious tutorial in the primary new game. A fairly solid recommend.

My first thoughts about this game was terrible and here is why.

The tutorial is so blend it teaches you a little but does not explain how in depth this game really is, be great to have a feature that tells you more of what a item does with examples on what it does like a journal. But other then that the tutorial shows you basically what the game is about.

First game play and what i have noticed so far? Apart from knowing absolutely nothing about this game it was challenge as i didn't know what to do and how to do anything. so starting out is complicated i realised the deeper u dig in the first plot you own the better your outcome was do not dig close to the edges. once you get about 15k you go buy the first plot, then the troubles can start with either lag from overfilling the vehicle or carrying to much in hand. now this is early access and i am sure eventually this will improve so its not game breaking, the auto save feature is a tad annoying as it freezes for a minute at max to save.
anyways back to the whole first plot you buy its big but kind of annoying to level out it can take you 3-6 hours to do this so be prepared to take a long time doing so. then after that i found this really enjoyable and addictive because there is so much to do and explore specially the way you obtain your drills and all that by using the big anvil and buying the blue prints. Which mind you doesn't cost as much as it should in money to obtain the blueprints i think honestly they should be around the 2k mark each at t1. As for others 6k for t2.
but for the plot its excellent and plenty of ways to build and enjoy it with endless possibilities now performance wise not sure how its gonna handle big or medium size builds That's my only issue now is the performance needs improvement and a few things added which i will list below this should be built in game without the need of mods i am hunting achievements so cannot mod at all.

1. Shopping list so you can pre order your items before collecting them or make a list so when u hit that amount in your cart it puts a line through it. which u could possible buy this shopping list from the store or even have a board at the shop where you can add the items to it and once its complete it puts a line through that item.

2. There should be a way to stack more items in the shop or buying items in bulk because loading the vehicle after loading the shop is slow at times but i see why they do it but there should be a way to increase work flow.

3. T shape pipes are very needed as this would add more ways to build and the use of pipes.

4. More land to purchase or a whole new map that will only unlock when beating the original map so the goal of this would be a checklist of things such as owning all plots, completing a certain amount of quests, reaching 2m hydro coins, and 500k quest tokens etc. this would be a challange and worth the grind and i am sure alot would agree with me and for the new map you would start over but with a price hike and new equipment and new ores/bars/gems/fruit etc.

Anyways i have now come to the conclusion that i did not recommend this due to it not meeting my needs but i now do recommend this game as its gonna make a big impact on the mining/automation gaming industry, thank you max and your team for putting all the effort into this game and with the continued updates. hopefully max actually takes the time to read my review be appreciated.
