Seems like it's got a lot of promise as a game, but it's incredibly unpolished for a game which claims to be at version 2.0 rather than in early access. Many aspects of the game feel unfinished with mechanics like farming feeling like they were implemented in an evening after one of the developers thought it would be cool then never touched again.

In-game help is missing or incorrect, the wiki is even worse often only containing generic information about an item rather than actual wiki content. Often the only place to find out basic information about game mechanics is the Discord server, which to be fair is very friendly.

Physics is all but non-existent with items floating in mid air being a regular sight. The game has many bugs, not just small annoyances but items straight up being placed underground and lost forever, or items being completely stuck until the game is restarted.

You can only carry one thing at a time which becomes the biggest bottleneck in mid-game and there is no upgrade or convenient way to get around this. There is no inventory system.

Giving [i]Hydroneer[/i] a thumbs-down makes me somewhat sad, but unfortunately it leaves me no other choice. There's a lot of good stuff in there, starting with the attractive premise of a mining simulator sandbox. The graphics are serviceable, setting up an automated mining outfit feels quite satisfying, and there's significant potential for more advanced builds including logic gates for that extra bit of fine control over your operation.

Sadly, almost all of this is locked behind an incredibly tedious grind. This game not only disrespects your time, it actively hates you. Yes, you. And your family, and your dog. Especially your dog. Don't get me wrong, I know that construction and sandbox games tend to have a slow-paced start, and I'm completely fine with that, but [i]Hydroneer[/i] takes it to such a ridiculous extreme that I can no longer tolerate it. A game that's all about automating production shouldn't gate its automation features behind hours and hours of manual grinding. While this can be circumvented for the mining part by playing the fishing minigame (which isn't what I bought this game for), other features like farming have no such recourse. 

Let's stick with the farming example for a rundown on how this game does its best to waste your time in the most agonizing way it can. 
Farming equipment can't be purchased with the game's standard currency, because why should it? That would be way too convenient. No, you need special tokens, which can only be earned by completing farming-related quests, which in turn literally boils down to cooking bowls of soup for the NPCs wandering around the map. To make soup you need to plant and harvest crops, starting with tomatoes. Like all other pieces of equipment (yes, all of them; no exceptions), seeds can only be purchased individually. The packets stack to a limited degree, but you still need to pick up a seed packet, drop it in the purchase area, walk back to the counter, pick up another, drop it on the first, rinse and repeat. Sounds tedious? Oh, you sweet summer child, do I have more bad news for you. 
Now you have your seeds and your starting equipment, the only farming gear you can purchase with standard money. You haul it back to your claim, plant the seeds (individually of course) and water them... individually. You literally have to take your mining pan, fill it with water, pour it on one single aspiring tomato plant, refill the pan and repeat with the next plant. Sucks? You bet it does... and that's just the first round. You need to repeat the whole thing about once a minute until the plant is fully grown. For every. Single. Plant.
Okay. After what feels like an eternity of manual torture, you finally have a bunch of tomatoes. You cook the soup, take it to the quest giver and receive something in the ballpark of 40 tokens. That's just enough to purchase a watering can, which allows you to water an incredible FOUR plants per refill. Certainly a step up from the mining pan, but still mind-numbingly tedious. You want to automate this crap. That's what you bought this game for, after all. You vaguely remember seeing a sprinkler attachment for your water pipes back at the farming shop. You check the price tag and feel your hopes evaporate before your eyes because the damn thing costs a whopping 2,100 tokens. That's about 50 quests' worth of work just to automate the watering of a single small area of your fields, and it does nothing to help you with the harvest, the next seeding, the preparation of the harvest for cooking, the cooking itself, or any other part of the farming system. Isn't this great game design?

I freely admit that farming is the most extreme example of how [i]Hydroneer[/i] actively fights your attempt to have fun, but the rest isn't far behind. And if the game isn't wasting your time for a change, it's making your life difficult in other ways for absolutely no good reason. 
For instance, equipment comes in several tiers of increasing quality, but tools of the same type aren't readily interchangeable. A T1 drill has its power input on its backside near the ground. The T2 drill has it on its left side near the top. So instead of simply removing the old drill and plonking down a better one in its place, you have to tear apart your entire automated production line to accommodate this random BS. Oh, and it also makes it impossible to place T2 drills side by side, making them less efficient overall despite being higher on the tech tree. Again, just one example of many.

I could go on for at least another dozen paragraphs about all the nonsensical stuff in [i]Hydroneer[/i], the incomprehensible design decisions, and the near-psychotic level of contempt the devs seem to have for their customers' time, but I think I've made my point clear by now, so let's wrap it up. [i]Hydroneer[/i] has a lot going for it. It has many neat ideas and a solid core so that sometimes, when all the stars align and you squint real hard, you can just sense an echo of the fun you might actually have with this game. And then the next BS roars around the corner and slams you back down to the reality of how much potential was wasted in its development.

Hydroneer is set in a colorful and vibrant world, where players take on the role of a miner who must dig, explore, and trade in order to grow their business.

One of the things that makes Hydroneer so enjoyable is crafting  mechanics. 
This attention to detail really helps to immerse the player in the game world, making it feel like they are actually mining for resources.
Hydroneer is the sense of progression it offers. Players start out with very little equipment and must work their way up to more advanced tools and machinery. This gradual progression feels incredibly satisfying, as players see their mining operation grow and become more efficient over time.

In addition to mining and building, Hydroneer also offers a trading system where players can buy and sell resources with other characters in the game world. This adds an extra layer of strategy to the gameplay, as players must decide which resources to prioritize and how to best use them to grow their business.

Overall, Hydroneer is a fantastic game that offers a unique and engaging gameplay experience. Its attention to detail, sense of progression, and trading system all make for an incredibly immersive and satisfying experience. If you're a fan of simulation games or just looking for something new and different, then Hydroneer is definitely worth checking out

Really fun mining and automation game, the controls take a little bit of getting used to, and although there's a pretty decent tutorial about the  basics of the game loop it doesn't handhold at all and there's a lot of things you need to figure out for yourself. The early parts of the game where you have to do everything by hand are kind of tedious, but you get access to some automation pretty quickly and from there things start snowballing rapidly. Some things like the building controls and exact placement of dropping items don't make any sense at first, but once you get over that initial hurdle and understand what's happening everything suddenly clicks into place. Definitely some things which need a bit more polish and QOL improvements like buying multiple items at shops, and if you don't like just being thrown into the game world and left to figure stuff out by yourself it may not be for you.

Only played 15 minutes but the controls were bad enough to make me stop there.  

You can only hold one item at a time, a tiny nugget of ore or a giant furnace are effectively the same in that regard.  The shops really maximize on this limitation as your money has to be dropped in a bucket then each item you want to buy manually picked up and dropped on the sales platform one at a time.  It may sound like a small issue to complain about but it is incredibly frustrating and adds nothing to the challenge.  It's just a time waster.

You have a circle in the center of the screen to show what you are interacting with however dropping items has another circle to the right of the center which leads to very frustrating moments as intuitively you would think the solid blue circle in the center is what you should focus on rather then the thin outline of a circle off center.  Whats more odd is some objects you hold interact with other objects using left click and the center circle while other have to be dropped onto objects using E and the off center circle.  I'm sure with enough time you get used to it but it adds useless frustrations.

After 4X and Turn Based Strategy games I am a sucker for Base Building type games.  I have seen Hydoneer for a while now but for some reason never added it to my list of similar games.  It wasn't due to the price, which is even at full price is a great deal.  I guess every time I saw it I had other things on my mind.  Well thanks to the most recent deal the game was just under $10.50 USD so I had to finally try it out when I say it on the front page.

So far I only have one session in the game, at just under 3 hours played but I wanted to give my initial thoughts.  First off I installed on my i5-7400, 16 GB RAM, SSD, 1060 GTX which is what I played with at this point, and also my Steam Deck which I will come back and re-review after some time with it played and compare controller vs. KBM play as well at that time.

Cons First:
While I did not have any crashes to desktop, I feel that I need to note that I had at least three minor freezes for upwards of 25-30 seconds that I almost went to task manager to end task.  Each of these times was during an auto-save.  I am not sure why this was as I have the auto-save set for ever 5 minutes and I only had it happen 3 times and nothing major was going on during those three times of note.    

However during general game play I had no lag or other issues.  I am going to have to do a little more research to see if I can replicate and see what the issue is.  I am up to date on my SSD and Nvidiia Drivers so I should be okay there and I haven't had problems with more intensive graphics games.  But like I said, this did not lead to crashed to desktop and resolved after less than 30 seconds.

The only other slightly bothersome issue I have is with the game play it's.  While there is a visual center dot for things like clicking on items to pick them up, press buttons and so forth, this dot / interact button is separate from the button to drop items (I am sorry I forget the actually name of said indicator at the moment).  It defaults to black, which I highly recommend you  seek out under settings and game play and change to white, or a brighter color, I went with the magenta color myself because when you are dropping it's into pans, on the anvil, the cart, a table and so on, this indicator is where the item will fall to.  

If you are like me your brain is pretty trained to expect your focal dot to be where an item will fall, but since it isn't this may throw you for a loop, even more so at night when you will have a hard time seeing the drop point.   However once you change to a brighter color it becomes a lot easier to deal with.  Maybe no one else has fought against this issue, I haven't looked at other reviews or the forums, but I would imagine it is a common problem that people new to the game run into.

Okay, so that's the Cons that I have at this point.  Not bad, both are more annoying than major and the secondary one I mentioned is fairly easy to work around with the color change.  So now let's look at the pros.

Pros:
 1) The game is done in a nice cartoonist art form.  Sorry but for decades I played Warcraft and then World of Warcraft and I like my dwarves to be cartoonish, and they are spot on here.  Technically I don't even know if they are Dwarfs of just strange looking people.  I am going to think of them as Dwarfs since it's a mining game.  I love the art work, it has some great detail, some cell shade landscape looks, and as started cartoon looks.  All in all a very enjoyable look for me verses many of the survival / crafting games I have that go for a very realistic look.  I appreciate it myself.

2) While I am still using tier one gear, I like to gaming flow.  It feels good.  Even before I really even think about automating anything I am already doing so myself with multiple buckets, pails, furnaces and so on.   Coming up with a new way to speed up my processing even with the basic tier one items has been fun.  My next session I should be about ready to move to truly mining down and becoming a Hydroneer but even before that part as it is I could easily spend a couple more hours just maximizing how to increase my output with the bottom line equipment.

3) Other than the few lockups I mentioned during autosaves, I had no other bugs or issues with FPS or studdering.  I experienced zero clipping issues.   All in all the game feels pretty solid.  I would highly recommend it to my friends.  I do not feel my money was wasted in the least purchasing the game.

As of my experiences so far with just under 3 hours I would rate the game a 9/10.   I would have rated it higher but I am not a fan of how there is a second marker for where items are going to drop, maybe if there were different difficulty levels, but to me the only parts that frustrated me were and still are to a small degree that issue..

I have to applaud the dev(s) for making such bold decisions when making the foundation for controls/UI in this game. Inventories in other games can feel too small or unorganized, sometimes lacking the ability to quick deposit or "grab all"; rather than go through any of that nonsense, this dev team decided not to build an inventory at all. So, you have to pick up items one at a time and place them with yet another bold approach no one asked for: an off-center drop cursor. If that wasn't spicy enough for you they throw another curve ball at you with the currency system: drop money piles on top of each-other (with the aforementioned trash drop cursor) to combine them or smack them with a tool to break them. When you go to buy an item you have to drop your money into a bucket, purchase and re-locate the item then go back for your money later. If you thought they were done with radical ideas there, think again. They took it another step further by using Steam's Remote play for multiplayer, read through other people's reviews for comments on how fun and exciting that is. Considering this game was released during lock-down when everyone was stuck inside, why would you not release a full multiplayer? 

If you're interested in wasting your time, this game is for you.

I really want to recommend this game but I can't.  The concept is right up my alley but the beginning process is way to clumsy.  This is based mainly on the drop mechanics for processing dirt and crafting.  There has to be a better way to input crafting materials than trying to match up a little dot to the surface of the item you are trying to use.  Most of the time you can't even see the dot unless you are standing directly on top of it (i.e. the Anvil).  I just can't get into the game because of this.  Also the tutorial is not bad, but needs more detail.  Things like explaining that you have to line up the dot when placing items in a furnace for example.  The placement is mentioned when you pick up an item in the beginning of the tutorial but it is not explained how it should be used.

These things are not game breaking but the enjoyment level is greatly diminished. I will check back and see how things are progressing.

Hydroneer is a game that oozes charm initially, with a neat pitch of it being this big, expansive mining simulator that lets you create mighty forges and simplistic machines to simplify the digging process, while driving along in a big vehicle and playing with a friend. Sadly, the trailers and the actual game play simply don't match up at all. It drops you in with effectively no tutorial. Curiously, you'll find a button to launch a direct link to the wiki, which I immediately don't see as a good sign--I shouldn't have to leave the game to understand how it works. Pushing that aside though, I read the abysmally small quick-start guide, and got to work. It took awhile for me to notice there were tools provided at the start, so after hunting those down, I began the process of shoveling dirt into a pan, filling that pan with water, brushing the dirt, and getting little chunks of whatever in it. From there, it was sprinting uphill to sell it, to then...have to carry the money physically back, and rinse and repeat (quite literally). Again, there's no in game tutorial--and the quick start guide only covers up till blacksmithing. There's drills on sale, but the in-game description and the constantly yammering NPC next to it says that it's damaged by unfiltered water. Seeing as I don't see any sort of filter available at any of the nearby stores, I refrain from buying it--due to seeing the cost of repair tools being pretty steep. After fiddling with smithing, dumping an obscene amount of ore into making a bar, only for the resulting dagger to only be worth 20 coins, I simply put the game down. It's frustrating in so many little ways, whether it be needing to drop money on top of other stacks to combine it (Why? What does this provide?) to your character making obnoxious grunting noises any time they can't interact with something for one reason or another, to just the complete lack of any kind of explanation as to how to get started beyond the barebones boring basics, I found myself feeling scammed out of my $10. Honestly, this game is nearly 3 years old now--how is it still in a state where the wiki has an in-game button dedicated to opening it, but the wiki isn't even fully filled in? In the 2 hours I played, I'd rate it at most, a 3/10. It's very far from the worst game I've ever played, but for all the charm this game has, it is a mechanically annoying mess.

Hydro Porter and the Planned Obsolescence
The game used to be a lot more entertaining but every update adds content while also making that content worse.

In the old days, the goal seemed simple - build a huge row of drills, get an obscene amount of materials, sell those for money.
Only because the dirt under the drill never diminishes and it's pretty easy to run them forever while AFK, money gets worthless real fast and there's nothing more to see.

Minerals now rely on more depth. OK, so move the drills a little lower but no big change there. There are even drills that give better materials that require that depth - it's a little more progression but ultimately just about colour that works the exact same way

OK, so farming comes out. People all over the map demand soup. You need to grow veggies, get the weight right for the ingredients, then run the soup out to them for a new variety of money. Only, cut veggies stack and you can only halve them. You now need to spend a while splitting and combining to try and get the quantities right. Add into this the fact the rewards barely cover the cost of the seeds and since seeds give 1-3 items and each turns back into 1 seed you feel slowed down. Now finally, add onto this finding the NPC on a map you have to stop, pick up, and check, and the distance you're running items out. The distance that would be much easier on the fast vehicle, but that barely fits anything on it.
That's all pretty tedious but the only thing the farming money rewards give is more farming goods (colours of the same mechanic) and a set of (cosmetic) greenhouse parts.

So now prospecting is a thing. Another type of money. It's the same as farming for getting quests > weighing > making > delivery but even worse because your big strip mine doesn't give nice tidy weights to make items to specification. No, you need to halve a huge 60,000 ingot over and over and over to get maybe 50 weight for maybe 80 special mining money.
Automation is going to take doing that several times since a tool to cut to weight needs the currency you're being paid for this time-sink. Oh, and you still need to collect the quests and run the products back out.

Overall, it's just becoming grindier, slower, and less intuitive. The balance in the old version was not good but instead of fixing it, the dev has just made things more punishing instead of more rewarding. You're still working towards the exact same goal of making your life automated and giving up, you're just now doing it with weights around your ankles.
The only thing the new update has added is a fix to a problem it introduces, and a new colour of goods that works in the exact same way.

Awesome concept. 

Shame that the system is build upon this "place thing below character at this tiny dot" mechanci that is cumbersome as shit.

The tutorial would suffice IF AND ONLY IF the game wasn't really janky & mechanics weren't semi-counterintuitive.
The clunky-ness of it all is the main reason I cannot imagine people getting into this other than those who are deadset on making it work.

I tried, I really did. The concept of it all is neat and I love factory style games a shit ton so one that also has to do with an older setting & "hydroneering" was awesome to me.

That being said, placing items is a chore. Carrying gold as a singular item into a BUCKET to buy things is so odd. 
Like I get it, some things are not convenient for a reason, but seriously? I can't carry a hammer and have a coin pouch I need to lug these gold coins as my only carryable item?


It seems like the developers had a great idea and many great executions but either laziness or lack of desire to make the game accessible truly turn this into a game that requires more effort and time to enjoy.
I guess that's to be expected of the genre but typically the intro learning phase is FUN. 
Factorio I loved learning the mechanics and seeing if I could do something more efficiently. Here, it's frustrating. 

To the reviews that say it's on the players that they don't understand the items are dropped as a circle on the ground and it's an indicator I ask you this:
why?

Why have this be a core mechanic when it clearly doesn't function intuitively the way players would expect or desire it to?
Rather than excusing a negative aspect of the game as "players don't get it" maybe we should ask if so many players don't get it, why is it a core function of the game?
ITS A GOOD GAME

I enjoy the concept, but the mechanics of the game can be infuriating.
Things I would like to see:
1. A deconstruct key separate from the pick up key. I cannot tell you how many times I have picked up some construction that I have not been able to put down again because it is obstructed by the ore/mineral I was actually trying to pick up.
2. The ability to use two hands for some object. It would be great if I could carry the fishing bucket and the rod.
3. Chutes or attachable buckets/pans. It is a genuine pain trying to pick up all of the little pieces that don't land perfectly in the buckets or pans. About 90% of my key inputs are dedicated to picking up the tiny pieces. This further contributes to the annoyances of deconstructing on accident.
Looking forward to seeing if these quality of life things get added.

This game is janky as hell and I love it for that very reason.
Reasons I love this game:
- The gameplay loop feels different from other games were you mine resources and craft things out of them. It's mellow, there aren't really goals set for you and as of 2.1 the tutorial consists of mostly self direction and self education, otherwise a *lot* of trial and error. To my understanding, there is a playable tutorial coming in 2.2 which is supposed to launch today. I'm writing this review while I wait for it to drop.
- I like when numbers go up, and this game makes every tier or progression, every new tool or piece of machinery feel special. I enjoy when I have enough ore in a single pan that my framerate drops to zero. Sure, there can be some frustration with it but ultimately it's a game and it's not like you're punished really for the bugs and quirks. You just... keep playing more of the game.
- The game has a lot of different things to do, but nothing forces you or even nudges you in that direction (except for that NPC you end up walking by all the time who could really do with some scran). It's a lot of self-directed exploration


If you're looking for the following, you won't find them here:
-This is not a survival game. There is not hunger or thirst, you don't have to sleep
-This is not an RPG. You don't have skills or levels, the progression is more baked into the materials you find and use.
-The gameplay loop is fun, but it is not efficient. If you're looking for a really clean experience free of bugs or quirks of the physics engine, look somewhere else.

I tried to like this game, I really did. It has a tremendous amount of potential with how well the modding community has been integrated with it. The mechanics that underlie your experience in this game are incredibly complex and allow for the creation of some truly beautiful mining setups.

However, where it falls short big time is the user experience. It is as if the developers purposefully made this game a torture to actually play. The UI is ugly, unintuitive and sluggish. Picking up and dropping things feels absolutely horrible. There are quite a few bugs too.

For me, this game went from something that I like to play, to something that I only like watching others play, because it saves me the struggle of actually playing it myself.

If you're looking for a fun and relaxing game that combines resource management, exploration, and creativity, Hydroneer is an absolute gem. This game has everything you could want from a simulation game, and it delivers it all with stunning graphics, smooth gameplay, and an addictive soundtrack.

From the moment you start playing Hydroneer, you'll be immersed in a world filled with possibilities. The game puts you in the role of a gold miner, tasked with exploring the world around you to find valuable resources and build up your mining operation. You'll need to manage your resources carefully, balancing your budget with your desire to expand your business.

One of the best things about Hydroneer is how much freedom you have to explore and create. You can build your own mining operation from scratch, designing everything from the layout of your mine to the equipment you use to extract gold from the ground. The game encourages experimentation and creativity, so you'll never run out of new things to try.

But what really sets Hydroneer apart is its attention to detail. The game's physics engine is incredibly realistic, making mining feel like a genuine physical task. Every tool and piece of machinery has its own unique properties, and learning how to use them effectively is both satisfying and challenging.

Overall, I would highly recommend Hydroneer to anyone who loves simulation games. With its gorgeous graphics, immersive gameplay, and endless possibilities for exploration and creation, this game is a true standout in the genre. Whether you're a seasoned miner or a newcomer to the world of resource management, you're sure to find something to love in Hydroneer.
VERY GOOD GAME LOVE IT

Hydroneer is an indie simulation game is set in a fantasy world where players assume the role of a miner who must extract valuable resources, such as gold and silver, from the ground. The game play of Hydroneer is a mix of resource management and puzzle-solving mechanics. Players must build and operate a variety of machines to extract resources from the ground and process them into valuable materials. The game also features a variety of puzzle elements, such as finding hidden treasure and solving riddles to progress. One of the standout features of Hydroneer is its charming and colorful art style, which creates a whimsical and relaxing atmosphere. The game's mechanics are also straightforward and easy to understand, making it accessible to players of all skill levels. Additionally, Hydroneer offers a variety of customization options, allowing players to personalize their mining operations and machines. The game also features a multiplayer mode, allowing players to collaborate with friends and compete against each other. However, Hydroneer can become repetitive and grind, with players performing the same tasks over and over to extract resources. The game can also be short, with the main campaign only lasting a few hours. In conclusion, Hydroneer is a charming and accessible simulation game that offers a relaxing and enjoyable experience. Its charming art style and straightforward mechanics make it accessible to players of all skill levels, while its multiplayer mode and customization options add depth and replay ability. While it can become repetitive and may be short for some players, those looking for a casual and enjoyable mining simulator will find a satisfying experience in Hydroneer.

I really wanted to love this game, but I just can't. The controls are so clunky and the whole concept with that drop target makes it fumbly and just drives me nuts. I gave up after a few minutes of frustration. Hell no. Why do this guy had to reinvent the wheel with that drop target that most of the time seems to stick under my feet?

I'm sure many avid lovers of this game will call me a dope or lazy, but so many of the automation aspects of this game just don't make sense. After a few hours in, disregarding the clunky controls, it feels like getting into automation of mining just doesn't make sense with no guidance at all. I understand the logic that that conveyor belts need water to be powered, I understand that drills need to be on ground, but trying to piece together these parts with the tools provided just seems frustrating. I had to go back and fish with a pole and traps, just to buy many new pipes or a few more conveyors to make something work and I just gave up. It seemed like I couldn't place conveyors if there wasn't fitting ground or because uncapped pipes fed into them, I honestly don't know.

The game feels like a puzzle to which you don't have the clues or tools to learn how to proceed. I'm not talking about a full on tutorial, but I'm just a guy who doesn't have 40 hours to figure out the exact right placement needed to make a simple conveyor belt up into a grinder.

hard pass if you don't have the time. Lovely game though and if you want a Riven like experience in your crafting games or want to watch hours of youtube videos to explain something that isn't a well put together system. There's just much better games out there.

its really good

Hydroneer is the best terrible game I've ever played. On paper, it sounds great. A mining game that makes Factorio-style promises of automation and engineering, machine maintenance, piping, all the good stuff you wanna see in an industrial sim.

Then you get in and find out you have 1 hand. No toolbelt, ever. No way to place anything besides throwing it on the ground at full force like those old milk challenges. You are told to dig... with a shovel that makes a tiny indent and a bucket... Not quite as glamorous as Factorio or Satisfactory where you are bringing stuff from space with you. Oh and there's only 2 individual machines for sale at the start. You can't even craft. 

If you stick with it, though, the janky charm ramps up very quickly. So far, my favorite part is how drastic the production techniques have evolved as I played. I went from shoveling dirt into a bucket then hand washing it, to a hand-wash production line with like 6 buckets, to having 1 machine that I dump my buckets into, then 2 machines, and I pick up the dirt myself and put it in, and now I just bought a huge load of (EXPENSIVE) conveyer belts. Whereas Factorio is about progressing into more and more complex but fundamentally similar recipe flows, this one seems to be about scaling up into entirely new production processes.  Hydroneer is pretty small scale overall, and most of the game seems to be about trying to process more and more (and then more and more valuable) dirt. 

It's kind of like a job... and the game got MORE fun when I thought of it that way. That's not going to be a game for everyone and I'm not even sure I would PREFER it this way, but it's interesting. 

Overall, that's what Hydroneer is. Interesting. I got it on sale and find it very worth it. New updates are really adding a lot. Cooking is fun diversion and there's a lot of cosmetic building pieces, but it's all expensive. This seems like it could be a basis for a SUPER SUPER good MMO down the line. For now, It's mainly odd, but worth your time if you're a fan of the genre.

pros:
Very fun game that starts small and snowballs into a whole mining operation.
There's multiplayer and splitscreen, so you can play with your friend(s)
You can do crops farming if you get bored with mining.
You can do fishing and get better fishing rods as reward for certain rare drops.
Door-dash simulator included.


flaws:

There's a feeling for lack of content, although there's a lot to be done.
Once you get into T2 gear, drills, harvesters you rack up money so fast that after not much farming you sit on millions that you can't do anything with.
It's extremely annoying buying larger quantity of materials you need. You have to click 1 by 1 everything into preferably a cart and you can imagine when you need 500straight pipes and around that amount of conveyor belts.
When you're done with buying you have to struggle through 2-5fps (on very high end machine) to get that to your plot.
There's also fps problems once your mining operation goes bigger.
And never forget to turn off your machines before you save & quit the game.

Excellent game! Where a lot of games employ a farming/grinding mechanic and keep things simple (for the engineers) by limiting the impact of physics; the developer(s) of Hydroneer shouted "YEET" and decided to let physics play a significant role in the game. I love it - placing a bucket just a few inches off from where you wanted it to be could result in hundreds of raw resources just piling up on the ground next to it, requiring you to loathe your sloppiness, move the resources into the bucket manually, and move the bucket to a better position. It's certainly not enough of an occurrence to be frustrating but I absolutely love the reward for "being organized". Items like tables, walls, etc have true value because of the organizational benefit they bring - it isn't just cosmetic. Getting excited to bring home a new tool rack to your dig site is a legitimate experience because of this and it's just perfect IMO.

Hydroneer is one of those games which, on the surface, should actually be fun, and easy to play.  However the problem is, that while sure, it CAN be fun in spurts... it's more frustrating than anything.  What's more, it's as if the developer simply doesn't either have a clue how to fix the issues that players have... or has become so invested with his own goal for the end game that he simply ignores the issues.  

The number one issue this game has, is tied to its physics calculations. Which, if you know anything about the game itself, or what it claims to be, is a MAJOR problem. A problem which isn't really being addressed. The developer regularly posts streams about how he's making entirely new sections of the game... and yet never touches on the problems with physics.

It doesn't matter where you look, as a player you will inevitably run into physics issues with this game.  From things you just dropped being thrown off across the map due to the weird physics calculations; to vehicles like the mining truck simply being useless due to an inability to drive up a simple ramp.

Stop and think about that part people. A mining truck CAN NOT drive up a player placed ramp.  Now the truck doesn't just stop and sit there. Oh no, it will suddenly be punted into the air. If you're lucky, it comes back down in a place you can use it. Most of the time though this thing goes flying through the air and leaves you dizzy and frustrated.  All because the developer can't be bothered to go "oh, you know what, instead of doing this whole new expansion, let's sit down and put some serious time and work into fixing these physics issues." 

I want to like this game... really I do. However I can't. I've over 100 hours in it, and were it not so frustrating seeing my hard work just get exploded across the map because of some bad physics calculations; I like would have far more.

2.0 Update is out... now where to start.  It's... broken.  There seems to be a bug where, randomly, the game will decide to just completely wipe your save. So all the work you've done, regardless of how many hours you put into the game, just poof, it's like you never touched the thing. Also, all your tools, money, and everything is gone, forcing you to start over and completely forget that save.

Compound that with tools like the 'hand sorter' that either yeets things over the pans you put down, or just decides to lag out and spill everything on the ground,  a curious, if not mind numbingly annoying decision to make players go on a hunt to figure out where the previously easy to find, and equally easy to use stock markets locations,  and an overall inflation of prices of the various better tools... and I'm starting to wonder why I even bother with the game.  Realistically speaking, were it even possible at this point, I'd request a refund, because I really don't want to bother with the headache of dealing with a game that's so buggy, and so very poorly thought out.  Buyer beware.  The game is NOT worth the price that's being asked.

I will say this, remember the mining truck? Well they fixed its ability to go up, or down a ramp.  And by fixed, I mean completely removed it from the game.  Which unless you particularly like using various expensive mining drills, or having to move a load of dirt by hand... makes the game so tedious that it's just not worth bothering with.  It's as if the developers looked at the game and said "Well we can't fix this, so eh, scrap it."  They claim to have 'more coming'... but given how they said "We'll have multiplayer" and then gave users a janky kind of split screen... something that games stopped doing in the 90's... well I don't hold out much hope of them actually fulfilling their promises.

That's probably what angers me the most.  The developers promise, promise, promise... and never really deliver.  It's like they expect you, the purchaser, to be dumb enough to accept whatever junk they throw at a wall in the hopes that something... anything... sticks.  Sadly, there's a lot of people out there who do just that, which in turn leads to things like that janky, failure of a multi player.  It's not hard to do multiplayer in unity. Other games have done full on multi player, and didn't have to default to split screen.  So what was the difference here?  

In the end, this "major update" is little more than "Added 2 new areas to mine, removed useful mining vehicles,  moved/hid sell points, and jacked the prices on machines up enough to make the grind even worse."  It's not an update, but little better than a 'content patch'.

Edit 2.

Oh it only gets worse. I mean seriously. The developer can't seem to figure out what he wants to actually do. Now a game that is marketed as a mining game... is delving into FARMING?  Come on Dev, pick something and stick with it!

The more these non-updates come out, that keep changing whatever direction the game is going in, the more I start to think that the game is just some kind of scam aimed at milking users for all the cash he can.  Always changing the direction of the game when popularity starts falling of.

Run, don't walk, RUN from this one as fast as you can. It's not worth it.

Edit:  So, here's a new 'update' to this review. Something you should seriously consider prior to even looking at the game.

Whatever you do, you must only say good things about the game in the discussions... else you'll get banned. Now, sure, I know that banning any dissenting comments, or even users from a Steam Discussion is directly against Valve's own rules for developers.... but based off my own recent experience where I dared answer a question honestly about whether or not the game, in its current state, is even worth buying with an unequivocal no... I have now been banned from the discussions. I do plan on contacting Valve in regards to this behavior though.

As a fan of survival games, I was looking for a laid-back and relaxing experience without the added pressure of managing hunger or thirst. This game fits the bill perfectly, with gameplay centered around optimizing your own mine and/or farm, without any particular end goal other than to enjoy the process. 

Initially, the game may feel a bit repetitive, but as you progress, you can automate many of the more tedious tasks, allowing you to focus on the more advanced aspects of the game. I found myself getting lost in the decorating and optimizing of my mine and farm, which added a fun and creative element to the gameplay. As you continue to play, the game becomes more complex and satisfying, with plenty of challenges to keep things interesting.

What really sets this game apart is its welcoming community. In my experience, the community is incredibly supportive and helpful, and I was pleasantly surprised to be able to reach out to one of the developers and hear back in under 48 hours helping me with a game bug, and based on what I read from the patch notes after that, it looks like it may have been addressed. Having played many games over the years, I can confidently say that this community is one of the most helpful and supportive I've encountered.

Overall, if you're looking for a laid-back game to relax and unwind with, this game may be worth checking out. It has a lot of animal crossing appeal, where you are never really done as it wasn’t the point. While it may not be the most adrenaline-inducing game out there, it offers a stress-free experience and a supportive community that can make for a truly enjoyable gaming experience.

It feels like minecraft pre 1.16 (nether update); there's huge potential and the possibilities are endless but you are limited to the "build more bigger" gameplay loop. There's NO automatic crafting except jewel compression and smelting which functions as a lag reducer masquerading as wealth and utility conversion. The UI is creative and I love the immersion of a physical inventory system but it's not very user friendly or intuitive. Performance is also pretty bad. If you want a factory game with a 3rd dimension and a polished "feel" spend twice the price and get Satisfactory. 

If this game doesn't add a bunch more content in the next year and fix performance I am going to change this to a dislike. Currently, I believe in what this game can be one day and the dev(s) is clearly creative and competent.

The performance is bad and has been bad for years. On a new save that I just started, the game drops frames when turning the camera. That alone is enough to not recommend the game. I have a fairly good rig that runs far more intensive games, so I was surprised that this game (which does not look good compared to say, dyson sphere program) still cannot consistently run well. The game is mechanically simpler than minecraft and should not have performance issues on high end hardware.

I appreciate that the developer has put in work to add things like NPC's and more locations and even streamline the code, but when the performance is this bad and basic UI/UX stuff is still missing 2 years down the line, I can't recommend it. 

If the game ever moves away from it's busywork dropping/carrying gameplay and fixes the performance issues I will update the review.

Background: I bought this way back and returned recently to find the same asinine "no inventory" and "dropping reticle" systems never went away. I had gotten fairly far with the automation when I first played the game but there doesn't seem to be any direction from the developer to reduce all the running and dragging you have to do. I thought the game would get better as you play, but it just adds layers of busywork instead of challenges. 

You get vehicles and automation to replace your cart but you are still loading and unloading everything. Vehicles do not remove the busywork of running around delivering things or sloppily dropping things on top of each other instead of having an action to interact with your currently held item. The control scheme is sloppy but the current player-base will defend it because it's "hardcore". 

Fans of the game will say the game isn't for you if you suggest any changes so it doesn't look like the developer will ever change these things.

I've been back to this game a couple of times now (which I suppose says enough by itself), so I figure it's a good time to amend my old negative review.
My main issue was the performance, and while it's still not perfect (particularly when picking up a pan with a lot of ore chunks etc in it, which is odd since it shouldn't be calculating physics for them if they're locked to a container) it's a LOT better than it was when I last reviewed.
I still like the whole no inventory thing. It can get a bit tedious carrying things like foundations, and torches that don't want to stay in the cart, but generally it's kinda relaxing organising everything right there in-world. Things lock to containers when their physics settles, so you're not kicking over buckets and having your ore chunks spill all over the place. You WILL find plenty of other ways to spill 100 ore chunks all over the floor and have to pick them all up, though.
Overall there's a few Weird Design Decisions but it works pretty well now. Though I did turn voice off pretty quick because I might scream if I have to hear the word 'scran' again.

If you have fun tinkering and enjoy a challenging game where the only challenge is how far you can push your imagination in building and automation, this fits the bill. Has a pretty active mod community. I recommend checking it out for bulk buying and such.
Caveat Emptor - If your'e expecting to hit an "I" key and open your inventory (hint-there isn't one) or some backpack that can hold infinite items (hint-there isn't one), you may not want this game. Without mods, it's tedious transporting materials. It's a physical inventory and not a virtual one. Which means you lug each individual piece around with you either 1 at a time on your person or multiples in your vehicle. This is likely why I like the game so much - because you have to touch everything. May not be your cup of tea if that turns you off. 
The game is fun and the gameplay loop is basically "How much money can I make and how far can I stretch this automation?"
Highly recommended.

I was on the fence for a while, but overall I have to say this game isn't well done.  
Somewhat fun, yes, especially early on, but it's really frustrating overall.

Main problems:

1) bugs.   

Items disappearing, random freezes, long freezes during saving, and a total slowdown if you try to move too many items (few hundred will do it, eg a pan of resources)

2) tedium

Digging a bloody hole takes ages.  Moving earth takes 10 times more.   Moving items around  is slow.  And you have to re-build every single bit.  The program forgets item orientation, and rotating is not that intuitive either. (it's not even explained!)  Need I go on?  

3) total lack of information

Apart from some very basic youtube tutorial you get nothing.  Unless you consider hieroglyphs helpful.  (We have invented proper writing, why try to communicate with ambiguous images?)  The in-game descriptions of machines, logic pieces, etc are skeletal at best.  It's nearly impossible to figure things out on your own, since they aren't entirely logical - it certainly is very hard without some prior knowledge of some parts at least.   


[b]Summary:[/b]

Unless you are a time millionaire and want to punish yourself, I can't recommend it.  

You're expected to build logic circuits and networks of machines, building takes a significant amount of time due to the lack of proper building tools (eg multi-select), and you'll have to keep running to the shops (slow, you have to pack up 10 items to buy 10, no way to do it on one go!) and re-build things because of the lack of information.  

This combination is unforgivable in my opinion, hence the negative review.  

Alternatively you can copy/build stuff others have already figured out and posted online - but where is the fun in that?

I've never made a review before, but I've played for two hours and I can't play it anymore. I keep getting hit with the same bug over and over again, I've restarted several times, but my tools (Shovel, brush, pales) Keep disappears, they just despawn. I think I've figured out what's triggering it, if you put down shovel, then pick up another tool too quickly, it despawns the shovel. I have repurchased 4 shovels and 3 brushes, and I don't know, 3 pans. It's just stupid. I'm sure the game is fine, but I'm getting my money back.

I generally like the automation-crafting stuff like Factorio or Satisfactory, but I can't get into this one. Even from the start it's tedious with a pick-up/drop mechanic that has you constantly twitching your mouse to try and place things properly due to an offset drop icon that is different than the mouse cursor. And you have to learn to love it, because you can't change it and there is no inventory system or even holding two things at once. So most of your time is spent running around and switching between items trying to be efficient. Once you DO set up your first mining and sorting automation, things will quickly become buggy when you pick up your pail of a hundred mixed raw materials. And god forbid you misestimate how the physics are going to pour those items or you'll spend the next 10 minutes picking everything back up. Or if your sorter becomes unpowered without you realizing it (because there is no indicator), because a filter went bad and cut off the water supply. Then you're spending 15 minutes rotating around picking out the materials, because no, the sorter will only sort things that pass through the opening, not materials already in the sorter. Just overall feels like a half-baked tool set more than a game, like the product of an all-night game programming competitions or a school project someone turned in to graduate. Not awful, just not fun and definitely not optimally programmed or designed.

The developers tried to explore new inventory mechanics by simply completely doing away with an inventory, requiring you to use buckets and carts to carry anything beyond the single object in your hands. I appreciate the attempt at originality, but it is utterly atrocious.

One might dismiss the tedium of picking up and dropping 4 or 5 different objects to accomplish a basic task like panning for gold so you can get started. That can be said to be a matter of taste. However, when you've got a pan full of hundreds of nuggets, you have no options except insane infuriating ones. Sort them by hand? Will take you an hour. Dump them into a sorting machine? You'll probably miss, and the machine will miss the pans you set up to catch the output. Use a magnet tool to police the mess you just made? It's garbage, won't attract what you want it to, and will attract what you don't want it to. Plus more than a few dozen nuggets will destroy your framerate and make you vastly more likely to miss the toilet bowl. No words can express how rage-inducing it is to see an explosion of nuggets go all over the place because you missed your lay-up.

My advice to the developer would be to abandon this failed attempt at item mechanics, and give the player pockets, at LEAST for resources. You don't need an inventory screen, just give the player a non-physical way to police nuggets.

I'm honestly torn about leaving a negative comment, because I have actually enjoyed playing this game... it's just that there are more negatives than positives for me in this game as it is.

It's very grind-y in the beginning, which I love, but then it's also very easy - almost too easy - to set yourself up with an automated mining place and making big bucks for no real reason. I mean there's nothing to really spend your money on besides expanding your automatic mining "factory" but even then it just makes your game lag more than it's worth.

I really do love smelting my ores and weighing them to see how much they're worth - I almost feel compulsive about having to make weapons or jewelry that are worth more than my last! .. but after a while it feels really pointless because it's basically the only thing I do in this game since everything is already running on it's own. I usually end up playing on my phone with this game going in the background on my computer.. and that's not really cool. 

It also needs some readjustments for snapping things to place - some times it feels like I've spent most of my time in this game trying to get my pipes in the right place. It is incredibly frustrating sometimes, especially when you haven't hammered something into place and accidentally pick it up again (lmao)
Collision is also crazy in this game - things will fly and bounce away into nothingness very frequently. 
I'm also experiencing some of the worst lag ever recently - out of nowhere - when I start my machines up. Like it's so bad I can't do anything!
All in all, I will probably come back to see how this game is doing in a near future, and will hopefully be able to leave a more positive comment on here! I very much love the concept of this game and I don't regret spending money on it!
I hate pressing the "no" on wheter or not I recommend this game, because I know there are people who have better patience than I do with the things I find negative in the game. I do recommend people to at least try the game out - but for the purpose of my comment I'll tick the "no" for now.
____

I noticed that a lot of the things that made my previous playing experience negative had been tweaked and worked on and I honestly don't have anything negative to say this time!

The most fun grind there is - at least for a short while.

It's actually quite amazing that this game is built with Unreal ShitForAnEngine and manages to run almost always at 114ish fps.

There are a few bad pracrice coding issues the devs should probably address, like - I'm willing to bet - Tick Aggregation on mining machines (add enough and the frames start to drop, which indicates their on tick event is individualized).

Collisions are shit, that's the engine however. There really isn't all that much a developer can do. Maybe buy and use a different physics engine - like Havok - which sure does cut into the profit margin a wee bit but is much more reliable than anything the Epic team touches...

Overall, the item progression / money acquisition is simple and logical enough that you can just sit there and figure stuff out.

There are some lazy design choices that the devs are peddling as "wanting people to have to think to build".
They appear most obvious in the logic nodes proably, where you have >= but not <= (and all you have to do is turn the piece around). One of the not so clear ones is the lack of cross intersections on all pipes.

I haven't even began to peruse the house building items, and there is a ton of them, which makes playing and building fun, as you wait for resources to gather up.

Overall, the game is well worth its money.

Special note, the voxel system for digging is nicer than one would expect. And the tools provided are rather spot on. It's not even close to no man's sky in terms of *fun factor* of terrain manipulation, but if you want to go full dwarve and dig up a copy of moria by pickaxe, this is the game for it XD

I want to like this game, I really do, I've heard the game is really good afterwards, but the early game is killing it for me. Not that it is boring exactly, but the bugs combined with janky controls.Placing buildable items is a nightmare, I somehow managed to place an item under the ground, so I had to dig it up to place it again. Items falling through the ground or flying off into the sky to never see them again, so you can go buy another bucket or another shovel, this is exacerbated by controls, which disallows you to place an item on the ground, you have to drop it, which can cause it to fall somewhere you don't want to, which can cause it to fly away or fall through the ground. Manual handling of individual ores is insanely annoying, as spilling the ores into a crucible may cause it to spill the ores everywhere but the crucible, if the game so decides. Oh and hitting the crucible onto a furnace? I mean, the crucible visibly heats up, if it is in a correct place, that's great! Until you need to spill the melted iron into a mold, and place the crucible back, and now the visibly heating up is useless, because it is heated up already and you can't notice it, so place it back, only to find out later it was not heating and now you have to wait until it heats up again.

I originally played this game when it was fairly new, and I excused this because it was new and decided to wait until I play again, so that they have time to fix these issues.
The game is at 2.something while it still feels like an early access.

Notice how all the positive reviews for this game has no substance to them? That's because the game doesn't have substance either.

It is incredibly grindy (especially the first hour), forced to watch YouTube videos to understand the basic mechanics, simple and unbalanced progression system, no goals to work towards, and it is incredibly buggy.

During my short time paying the game I encountered 7 game disrupting bugs that has no place in a game that is past early access:

-Your main truck spazzes out and flies endlessly when it has stuff in the back of it. The reset vehicle button doesn't work as expected.
-I get stuck suspended between terrain and buildings and need to force unstuck myself.
-I dropped money on the ground and it clipped through the floor. Twice. Had to cheat more money in to regain my losses.
-Building placement is janky as hell. Can't place buildings where I think I should be able to, and can place them where I shouldn't (like completely submerged underground).
-Crops stop regrowing after a harvest without any visual indication of that. Had to go to Reddit to figure out they need to be cut down and replanted after a harvest.
-The game drops to single digit FPS when picking up a bucket full of gems.
-Crashed to desktop multiple times randomly, losing unsaved progress.

If you want a factory game, just go play literally any other factory game on the market. Your money will be better spent there.

Changing from a negative to a positive.

The new updates have breathed new life into the game. Vehicles now feel 'real', no longer are there weird glitches happening all the time with driving or with loose items, the NPCs add a bit of life to the game (I'd still like to see a lot more personally, but what's there is good). I haven't even gotten to the new farming content yet, which is the first time I've really felt like I've had to come back and revisit the game for a second sitting since I purchased it. It's beginning to morph into a legitimately great game and I'm thrilled for the devs - there's a lot of love being poured into this. The updates aren't _frequent_ but they're consistent, and consistently good.

Overall, I'd say yeah, give it a try. It's a bit different than other titles in the genre but it's a cute little gem nonetheless. Happy to be changing this from a negative to a positive.

---ORIGINAL NEGATIVE REVIEW---

UPDATE:

New major release has a lot of gameplay improvements but is still insanely buggy right now. Review on its way to being positive, but I'm still judging pretty harshly given that this is clearly an early access game billed as a completed game.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:

Will probably change this to positive at some point, but right now I can't. I had to check the store page to confirm it really wasn't early access, because it sure feels like it. There are the beginnings of a GREAT game here, but a lot of work needs to be put into the polish at this point.

PROS:

- Fun concepts
- Great graphics (not too flashy, very cohesive, good lighting and fun style)
- The voxel handling is mostly okay - digging really feels like you're digging, which is a hard thing to achieve.
- The shopping system is really fun. It feels realistic and satisfying loading up and taking away a haul.
- The early game is actually a lot of fun. I like having to do the work manually and build up to automation. Really makes you appreciate the game and makes the work feel worthwhile. The dig/water/scrub/smelt/craft flow is awesome and rewarding.

CONS

- SLOW. This game is soooo sloooowwwww to progress in. I saved up a bunch of gold before I started building automation - when I had enough to buy the parts, It took me an hour just to build a basic mining rig, and it was NOT a fun experience.
- The balance is very off. Things seem to cost a normal amount, but you have to buy a LOT in order to do anything interesting. The pipe system is fun but the proportions are tiny and cumbersome to work with, and the water pressure part is aggravating due to water being kind of far from any of your rigs.
- The physics are extremely buggy; items fall through the ground _often_, and your truck will randomly fly through the air to another part of the map without notice.
- It's not very clear how some things word - this is arguably a pro as I sometimes find this exciting, but there is no "affordance" (UX term) given by many of the items nor the piping systems.
- Item placement is annoying and buggy - you are allowed to place items under the ground, even deeper than the lowest diggable point, which makes no sense. Also, you can place e.g. two pipes in the same spot and it's a tossup how the game will react.
- It's quiet - no music, no people walking around, no voices. Just subtle sound effects (admittedly the ones that are there are quite pleasant to hear - there just aren't many).

SUGGESTIONS TO THE DEV(s):

- Fix the physics. Really. It's really bad. Fearing my stuff is going to fall through the ground is an awful feeling, and getting launched a mile into the air isn't fun either.
- Make straight pipes expandable, even if you raise the price 10x. Having to buy and then load 100 pieces into the truck just to get _anything_ running is tedious and kills any joy I had.
- Not sure if this is technically feasible, but make the entire underground diggable - not just the small plots. Enforce boundaries, sure, but I can see myself hitting the end of the game content and being frustrated.
- Add some music and ambient environment effects. The atmosphere is too quiet.
- Explain what the different trucks do. Why do three different colored trucks exist that are the same price but still more expensive than the default truck, which looks the same?
- The smelting process seems like I'm wasting ores because the bars cap out at a certain point, but there's no indication as to how to make sure.
- Make the drop point position (the green circle) configurable. It's incredibly awkward trying to chance a drop into a bucket or something - I spend maybe 20% of my time picking shit up because the aim was 1 pixel off.

Very easy to get lost in the sauce

At present, no, can't recommend due to motion sickness issues. The idea is fine and it's a neat concept that everything is a physical object instead of just an image in an inventory, but that concept is also a problem as it means you have to constantly move tiny little things around.

Starting with the very basic mechanic of dig dirt and put dirt in bucket requires constantly moving the camera from side to side. Once you put dirt in basin and brush the thing, you then again have to move every single nugget one by one, which again means moving the camera all over repeatedly. This constant and repeated need to moving the camera back and forth is nauseating and by itself makes the game unplayable for anyone prone to motion sickness. And it does not help that the drop marker is always somewhere off to the side instead of where you're looking, so you have to look around to figure out where the stuff you drop will end up.

Given the basic mechanics of the game I don't see any simple fix to avoid the motion sickness because it requires changing how it works so you don't have to move the camera as much. Basic things like make stuff drop where the crosshair is pointing and being able to pick up more than 1 thing at a time would go a long way (and make the game a lot more intuitive), but the digging mechanic has to be totally redone for this to be possible.

Essentially, the biggest problem with the way the game works is that it's first person. If it was in third person the mechanics would be far less nauseating, but not any less tedious.

update jan 2, 2023:

decided to give the game another go, since there'd been a major update and a few patches.
another six hours. in which very little was accomplished, a great deal of time was spent fighting the clunky gameplay, and i've renewed my resolve to not come back to this game anytime soon.

last patch notes tells me vehicles were reworked! but nothing about how. i [b]do[/b] know that vehicle steering is still tied to framerate, against all rationality, so if you have your framerate fixed at 30 fps (which the game lets you do in the settings ui, and there are many rational reasons for a player to choose to do so), steering is misery (and this isn't just the trucks; carts are vehicles too). also controller turning is also tied to framerate. good luck with that if you don't have rock solid fps.

gameflow is still a trainwreck. no inventory, no ability to move things in bulk in any kind of rational manner aside from small pans of tiny objects. need a bunch of building supplies? yeah, tedious manual labor. need to rework your layout? more tedious manual labor. want to get a nice smooth span of dirt? play the rake gambling game, there's no way to get it to work consistently in vanilla (and i couldn't bring myself to start messing around seriously with mods to find out if it can be fixed properly that way).

for that matter i couldn't even bring myself to get as far as doing crops, because i was so miserable just trying to get to basic automation going; i'm now convinced the hand sorters are a malicious trap, since the belt versions aren't much more expensive and are substantially less frustrating. [i]less[/i], mind you. all automation in this game is still misery.

pretty much everything from the previous version of my review still stands (the objectives might be stretched out by farming, maybe, but i didn't get there and i doubt it addresses the fundamental issues), so i've left the rest unaltered.

original may 12, 2022 review:
it's a cute game, with a fairly clear premise, with a dedicated dev team. there's just not enough to it, and there are enough user experience flaws that even at the current sale price ($7 usd) i can't in good conscience recommend it.

content-wise, there's six dig sites, each with different vistas, there's a few shopping areas, and a little bit of explorable territory that has no gameplay impact. unfortunately, unless you are into hunting hidden items, you can easily see most of what the game has to offer without ever crossing into 'tier 2' equipment. after you get through a little of the obligatory hand mining, the tier 1 harvester (you only need one, bought by the starter plot) and some tier 1 drills (you can buy one with the harvester) will easily produce quite a lot of money, and while it will keep you busy for a while buying more automation framework (conveyor belts, pipes, repair tools, better pipes, automation for repair, etc), there hits a point with just tier 1 machinery where you are producing money faster than you can spend it. once you hit this threshold -- i did with just six tier 1 drills in a second digsite -- there is little actual pressure to continue on to tier 2 equipment unless you just really want to see bigger numbers.

to be clear: you don't earn money faster than you can find things you want to buy, but faster than [i]you are capable of actually spending it[/i]. this gets into the user experience flaws: you have to buy things one at a time, moreover, the process for purchasing things is especially laborious due to the dev's choice to avoid anything menu-like. pick up item, put it in purchase area, repeat, until you have as many things as you want to buy (or can fit into the purchase area, if you aren't using a cart), then you put money into the pay bin, hit a button... and then you have to get the stuff back home. usually by loading it into a truck. at which point you have to laboriously unload it, optionally staging it somewhere before you start building things.

there is no way for this to move more quickly. there are no reasonable ways of packaging objects for ease of movement or storage. you cannot buy things in bulk. everything is, by design, exceedingly laborious.

and all of this is without getting into the persistent issues: hydroneer 2.0 did function as an effective rewrite of the game's logic, which greatly improved the physics stability, but there are still a large number of issues with regards to arbitrary framerate issues (in truth [b]simulation rate[/b] issues, but simulation rate and framerate are tragically linked) which result in effectively punishing the player for trying to buy too many things at once. especially since while the game is at a low frame/simulation rate, physics for the vehicles get increasingly dodgy, to the point where they can rapidly become undriveable. while i'd like to think these problems could be solved, the fact the developer didn't think solving these problems warranted more time before shipping the update is unfortunate.

i'll probably check the game out again in the next major update, and maybe i'll flip my recommendation around at that point, but right now i just don't see the game as worth it for most players.

and as for my current playtime of 73.9 hours as of this writing: only 37.1 hours are from the 2.0 update, the previous were from my failed attempts at getting automation going because the pre-2.0 physics were unbearable. it *has* improved markedly. it could improve more. but the game still isn't there just yet.

This game is GREAT!

It does have its ups and its downs, but it is definitely more positive than negative.

It has a steep learning curve in the early game and little more than a YouTube video from the Devs to help guide you. This video (or at least watching another guide to starting from YoutTube) is critical to success as it’s not intuitive!

But getting over that learning curve, you learn some of the many charms of this game!

You have no inventory, so you have to manage everything a little more than you might in most games. You can only pick up one item at a time, so you end up having to put things in a container and carrying that. Or you load up one of the vehicles and move things about that way. This can get a little annoying when doing a big project, but mostly adds to the complexity/problem solving aspect of the game!

Next you have 2 cursors - one for picking up items or using them on things, and another for where you’ll drop items. Again, not intuitive, but once you get used to it, can be used to great effect.

The begins the grind - you start at the beginning of your mining journey panning for resources - dig dirt, wash it, get stuff. This can be painful, but there are strategies to optimise this (YouTube to the rescue again). But basically you do a bunch of panning & earn a bit of money selling your resources to the Jeweller.

Some people then use this money to buy a fishing rod & go fishing - personally I find fishing a bit boring and beyond completing the quests to upgrade to the T8 fishing pole rarely do it - and then only when I’m waiting around for other things. I also find this to be much slower than going back to mining more.

The alternative is, you can use your money to buy some equipment to make things easier - unfortunately, you likely didn’t make lots, so you’re still on the hand panning, but you can make this a lot easier for yourself with the new equipment. Also new equipment will make it easier to get as low as possible - the lower you go in this game the heavier the resources you get from the same action. So, another hand panning session, and possibly a bit of processing (depends how much you got from the first session, if you had enough to buy everything that would be useful) and it’s off to the Jeweller again!

You’re likely to have enough money now (if not it’ll be another panning session for you) to start moving into automation. Then it’s drills (that perpetually dig dirt for you) and harvesters (that do the cleaning for you) and conveyors (to move it all around) and pipes (to power it all).

If you’ve done your research beforehand, even at a leisurely pace, it’ll only really take you an hour to get to this point.

There are more dig sites available to buy for reasonable prices (if you’ve done particularly well with your panning, you’ve probably got enough to go buy one before setting up automation) the starting plot is limited to only a certain depth.

More drills (including the next tier) can be crafted at an old dwarven mine “Icehelm” which is a cool little progression mechanic.

There’s farming as well now! I recommend having made yourself a fair bit of money before diving into farming - it’s totally optional, gets you a different currency, which only buys more farming items - but could probably be started as soon as you have enough money to buy the basic equipment.

Farming is fun - not only do you have to make a farm, you have to find customers who want soup, cook soup to their orders, then deliver it to them. Again, it can feel a little grindy at times, but the progression feels real and purposeful.

There’s a load of vehicles to help with things like moving stuff about, but also more specific things like collecting crops, sowing seed and flattening land.

There are building pieces which can be used to construct buildings and interiors. Some players have made pretty buildings, others have made entire complexes of buildings.

There’s even a logic system to automate the automation further.

There’s a lovely discord community full of friendly and helpful players if you get stuck/need help figuring something out. And a whole community of modders, adding in community requests, the devs don’t feel fit the game.

Yes, there’s problems - the obvious lack of an in game tutorial system. The game occasionally throws a spanner in the works when someone does something not anticipated. Early game/late game needs a bit of a rebalance. The game eventually “runs out of content”. But these are mostly being addressed - there are regular bug fixes whenever something becomes apparent, not just someone derping into ridiculous situations. Things are regularly reviewed to improve them (the game balance is much better than it was). There are regular free major updates adding more content.

The multiplayer (up to 4P) is only streamed split screen at the minute, what’s more, only one person can use mouse and keyboard - everyone else needs to use controllers. This might be a deal breaker for some people. Personally I don’t multiplayer that often, and when I do, it’s tolerable. The devs explain that the tools aren’t available given the mass of objects in a normal hydroneer save - it’d be like your playing a game of pool and on player 1’s screen the black ball goes down the hole, but on player 2’s screen the black ball jumps the cushion and rolls away from the table - you want everything to be the same for both players, else things are gonna get funky real fast!

The game starts using the best settings it can - I’ve got a good pc, but my game turned into a slideshow. Unless you have a serious computing rig (graphics are key to this game) I suggest the first thing you do is reduce the graphics settings.

Couple of things to bear in mind before complaining - This was mostly created by a single dev, and the team is still pretty small. The cost for this game is still really low, given the quality of the game.


SUMMARY

As I said, this game is great. It’s original and quirky - in a good way. It offers progression and development. At the time of writing this, I’ve played 150 hours and I’m far from having experienced everything. Yes I can see content running out, but they are adding more all the time. Also, it’s a sandbox game, there’s more than one way to skin every cat, obviously some are more efficient than others, but figuring out all the variations adds many hours of fun. While not for everyone, I do recommend checking it out and giving it a fair chance to get used to the control system.
