Most of my previous grievances have been remedied; whether by update, IDT10T, or PEBKAC realization.
After giving it another go and an update, my only current complaint is the turn speed when using a Steam Controller and PlayTogether multiplayer. I turn so slowly it is like watching a 97 year with a walking cane that gives you a "fear they'll fall over if they move faster" jolt every 3-0.5 seconds. That, and I haven't figured out (or looked up the button combos to, since I'm 2nd Player) how to rotate items to set them down and connect, lmao. All my movements via Steam Controller feel clunky. After a few hours' playtime, it "feels" like I process dirt to ore/gems at <10% the rate of the host who uses mouse+keyboard. The hardest part of the game is now pointing at and clicking the right thing; the slowest part is moving my POV centerspot. Maybe I need to change my controller profile settings before joining the PlayTogether session??

===Original Review===
The general outline of the game is good, but implementation leaves something to be desired. Methods to make the painfully boring primary loop (shoveling dirt and cleaning it) less painful are punished by making your dirt and effort disappear. Oh, I'm sorry, is there water in your bucket? Watch all of the dirt you just dumped into it disappear from the world! Oh, I'm sorry, did you put dirt directly into the pan instead of filling the bucket first? You can no longer put any dirt into the bucket and get crap items after cleaning it! Oh, I'm sorry, did you dump dirt into the bucket after putting dirt directly into it? Watch it become unusable! Oh, I'm sorry, did you think putting your bucket in the stream would makes things faster? Refer to the first game-induced griefing described earlier.

Compared to other games with construction, factories, automation, etc, this game doesn't want you to build big quickly. This game focuses on aesthetic and presentation to the detriment of building. Some people will like that, as everything you build feels impactful, but that feeling is because the game hamstrings you with poor tools for constructing inside a sandbox.

Buying and laying down an object is tedious, because each piece needs to be picked up and placed 3 times. Once when taking a copy to put on the checkout pad, again to load onto truck, and then a 3rd time to place it where you want. Sometimes 4 if you want to unload your stuff from your truck closer to the build site.

The "sandbox" label is well deserved, because there aren't much in the way of new resources, items, processes, etc to get. I got there within the few hours of playtime I had.

As for performance, I have 10 second full pauses I can't understand the cause of that happen somewhere on the order of every 20-60mins, very randomly. Game straight up stops all movement/video except audio. There are tiny pauses during saves, but its the full 10 second pauses that are frustrating.

The game's lighting feels overly harsh, with sunset/sunrise lasting too long and providing inadequate light for too long. The light sources that can be bought are mediocre and feel like a waste of money. Sleeping is a weird mechanic that feels misplaced, as the game isn't survival.

Placing objects is hard because snapping to the grid is frustrating, and it won't intelligently snap to parts. Trying to drop something from your hands is hard because your shovel will clip an oversized collision mesh, even though visually it isn't touching anything at all. This then begins a frustrating "dance" to figure out where its safe to drop something, all the while the character's annoying grunt sound plays as the only feedback something is wrong.

Voice lines are repeated frequently, and there are few voice lines. Most characters share the same voice lines.

What made me give up, was in realizing I would hate the redesign process. If I designed it wrong, I'd have to individually deconstruct everything. If I wanted to use my stuff elsewhere, I'd have to deconstruct, load, move, and reconstruct one piece at a time. I had just got the machines for self-drilling, harvesting, sorting, and smelting. Would I want to slowly rebuild all of that? Knowing a good chunk of that time would be driving back and forth to the shops, slowly buying items? I kept thinking "not really..."

After foreseeing that future, I realized other construction games spoiled me with all kinds of tools, items, mechanics, and more that make building and creating fun; this game has none of those tools. Its all about the moment-to-moment feel of individually placing each part and "living" in a sandbox with wooden NPCs and destructible terrain in designated sandbox only areas.

[h1] Tedious and Unsatisfying [/h1]

Consider buying this game IF you've played and enjoyed Satisfactory or Factorio AND you've gotten bored with those games AND IF you can get Hydroneer on sale. Even then, you might want to steer clear of this boring time sink.

Hydroneer drops you into the game with no guidance and only a link to a YouTube tutorial that is light on details. The interface is arduous and unnecessarily cumbersome; especially in the early part of the game. You can only pick up one item at a time which makes for gameplay designed to obscure a lack of content with tedious repetition. Imagine spending 15 minutes mining a bucket full of ore only to accidentally left click and dump all 50 tiny ore pieces all over the ground. The first few hours of the game for me were a "pick up small things" simulator. There's a magnet available for purchase deeper in the game but this should really be made apparent and available immediately to new players.

The game is fraught with ill conceived design decisions. For example: to mine resources you need both a drill and a harvester that each require an input pipe for water. The drill exhumes the dirt and drops it one block down into the top of the harvester so the ore can be extracted. However, these two pieces of equipment don't fit neatly together which results in the most common setup being a floating drill that players shovel dirt back under to get it to work. The game seems to go out of its way to make things difficult.   Since you can only pick up one thing at a time you'll make thousands of back and forth trips between shops and vehicles to move one pipe segment at a time. 

If you cut all this tedium out of the game you'd have a few hours of content at most and that's when you notice that this game is hollow. The world is hollow, the NPCs are hollow, the progression is hollow, the tech tree is shallow, the crafting is just awful - don't get me started on the stupid anvil and recipes nightmare. There aren't any milestones to work towards or sense of raison d'être.  The only enjoyable and redeeming aspect of this game is the pleasant *THUNK* sound your truck makes when it runs over a villager; but even that wasn't worth the entry fee.

I originally saw this game on YouTube and instantly wanted to play it. It isn't early access, but it is clear that the sole developer of the game is very excited and genuine about improving and adding on to the game, and even at this stage it is already a great game. I've played for about 4 hours now, and there is still so much of the game I haven't done yet! On top of this, I know that there is a lot more content to come. Yes there are some bugs and such, but overall I have greatly enjoyed the game, and I'm excited to see where it goes!

Edit: It has been two years since the game has come out, and it is still receiving a lot of major updates! This game has been so much fun, and there is always new stuff coming out to make it even better!

Edit: Once again, yet another update. And the game now has... FARMING?!?!? Some might wonder why there is farming in a game about prospecting, but I am honestly more in love with the game than I have ever been. Not only can you plant and water crops, harvest and sell them or make them into soup, but you can automate the farming, and there are now npcs! You can make bowls of soup from the crops and give them to npcs that request them. Eventually, maybe there will be more types of quests, and who knows what else will be added to the game!

On previous updates they also added fishing, which is simple but also fun, and of course as with everything else in the game, it can be automated, so you can find unique ways to gather tons of fish!

Good devs, good updates, good game.

The developers put out monthly updates to keep players in the loop as they anticipate update and as far as I can see, every update has done an incredible job at upgrading the players experience and giving the players more reason to come back.

-What this game does-
Currently it is an amazing combination of mining, blacksmithing, fishing, and farming. This game plops you into a wonderful world (Now filled with NPC's from the farming update) and gives you nothing but a brush, two sift pans, a map, and a shovel. Yes that sounds awful, back breaking labor and doing everything manually but this will only happen if you let it as when you start digging away and finally making some money you get to upgrade your muscle powered factory and use the power of water to finally let yourself sit down and relax. May as well pick up fishing to make an extra buck as your hydro powered machines churn away the earth and spit out precious resources.

This game has a great sense or relaxation as you quietly become the richest man in the village. Everything will start slow with you only making a few hundred at a time but it just gets faster and faster as you improve on your automation.

-Tips for new players-
Fish can be cooked and be sold for a higher price rather than raw. There's no indication when the meat is perfectly cooked but the meat will darken as it cooks and if you leave it too long you can burn the meat and ruin your fishes value. I do hope a cooking system can be properly implemented. Maybe something like how Sea of Thieves does it? 

The deeper you dig, the better the resources.

If any pesky NPC's get in your home demanding soup and refusing to leave your property just pause, save and go to menu, and load back in and all should be fixed.

-Current bugs at the time of this review-
[strike]If you happen to be carrying around a cart while looking at an NPC, do not hit the pick up key (Default is E) when looking at them as you will forfeit your cart to the soup loving NPC but your character movement will still act as though you are holding a cart. Thankfully there is a simple fix and that's just: Pause, Save and go to menu, and load back in. Hopefully after that your player should be normal and your cart with its possessions will be next to the NPC.[/strike]

Devs fixed this bug as of 12/13/22

I don't have a lot of hours in the game but it is a lot of fun.  I play a few games like this and this one offers a lot of what the others offer but at a much lower price.  At $10 you just can't go wrong.  The devs are still adding things to the game, not as dlcs or xpacks but just as part of the game for free.  The game start is a little slow at first but it gives you more than one path to make money.  You don't want to dig with a shovel?  Fish!  I found fishing is faster to make that start up money to buy an automated mining operation.  But you can dig and gold pan to get chunks of ore to start out too.  There is no real end game.  The game will pretty much go on forever.  I haven't found a way to die yet so it is just a game to let you build what you want and then watch your creation work.

I absolutely love this game and want to give it a wholehearted thumbs up without a single caveat... But I gotta list some real cons before hand. 

While the lack of a UI and simple control scheme is rather charming and totally fine, there are certain things that absolutely leave you scratching your head. With the tutorial video it's actually really easy to pick up, but there has still been countless times I've had to look something up or check the control settings because a tool tip isn't as helpful as one would hope. 

There feels like so much to do in your journey toward truly automating! and while I adore the time spent getting there and there is something really satisfying about doing things by hand, but it still feels like there are massive quality of life options missing. Like why is it that a game that encourages digging big ol holes (and outright requires massive holes in places like Mildew's Aquifer) still have digging be the most tedious and time consuming task possible? There are also no ladders so the only way out of a hole of your own creation is an awkward concrete staircase, or the good ol' "unstuck" option in the esc menu. 

Setting items down or watering plants are just a constant fight with the physics engine, and trying to place build items is it's own special battle every time. Especially when the ground I've painstakingly leveled out keeps rising over and over again. It's also a little silly that certain containers will only carry certain items, and anything else will just phase through it. Also water filters are the actual worst, as they break easy, and shut off the water when they do, bringing the entire line to a complete and utter stop. The benefit they provide is VASTLY outweighed by the tedium of running out of repair kits every five seconds because they break CONSTANTLY. Take em off and repair your machines when they break, I promise you it's a time saver. 

And even with all this said... I want to keep playing. It scratches an itch that a lot of those base building/automation games cant quite. Everything is so hands on, it lights up that part of my brain that wants to make mud castles and sort through shiny rocks. The Devs clearly have a lot of love for what they're doing and it shows. So if you don't mind a little bit of jank and keeping wiki open on a second screen, definitely give it a try. 

Seriously though, please give me ladders, teleporting is making me nauseous.

Having put nearly 100 hours into 2.0, I have to say I'm conflicted about my review. For the price, you can argue there's a lot of game(time, the game loop is pretty simplistic) for the money, but this game feels early access at best, not a second major iteration.

The concept is fun, some of the mechanics leave a lot to be desired, such as the buying system, even with using the cart or truck within the shop. I've heard second hand from the community that the dev is trying to avoid putting any sort of hud in to the game and while this is an understandable desire, it shouldn't be at the detriment of the game. Mods help with some of this and I can only hope they're brought into vanilla at some point. 

The game inspires you to build big, but what ever part of the game it is, can not handle big; with clogs being a main gripe, but also once you get to a certain size, even loading the game becomes a challenge.

I'd love to recommend this game and at the price I almost feel like I should, but with the current state of the game(I never played pre-2.0) this feels more like a beta or early access game.

[edit] v2.1
I put a few more hours into this game and I'm starting to believe this is just another rage game in disguise; like why the hell is my combine harvester drifting away from the belts as I'm emptying it and why do I need to continuously hold down a button to empty? I continue to believe the dev makes bad design choices for the sake of aesthetics, when the control and inventory systems need a massive overhaul. I could go on for much longer about the issues with this game that the dev just turns a blind eye to. This game should be one of those in the relaxing category for awards, but the flaws just make it a blood boiler!

I wasn't sure at first, but I've been won over by this cozy and mysterious game.  Something I really came to appreciate was how everything in this world must be carried, organized, or processed as an object right in front of you.  There's no inventory slots, no pockets to stuff things into.  So everything you build and every coin you earn comes from something you painstakingly carried around in your hands.  I haven't played another game like this!

Playing before the 2.1 update, I was all alone in a bizarre countryside where local commerce was run by a syndicate of autonomous buckets.  It was then that I learned every lesson on my tiny starting plot, carving and shaping every trench, running to fix broken machines, and watching my wealth grow in proportion to my knowledge and steady technological advancement.  But nothing really told me how to do this and the sense of incremental discovery felt benevolent and playful.

After the 2.1 update, this lonely world became overrun with beautiful, talkative NPCs who fit right in with the character of this world.  I see carrot seeds sitting on the shop bench, and a chef's knife on the table, and a stove for cooking pots.  I know I'll have to earn every drop of that soup myself, and somehow it's a satisfying adventure.

It's a good game with more content coming.  Maybe it will draw you in too.

This game should be early access. It feels like early access. More features are being implemented pretty regularly, and there are still a lot of pretty bad bugs. I've played early access games that felt more feature complete than this game. All of my gripes with this game would go away if it was just labeled "early access," but they pushed not only the final release, but now they're on 2.1.  I started playing in 2.0, so you'd think it's pretty feature complete, but no, they're still adding/changing things.  Now my 2.0 save wont even load on 2.1, so I have to start over from scratch in a game I played 50+ hours.  That's an oof.  This isn't the first time I've had issues with saves either. About halfway into my last save it just stopped loading and I had to try a whole bunch of things to revert my saves.  It only keeps one previous save state so if your mistake was within the last autosave window, you're still screwed. 

The game still has a long way to go.  It calculates physics for every single object in the world that is in motion. This includes dirt clumps, so once you get a fairly decent mine going, the game just goes at a crawl. Unreal has tricks they could use to lower the physics overhead, but they are focusing on other areas.  This is something that should have been fixed before main release. Imagine if Satisfactory crashed because you built 50 machines? Meanwhile I have satisfactory saves with thousands of machines, but this game sputters with 50-60 machines on a $4000 computer. Yeah, ok. 

This game definitely has promise, but as it sits right now, it's definitely playing like early access. I guess I'll check back in a year or so like I did with No Man's Sky.

Edit: Ok, a Dev response deserves more than a short snarky review from me.

I really liked the idea of Hydroneer but the gameplay killed it for me.

The first five minutes of the game I was starting out learning the controls and doing the dig and brush routine when I either stepped on one of the tools and next thing I know I'm going mach 10 for the stars and end up splashing down on the other side of the island.{I know how Jeb feels in KSP now.} I thought the whole thing was hilarious but I had to restart because I had no idea how to get back to the start. (The whole 5 minutes of playtime thing.)

So I restarted and got into the whole dig and scrub thing for the next fifteen minutes or so. It was almost zen like. Then I decided to go sell my pan of sparkling nuggets... And then the new guy moment happened. I emptied the pan. Think it just dropped them nuggets in a neat pile? Nope. Looked like I bazooka barfed nuggets all over the claim. Spent more time picking up nuggets than I spent digging them out. (One of those situations where if it happened to someone else you would laugh your butt off.)

Spent the next sevenish hours randomly repeating variations or combinations of the first two events....  You know it's time to uninstall and call it a day when your left with a twitching eyelid from aggravation.

It's slow at first but that's what makes it fun, you can have different methods to make money and have fun

No tutorial, they just hit you with a "Watch a short video tutorial" which redirects you to your browser and a youtube video. Very poor, I really need to watch a Youtube video first before I can start playing the game?

Controls are so annoying and clunky. You can't pick up more than one item, if you want to start out digging you need do extremely tedious "grab shovel -> dig dirt -> place dirt in bucket" then its "drop shovel -> pick up water bucket -> throw it in river so it fills up with water (cause you cant scoop for some reason) -> pick up the water bucket -> throw contents in dirt bucket -> throw away bucket -> grab brush -> use brush on dirt/water bucket -> throw away brush -> grab ore

You see how tedious this is? You also cannot pick up more than one item, so you have to grab one ore at a time instead of just picking up multiple ores in an inventory. Holy cow this game makes watching paint dry more enjoyable.

No direction or guidance from the first second, even in the youtube comments of the tutorial video people are astonished why you need a shovel from X place to start playing.

Maybe it gets a lot better when you can automate stuff later, but damn after 20 minutes of play I have no interest in pursuing something with such ridiculous controls. Oh, and you cant even put down buckets to align on the ground. You just "drop" them and 9 out of 10 times it falls on the side so you keep picking up and trying to drop it so it lands on its bottom. And even putting small ores in a bucket goes wrong majority of the times because for some reason the mouse pointer is NOT the area where it's gonna fall, instead you gotta wing it where it might land.

Jesus even writing this makes me furious. Refunded immediately. I'll just go back to Satisfactory.

The placement system is awful.

Don't unstuck your car, then unstuck yourself while holding a shovel.  You'll get stuck PERMANANTLY inside your car and you can't drive the car because you're holding a shovel effectively softlocking your game.

It's such a painful task to dig down and set up machined below ground.  You need a "Magical" single layer of dirt to mine, you can't just mine off the bedrock for "God knows why," so you're left having to take a shovel and putting a uneven and awful looking layer of dirt to put machines on.  

This game got a lot of hype from some creators but I'm not starting to think they were paid to make a bad product look good...as is the way of capitalism. We continue to get fed nonsense by people willing to take money to do so and end up with unfinished and lackluster products.  As this slowly becomes the mainstream players are forced to lower their standards because none of them are smart enough to band together and make change happen and, not to mention, how they're constantly fed that organizing and making things happen doesn't work (It does, you're just stupid)

I'm sick of the new standard. I want finished, well-thought, games.  I don't need these half-arsed barely working over-priced monsters that do nothing but anger me.

A lot of mechanics in the game are very frustrating, especially since a lot of the automation features don't work as intended. On top of that my save broke very quickly and I hadn't even left the first area. There isn't a lot of content on top of that so the game gets very repetitive very quickly, mostly just waiting and repairing your machines, but to be fair the game is pretty cheap. Maybe in another few years I'll pick it back up but for now I don't recommend this one.

This game is a journey TO automation. Expect the 1st half or more of the game to be a grind to get each part you need to actually automate everything. For me I completed the fishing quests to get there and ignored mining a good chunk of the way until I was actually automating it. Making your automation pretty is kinda the other part of the thing. Most of the game you can accomplish what you need by building on a second property (tier 2 quality dirt doesn't show up in the starting spot). Personally I enjoyed the journey but some people will hate it. Just framing this game for what it is so you know what you're getting into. Once you feel like you 'beat it', check out the mods that're available and fill in where you feel the base game is lacking.

A little automation/crafting Game.

Pros: 
- Great foundtation to expand on with game mechanics and ideas (long term)

Cons (General):
- You can dig dirt and place it in the world, but the world doesnt care. Meaning that you can create infinitly long Dirt sausages in the air that ignore Physics in a game where it apears that physics should be relevant... (this is my biggest complain)

- Controlls feel off. You pick up stuff and drop it somewhere to the right. You get a circle to where you gonna drop something but ... why? Why dont you drop stuff in fron of you? I can only assume you need this offset for later but i never reached that point. The offset feels bad.
- With the shovel you can put 4 Dirt into the Bucket or 1 Dirt into the Pan. If you have 4 Dirt in the Bucket u can put this Dirt into the Pan. This is the only way to get 4 Dirts into the Pan. Why ? If you try to put 4 Dirts into the Pan with the Shovel, it wont let you, your limit becomes 1...  why cant i put 4 Dirt with the shovel in the pan ??
- You pick up water with the bucket by throwing it into the water ... this is a minor complain but cmon.
- Driving from the Castle down over the bridge with speed ALWAYS stops your car and bumps it in the air.

Other Cons:
- I can melt Iron and Gold, i can not melt Coins. Why cant i do this? I would love to experiment...
- Water in a bucket on a Furnance stays water.. this is a missed oportunity.

Yet another game that could use a 50/50 type rating. Although truth be told there are so many quality of life problems with this game that I'm tending more towards not recommending. Granted this is a small time dev, so everything with a grain of salt. 

If you think this is primarily a building game (like satisfactory but water power + mining), boy do I have to burst that bubble. This is much more like a simulation of the most inconvenient grocery shopping experience you could have. Imagine this, you're going to the grocery store to pick up your things. Bad news is you can only carry one thing at a time, which means you're carrying your coins into the store to buy. That's right, no coin storage for you! Just lug your pile around and try not to forget it anywhere. 

Next you have to load your items 1 at a time into the pay area. So walking back and forth with each item, just to pay. So 10 trips for 10 items to the checkout. THEN you also have to load your vehicle. So 10 trips just for those items you bought +1 for your money pile. The game does have a pallet you can buy to put items on, but guess what, items can't be gently placed onto the pallet, nor do they like to be stacked onto each other, so you're dealing with one layer high items that tend to bounce, or roll away when you try to place them. It's a huge pain in the butt. 

The best part is that because this is a building game you need A LOT of different parts and pieces. And you'll be spending most of your time packing and unpacking them. The actual building, the mining, the crafting, all of it takes a back seat to the nightmare that it is to get the goods. 

While I haven't played on creative mode, to my knowledge you can just create the parts you need and totally circumvent the hassle, but frankly for me I've always found creative modes to feel like cheating, and it takes the fun out of the game. 

Now you might think, surely the mining is worth it, surely you're actually getting true progressive rewards that pay off and make you feel like you've accomplished something other than wasted your time at the nightmare grocery store. Nope. There are 8 different resources at the time of writing this, and 5 different things you can craft. The only thing that changes with your mining depth is your % of finding them. All of them can be found in the starting claim. There is nothing flashy to discover, no big reward for crafting, no useful crafted items (like repair tools). 

Speaking of repairing, guess what your main purchases will be late game? Repair items. Things break all the time and I think this is meant to be the money sink for the game currently. The huge drawback for this is that it completely prevents true automation. At the same time with how things are set up when you're playing the story/regular mode do you really want to invest the time and tedium into trying to make an semi automated system that you have to babysit? Things like this make me question why have story mode, are we supposed to feel this much pain while playing?

I played over 20 hours trying to squeeze some true fun out of the game, trying to lessen the stress that normal mode brought. I thought that maybe the game would get better, so I progressed until I had one of the better claims, dug to the lowest point, and set up my mining op. Trade off with that was distance to the store, which was already set up to be highly punitive. One thing the game tells you is that if you dig deeper the rewards will be better, which yes technically your % chance of finding the resources increase, but you're not actually getting better rewards. Just more of the same. 

This game adds more stress than relaxation (currently). There isn't a lot to do, there isn't a lot to achieve at all. The game itself is lonely, there are no NPCs, no quests, no life, with the towns literally having lights on but no one home. Waiting for NPCs. 

Overall I have to say things feel unbalanced and very rough and somehow very small. The game forces you to play a certain way by limiting your access to mining equipment (which isn't too difficult to unlock, but it's all very very tedious and time sucking). Maybe I've been spoiled by other crafting/building type games. It's very limiting right now on the building/crafting/exploring/mining, and your main task is literally getting the things to actually build with, in an obtuse manner. And then babysitting your creations. 

After 20+ hours of investment I personally think that some amount of actual accomplishment is warranted, or just a lessening of the pain/stress. Maybe this game will change for the better, right now the core of it needs work. 

If you like Satisfactory you're going to be disappointed, look elsewhere. As the game is currently, I wouldn't buy full price. At the time of posting, it does look like the game is often updated and still getting things improved. Maybe by next year my review will change. Here's to hoping!

I had mistakenly read the word MULTIPLAYER in the official steam news, multiple times, and had thought it was LAN MULTIPLAYER. It was not. I was only in the game for 5 minutes. 5 MINUTES. Do not be confused by the confusingly worded "hours played" above. That is a random number. I was in the game for 5 MINUTES. I contacted steam for a refund but they refused, stating that I played the game for too long. Thus unfortunately, I must seek recompense. Yes, THIS DOES AFFECT MY GAMEPLAY! 
Devs / publishers: feel free to contact me if you want a refund.

This game has some serious potential but it's completely ruined by some oddball choices the designer made.  Let me be honest, not oddball, just flat out awful.

The game relies on this targeting dot that shows where you drop things/put things.  It's a tiny round shadow that is barely visible during the day, and completely invisible at night, which you will be in within 5 minutes of starting the game.  Not only that, it's offset to the right and way too close.  Your first experience in this game will be standing in the dark, barely able to see the bucket you're trying to put dirt in, dumping it on the ground to the right every time because you can't see the targeting dot.

It's a shame because it looks like there is a decent game here, but that offset/invisible targeting system is just flat out unacceptable.  Refunded.

An amazing game, with a very nice technical side to it. I personally love games where I can tweak on a system I've build just to increase efficiency, and Hydroneer lets me do just that! If you're the analytical type, you'll enjoy building your own little operation, this will be a wonderful game for you.

It has nice, intuitive controls, a refreshing take on item management (no inventory) and a fitting, kind-of-cozy art-style. Even the bugs you will encounter add to its charm/personality.


Once the multiplayer update drops, I'm confident I'll buy it for a friend or two just so I can play some more!


UPDATE: I am loving the small QoL updates (and the creative mode). Devs keep you updated, entertained and looking forward to the 2.0 update!

2.0 UPDATE: This gem of a game is still getting a lot of love from the developers! Great new additions, with another one coming soon (dec 9th). I look forward every time to come back with some new features or just to start a fresh new game and unwind!

Hydroneer is a medieval building game crossed with steampunk, to put it lightly. Your objective is to dig for iron, gold, gems, shards and cloutium to turn into jewelry, weapons and other sellables and make money out of it. This money is then spent on buying tools, machinery, vehicles, building materials, etc. to expand your operations.

[h1]Full Review[/h1]

You start off with nothing but a basic shovel, a brush and some pans for dirt and water: the classic gold digging method. You have to constantly shovel dirt in your pan, add water and scrub for the goodies. This is no way to make some good coin! So what do you do? You forge your found iron and gold into a sword and a ring and sell them at the jeweler in town. You bring a visit to the local equipment shop and buy a couple of pipes. You then install these pipes at the river so that you no longer have to scoop water into your pan: you can just put it under a tap. This allows you to scrub for resources much more quickly. 

Let this form of progress set the tone for the game: you constantly expand your operations with new machinery and improved logistics that make your base a little better each time, turning manual labour into machine works, allowing you to focus on more things. The equipment and machinery available is moderately rich in variety, such as automatic drills, conveyor belts, pipe systems, housing items, power and Logic (the game's electronics). Especially the latter, the power and Logic system, albeit simple, has quite an arrangement of powerful options that can both improve your current setup as well as build impressive new setups.

What's interesting about this game is that there's no inventory system. Everything (absolutely everything) has to be carried from A to B manually. Of course, you do have logistic tools to help you out in that such as tractors, pallets and carts, but you still have to load those by hand. This is both a breath of fresh air and a curse. It makes building your base and transporting more items to it feel more rewarding but at a certain point in time, especially when you have serious cash to flash, it can become tedious and feel like wasted time.

On items, because of the nature of the game, collision is an issue. Items that touch the world or other items in a weird way have the tendency to be shot away at high speed, glitch through objects or in other ways disappear. I've had several items fly away and I haven't yet found them back. This is especially frustrating when it happens to a valuable item (small tip: be careful with crafting battleaxes!).

One of the more major shortcomings of this game I find, is the exponential increase in your wealth. You start off incredibly poor, struggling even for basic items and equipment and having to do a lot of manual labour, and then suddenly the switch flips and you're a millionaire with a completely automatic digging, refining, sorting and smelting process to boot. After reaching that point of wealth (which comes sooner than you realize), the motivation to keep improving my base began to wane. You could argue that if you simply like the game, you'd keep building regardless of that, but for me personally I want to feel like what I do is worth it in the form of a reward, e.g. a really expensive piece of machinery or something else to look forward to, to [b]build[/b] towards.

The game's optimization has some issues when it comes to how long the game is running. It normally runs pretty smooth but every half hour till an hour, I find myself reloading the save because the FPS dropped to something like 30-40 FPS while I have a pretty powerful PC (that is with graphics set to low and resource saving to off). It's a mild nuisance.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]

For an eight euro game, this is a little gem, good for a couple dozen hours, if not more. The devs are active, their Discord server is helpful, mods are supported and more content is coming, multiplayer included! The game's content/price ratio is very good and the future looks promising. It has some flaws, but they're not game-breaking and will most likely be ironed out in the future.

If you like building games, especially in the style of Factorio and Satisfactory, this game will most likely strike your interests.

Hydroneer isn't a bad game by any means - it's got the bones of a good game and some fun mechanics to play around with, but it's sorely lacking content. At the time of writing this, there's plans for the "2.1 Update" which includes farming, but this I'm writing this from my own playtime experience.

Hydroneer is a novel little time that I got me a few good hours of entertainment, but darn if that novelty doesn't wear off quickly. It didn't take me long to graduate from "shovel dirt into a bucket and make it wet to get money" to "build some machines to pump out resources automatically." After that, the game feels more like a matter of upkeep, with that sparkling novelty chipping off as you grow your operation.

I made a basic setup with a machine for automatically pulling from the ground, which deposited the dirt into a machine that automatically refined that dirt into ore/gems, which spit it out into a machine that automatically sifted out the gold, and then a machine that automatically sifted out the iron, and deposited them both into their own buckets for smelting. Once I had my little setup operational, I realized that there wasn't a whole lot to be done. I'd used the mechanics to make an automated moneymaking farm and I would reap thousands of coins per hour with little worthwhile to spend it on.

The physics are too unpredictable for this game to feel good about upscaling, like Factorio, and there's not enough depth to the game to make building your fortune worthwhile. You can certainly spend hours getting a system to make you buckets of money much faster... and you can join me in an otherwise-empty world, without anything to spend your money on, and without anything to progress towads.

Like I said, it's got some good bones at it's core, but Hydroneer is desperately lacking depth in every aspect. It feels like a proof of concept rather than a game, but maybe I'm just asking too much from it.

It involves fun and creative ways to workaround issues introduced by the central conceit of having minimal UI, no inventory and everything being affected by (sometimes wonky) physics. The resulting gameplay is enticing and addictive but as is lacks a focus besides scaling up to bigger rigs and making more money. There is no tutorial atm so you have to figure it out by yourself or rely on lets plays youtubers. Recommended if you are not in a rush to get anything done.

I like the game, but it feels incomplete.  I know there were other items and things to do in the past that have been removed in order to streamline and better the gameplay, but now there's just not much to do once you get your drills setup.  There are a few easter eggs, but not much more in gameplay terms.  It should probably be in early access.  There are more things coming down the pipeline.  Farming and some other things are supposed to be coming later in the year.  Automation is tricky and very limited.  I don't mind the trickiness, I just wish there were more parts I could mess with and try to figure out more interesting things to do.  There are only two tiers of drills at this point, and only five products that you make, that you sell all in the same place, basically.  There's six plots of land to mine, 3 ore types, four gem types, and shards.  It's simple.  I wish there was something bigger that I was working toward.  Something that all the money I started bringing in with the drills would become useful toward.  More things to craft and expand upon.  Once your at tier 2 drills, that's basically the only thing you make, other one of the five products on occasion if you run low on money.  I guess what I'm saying is that I like the gameplay enough that I want more to do.  It's certainly worth grabbing and playing, especially at the price.  With new updates coming out regularly, there will be more to do.  I'm ready for it.

Controls and manipulating objects in game is very aggravating and frustrating.

When picking up items and objects you aim with the reticle in the center of the screen but when dropping an item or object you need to aim with the shadow of the object instead.  This makes doing anything in game down right impossible in low light areas or at night time.

Edit: You can change the default color of the shadow to be more visible but that still does not address the fact that you pickup and drop items in the world in two different places using the same key.

This game might be a little addictive, I purchased it 2 days ago at the time of this review, I like that steam mods have been properly incorporated and are accessible through the in game main menu.

Optimisation is decent, graphics are good, physics are a mere suggestion, which makes for some fun interactions with what would usually be an inanimate objects, especially when you get into automation and items decide to stack into a single spot for no reason in particular, simple application of magnet on a stick may reduce framerate a little in this situation.

I'm having fun with it, it's weird not having any kind of inventory and having to keep track of where you left all your tools and many piles of coins. 
My solution was to eventually just leave huge piles of coins at every stores purchase bucket.
As for the tools, I'm starting to just purchase lots of tool racks and lots of tools to just leave everywhere I'm going to use them.

Whilst I absolutely recommend this game, you may want to steer clear if you don't like the grind (and/or don't like to use mods that make things a bit easier and might make it feel like "cheating", the "golden pan" mod was a good way to get things started a little quicker and remove the early game grinding slog for me).

The physics starts as an amusing addition, however it quickly becomes a nuisance and gets in the way of the fun, the last 8 hours of trying to get to a point where this game is fun has involved:
 - Trying to tip stuff from one place to another and watching them scatter everywhere, involves picking things up individually
 - Trying to put stuff by hand in to a crucible and watching them scatter everywhere
 - Trying to pick things up using the magnet on a stick, a tool designed to solve a game problem of stuff scattering everywhere, then trying to drop them into something and watching them scatter everywhere
 - Trying to combine money by dropping them onto each other and watching one of the chunks of money bounce off the other chunk of money and roll down the hill
 - Trying to use the handsorter only to find that the outlets throw the resources at slightly different speeds so there's no easy way of catching them in a pan or crucible, so you end up doing the pick them up individually, or the magnet on a stick
 - The magnet on a stick being better at yanking things out of a container than putting them
 - Dropping stuff onto the anvil to do crafting and watching them bounce off, especially rubies (**** rubies)
 - Watching my funnels being only marginally better at putting materials where they have to be than simply having conveyors or machines launch them, which (as you guessed) involves picking up the material by hand

In addition it's plagued with a number of poor design decisions, beyond the terrible physics, progress is effectively measured using your bank balance, and almost everything in is acquirable by spending money, this leads to an interesting problem that to acquire nearly anything you are presented with 2 choices, build something of scale, spend a lot of time crafting, and therefore fighting with the games wonky systems, or not play the game and let it run in the background. Arguably the most effective way to play the game would be for you buy the tier 1 tools and simply conveyor everything into the back of a cart or truck and then come back 2 days later and sell it at the jewellers, so instead of tackling this poor design decision negative systems, such as the tools breaking exist, which prevents you from just letting the game run by itself, and therefore forcing you to be at the keyboard at all times, because if you're not your whole operation may just shut down.
The resources themselves are also utterly irrelevant beyond their financial value, while the game seems keen to encourage you to dig deeper it gives you not genuine incentive to do so, as the resources themselves don't mean anything except a financial value, so why would you bother, you will be able to buy that next item with every you can acquire from the surface, it may take a little longer, but it's not really a significant difference.

As a whole I really really wanted to love this game, it's exactly the sort of game I usually enjoy, problem is you spend so much time tidying up after the various machines and there isn't really any genuine progression within the game I've firmly bounced off it, which I find a little sad.

This game plays like an early access release of a game that has some promise, but isn't anywhere close to being complete yet. The world is empty and lifeless - no NPCs, no wildlife, only some seemingly abandoned buildings for the player to interact with. The island to play on is fairly small and limited compared to what you would expect from an open world game. There is no health, no survival mechanics of any kind, I dropped myself from a mountain to see what would happen, and the only thing that happened is I immediately got stuck behind a few boulders. Good thing there is the "unstuck" option in the menu.
The main mechanic of the game consists of a minimal interface without any inventory - you can only hold and use one item at a time and all items have to be stored and moved around by dropping them in the game world itself. This means that to fill a bucket with dirt and water and then "wash" the contents for valuables you are constantly shifting between items - always dropping something to pick up the next item that you need. While the fact that all items in the game are always physical objects in the game world is an interesting concept, the way it is implemented, only ever being able to hold one item at a time feels too constricting and too much like an annoying gimmick than really adding anything to the game. It's also a bit of an immersion breaker. Humans have two hands, and belts and backpacks are real things.
I'm sorry to say that I lost interest after just 20 minutes. But I see the game is in active development. I might check back later at some point to see if it has become more interesting.

as I play through I know I'm a masochist. To enjoy the slow, painful grind of the shovel and bucket to slowly get machines to automate... my roommate is worried about me, but he plays LOL so I don't care. but the satisfaction ends at some point.

See, I have to agree that it stops having sense and being rewarding. For me it was the moment of disappointment after of all that time, grind, and resources to set up  2 tier machinery  only to find out it is essentially not worth it. I would have thought that for all that hassle tier 2 machinery would at least break less frequently. And even further I made the mistake of thinking it would be awesome to prepare a new parcel, nuke excavated to the bottom, with enough pipe network to power hundreds of those 2 tier mofos BEFORE testing them... 

The dream of building  a very large factory with 50 miners to automate your richness, is completely shattered when you realize you'd be spending sooooo much time fixing machines getting broken. I didn't have that much of a big factory and I'd have to go grab a cart, buy 20 bags of repairing tools, toss them near the machines and go to other parcel, spend 17 minutes there knowing that in 14 minutes I'd have to go back and repair the machines that were funding the next project and then go away another 14 minutes.

God is just not worth it, I didn't even get to try to build a pretty house or a big castle, I was so frustrated.

Anyways, so far so good, I like the concept, I like the potential it has, I like the enjoyment of pouring 8000 ore of gold into one ring to sell it to the only person that would fit it (your mama) and hipefully the vehicles come back. I hated that the update that removed the vehicles kicked in ONE DAY before I was going to excavate the new dig site.

I give this game a 9/10. I absolutely love the mechanics of this game and how much it has progressed and developed as well. It has a very cartoon-like look combined with some realism and detail, kind of like the Borderlands games, or somewhat similar to how Roblox looks in some instances, but on steroids. I also like to think of this game as a very simplified version of Satisfactory too. I am looking forward to the upcoming farming update, but I am mostly excited for the new Gem Compressor machine. The main reason why is because I have noticed that when running the mining equipment for hours at a time and repairing the water filters every 20 minutes or so (I know I can buy logic wrench dispensers and logic durability detectors to remove the need to frequently repair, I just haven't been able to do so yet), gems will over time clog up between the end of the conveyor belt sorter and the edge of the Gem Compressor, greatly restricting and/or completely block the continuous flow of gems. I have dealt with this issue in the past by using the magnet on a stick to drag all the clogged gems into the compressor (My current starter location setup has one compressor for each gem type), however, there is normally so many gems that the game will lag big time for a few seconds when moving all of the freed gems. Not only that, only a portion of the gems make it to the compressor and the rest splash everywhere in all directions. It ends up being a big mess to clean up every time, but it's worth it. I really hope this will be resolved with the new Gem Compressor, but in the meantime I will try adding a straight conveyor between each conveyor sorter and Gem Compressor and metal/tin sheets around each Gem Compressor and see if that helps with my personal issue. I am also hoping that once the Tier 3 Update comes out, there will be a Tier 3 Drill, Harvester, and Tier 3 tools as well at the very least. Last but not least, I have a suggestion for the developers out there that I would like to be at least heard or considered since other players may or may not want this to be a feature in the game as well. If this hasn't been done already, *PLEASE* tweak or add an additional option in multiplayer capability that allows players to have "true" cooperative online multiplayer. This means please somehow make it possible for players to play this game with 1 or more friends without being forced to have split screen on both ends and have 1 player only able to use a keyboard and the other player only able to use a controller. It would be *AMAZING* if two or more people could play this game together online, have the whole screen visible for all players, and have more than 1 player able to use a keyboard or controller. When I bought this game, I also bought it for a few of my friends, thinking this would already be implemented since there was a Cooperative Play Icon and Multiplayer Icon on the game's page in the Steam Library. This was not the case when my friends and I tried playing this together. I know that this is wishful thinking, but if this could be a reality by at least Update 2.5 or sooner, that would be awesome. Additional music/more songs in the game would be great as well, but I'm not as worried about that being added or considered.

I absolutely love this game. I've introduced it to a good few of my friends and they've had varied reactions to it, seemingly based on their temperaments as gamers. Mostly their reactions are positive, but I think their outlook highlights something for me: just like with a lot of things, this game isn't for everyone.
Hydroneer is great to me, because I enjoy slow and very involved progression. It gives me something to focus on and look forward to. In the best way it is something I can get lost in and enjoy being a part of. You place every component that is a part of your mining equipment and every wall or floor that is a part of your base. If you're not playing in creative mode then you will also be saving up money you've earned to buy those pieces as well. 
Sometimes the 'survival' mode can be a little tedious, but that is why I reached a point of pride and accomplishment in that mode and then moved to a creative world to enjoy the building aspect even more.
I don't usually write reviews for games. However, I feel compelled to do it in this case, because I feel there is something great here. I think the team behind this game is doing an excellent job and they are really involved and care for this. It deserves to be recognized. The game may not be for everyone, but it's great to me

After a few patches this could easily become a great game

Positives:
* core game loop is fun / concept is good
* coop
* relatively bug free

Questionable:
Theme - it's ok but not used well. Why arn't i dwarven? I could easily have some goals for setting up a new dwarven underground mining town, checkpoints/achievements based on how big it is or something. 

Start of game:
* could really use an in game tutorial

getting the hang of it:
* quite good, construction components, game functions well

mid:
* the game has a 'tier 2' that is functionally the same as tier 1.. doesnt serve much purpose except to be more expensive, this doesnt matter though, because you earn so much from the previous level that the cost of all items is irrelevant (poorly balanced progression)

* progressing to a second plot is unneccessary because you already have all the money you need

* money has no purpose except for purchasing more machines and vanity items

* a lot of the game is spent fetching items from stores. the whole game is physical, so not sure how this will get fixed. (carrying money around is even a pain)

* digging becomes a chore since there's only hand tools or explosives, no real progression here that works nicely

Motivation and Drive:
* the game runs dry quickly because there's no purpose. you're not doing missions, your not trying to get money for some purpose etc etc. Until this is changed, i don't see it being considered a good construction game.

I’ve played complex games, complicated games, simple games, difficult games, and everything in between.

Hydroneer is vague and pointless. And I’ve played Minecraft. 

The developer had the great humor to put one of your starting tools not with the others, leaving you stuck scratching your head until you get lucky and stumble across it or watch the ‘tutorial’ - a YouTube video. Not even a few popup boxes and in-game arrows, no, you’re just sent to YouTube.

After that, you are given no more information beyond vague and unhelpful item descriptions. Figuring out how things work isn’t overly difficult, just tedious.

Speaking of tedious, let’s talk about gameplay. Grab the shovel and dig a chunk of dirt, put it in the pan. Drop the shovel and pick up the pan. Put the pan in the water- actually drop it, not use it, or you will dump out the dirt. Pick up the brush, use the brush on the pan. Drop the brush, pick up whatever nugget you got out of the pan, put it in either the bucket or the wagon. Repeat about 150 times to get the chance to figure out how to assemble the automation machines.

And what are you doing all this for? Nothing. There is no goal. With Factorio, you’re trying to leave. With Satisfactory, you’re trying to complete the tiers. Dyson Sphere Project has you trying to build the ritual Dyson Sphere. Hydroneer has no goal. Do work, get paid, do more work.

Maybe in 5 years it will be worth the time to play it. Not right now.

The game is fairly decent for what it is, but you very quickly run out of things to do.

The "no ui" approach to the design is a bit quircky but the end result is that it feels like a port of a VR title and it generally makes simple tasks kinda tedious once the initial novelty has worn off.

The main objective of the game is to mine materials out of the ground and sell them to buy equipment to mine more materials. The trouble is that after the initial hurdle of earning eanough money for the 2 machines you need to automated mining you very quickly end up in a situation where there isnt really anything more to work toward. Basic automation very quickly gives you eanough cash flow to buy whatever you want, but there really isnt any next goal to work toward other than just building more miners to get more money to... well hoard in a corner somewhere i suppose.

Found this game through a YT'er. I'll start by saying I have 6.2 hours in the game.

This game is great! That 6.2 hours is from my first session alone. It takes a lot to keep me entertained for that time. At it's present form it's very good. There is a LOT missing and it shows, but you're not penalized for it in game. Everything that's available can be used and I've seen no slow down in play because of what it's lacking at this point. 

It's a very empty world with an eerie feel to it because you feel the isolation when in the town areas. Most of the city areas are unusable and don't have anything to interact with at present however everything you need at the moment is available at the starting area. 

The fishing is also clunky as hell. Casting is pretty cool but the bobber dipping for a bit is clunkish and reeling in is just an instant click. there's no fight to it, no reel animation. It just a click and the rod flicks then a fish drops in front of you.

With all that being said, I highly recommend this game. For $10 you're definitely not getting hurt. In it's present form I wouldn't pay any more than $15 if the price raises at any point however I'd assume if the price increases then there's probably a good update. Get it, you'll love it!

Hydroneer is a game about solving annoyances, but bears a central problem: its annoyances cannot be solved.  The gameplay is about learning to understand the wonky controls and physics, the basic loop of both panning and crafting materials, and why fishing is for some reason ludicrously better on rate than doing any of that (seriously, it's wild how much more you can make fishing versus engaging the game where its at).  I held off on the fishing because, well, that's boring as hell, did not wiki, and found the economy and discovery of the game to be slow but tolerable.

After you get in the hang of the repetitive motions of Hydroneers manual labor you can start scraping by enough money to start making things.  The things are all for making things less annoying.  Lights and camp beds so you can start to get a handle on how long and unpleasant the nights are, pickaxes to make digging less miserable, granite blocks to undo the mess you made digging, and water pipes so you don't have to toss your bucket into the river, crafting items to make your cart rides less frequent as you improve the quality per density of your pile of items.   Eventually you will have enough quality advantages to make enough money to start purchasing automation through water piping and, assumably, end your troubles so you can start having a little fun exploring the post game.

But here's the thing: there is no such thing as total automation.  Products can only get to the ore stage off of treadmills and still have to be manually smelted into their end state amulets or swords (or, more likely, sold in a messy pile of unfinished ore).  Machines break without filtered water, and water filters break over time (rapidly, from what i've seen) for no reason other than that they're water filters.  Which means that regardless of what you do, you will have to load carts full of material to sell to the merchants to purchase disposable tool bags to manually repair machines that you assembled to stop from having to do a job.  And that's a job.

I feel like the end goal of automation games in general is to get to a state where you can stop working on one thing and start playing around with another, until there's nothing left or you feel inclined to walk away.  In this game, the end state is that you have enough money that you don't have to pay attention to the awful machines you've built and can let them fall to ruin around you until you run out of money again.  That's not a good feel.  

Hydroneer feels *different*, which I applaud in any game, but it also feels tedious and unrewarding.  At a glance I'd say it needs faster loops, more engagement with the automation, and more balanced and varied routes to wealth.  There's a lot of repetitive action here for no good reason, and while solving some of the games obtuseness is a reasonable puzzle, it's not a strong enough experience that I'd give it a full recommend.

An interesting take on the mining and automation process of mining. Similar to Satisfactory your end goal is to mostly if not fully automate the process, but unlike Satisfactory you aim isn't to produce more and more advanced machinery. Instead you are aiming to gather Gold, Iron, and various Gems to refine and sell to eventually own the entire mining community and be able to build what ever you please. Of course you are not limited to this goal and can instead go on side tangents for your own amusement. For a good example of this I suggest looking up Lets Game It Out on Youtube and watching his video gameplay's as he does many things, but mining is rarely one of them.

Over all, if you like the freedom of choice and a vague overall goal this game is for you. The graphics might be a bit weird at first, but you'll get used to them quickly enough and they actually give the game quite a bit of charm.

I first saw this game about two years ago on YouTube and instantly fell in love with the idea and immediately bought a copy and haven't looked back since. I've bought/invested in a bunch of smaller indie games over the years and Hydroneer is by far one of the most fun and technically best investment I made. The dedication Max and many of the active members of the community to make this game truly an amazing gaming experience is really inspiring.  It is definitely not easy to make an enjoyable experience when there's no obvious inventory mechanic in the game, however, Max being the ingenuitive developer he is has shown us that it is possible to spin what would otherwise be seen as annoying from a game-design perspective into a pretty simple (and even relaxing) system.

Honestly, I cannot wait to see what amazing stuff Max, the community developpers/contributors, as well as the modding community have in store for this game in the future! Definitely a game you should at the bare minimum try. I can can assure you that you'll lose track of time and spend hours playing and enjoying the game without even realizing!

This game is a lot like a more medieval version of Gold Rush (though it still has vehicles?). But it also has what I feel is a more in-depth mining mechanic, as well as the ability to almost fully automate the mining and processing aspect.
Start out small, filling buckets with dirt and washing them out with the pan and brush to obtain lumps of iron, gold, gems and power shards (more on those later). Sell the ores and gems for coins which you can use to buy better equipment. Such as a forge, crucible and ingot cast to melt the ores down into bars which are easier to manage. Or invest in a grindstone to cut and polish your gems, increasing their value. Or combine it all with an anvil and hammer, creating weapons and jewelry to sell.
Once you get tired of manually digging all the dirt, start investing in drills, processors and semi-automated crucibles. All powered by water. But be careful, if you don't filter the water, it will damage the machines quickly. Is the machinery going too slow? Not enough water pressure? That's where the power shards come in. Use them to power pressure tanks to keep your water pressure high.
There are also several tiers of mining machines, each tier being faster and more efficient. Once you have completely mined out the first area, you can even buy other mining locations to increase your profits.
Bored of mining? Go buy a fishing rod and fish any of the multiple streams or even the main river. If you catch special fish, you can even obtain higher tier fishing rods.
Even though it's a relatively small indie developer (The initial game was made by one guy), they are constantly updating and adding new content. Highly recommended, 10/10 iron pipes.
P.S. Really excited to try out the new 2.1 Farming Update.

I both loved and hated parts of this game.

Progression based factory games have always been a love of mine since before they were even a genre (to my knowledge first thing that comes close is minecraft redstone automations).

What starts off as a tedious manual operation quickly evolves into large scale production facilities which can and will bog a computer down when done inefficiently. It has some optimization problems, especially when carting around large quantities of building materials in a truck but the game is still relatively new and devs are obviously very actively working towards making the game better all the time.

Where things fall off for me (and this is my problem, less about game design) is my ability to figure out how the logic circuits work. I've tried on several occasions to figure it out but I just can't get a timer/stop start function to work with it. Like i said though , this is way more to due with my ability to understand the system in place and less about the games options to make it happen. I know that it's possible because I've seen videos proving it but I am just not smart (or familiar) enough to figure out how to do it myself.

Either way I hope they expand the logic system options to make them more ... umm, stupid person friendly :P But I'll still play it again when tier 3 equipment is eventually unlocked too. I would love it if the multi-player wasn't a split screen, I don't know if that's always going to be like that or if it's just a stop-gap until true multi-player is added. I hope it's the ladder since there are people I'd love to play this with but they won't because it's not how they want to play.

The concept is great, the idea of having no internal inventory is an interesting concept and while it can be tedious it makes for an interesting game mechanic to work around in my opinion. I say that but I'm also hoping for some kind of delivery system to get added for tier 3 as an endgame system.

GET IT NOW
I really like this game but getting started is a grid and lots of the game is waiting for more resources to progress.

- 0-5 minutes in, wandering around a random dirt patch wondering what the heck I'm supposed to do.
- I go back to the main menu, see a tutorial button, and click it; a youtube video opens in my browser. Thankfully I have a second monitor to notice it. Watch the first minute or so to figure out any shred of context possible.
- Finally find the shovel and bumble around with my controller for a bit until I figure out the controls. I start putting dirt in the cart, thinking that's what it's for. Watch more of the tutorial, realize it goes in bucket. Try putting multiple dirt piles in bucket, can't do that. Eventually I figure out the process going back and fourth.
- After about 25 minutes I get a bunch of ore and gems and such, in the most tedious back and fourth process of dropping and picking up items possible. I thankfully noticed a map and try to orient myself, and go to somewhere that I guess is a shop according to the map? (if there were any signs or markers I didn't see any) I see a bucket in front of a building on the ground with a big sign a few feet over it that says SELL in big capital letters with a bright red button under it. It's getting dark out ("why is there a daynight cycle?"), but I can just barely see the gems I picked up. I put them in the bucket on the ground. I repeatedly press X on the button. Nothing happens. I look at the video again. Apparently I was supposed to put them in my OWN bucket on the TABLE a few feet next to the sign that is over the bucket on the ground.
- I run all the way back, pick up my bucket, and move the ore into my own bucket on the table. The sign has a little # indicator that changes to 65. I press X repeatedly on my controller on the red button. Still nothing happens. I try clicking my mouse. It works. I wonder for a moment, try one more ore piece, and try my right trigger. It works. Every other interaction so far had used the X button, but now suddenly I use the right trigger?
That was the point I quit the game. Saw the top comment on Youtube asking for in-game tutorials rather than a video, saw some top recent reviews also mentioning confusion, and realized that the rest of the game was probably going to be the same ongoing struggle to figure out how to do anything.

In UX/HCC terms, minimalism does not mean having little to no UI elements with little to no guidance for the player. It means putting the least cognitive/memory load on the user so that they can figure things out as swiftly and painlessly as possible. Slapping a video on Youtube that assumes default keyboard controls so you can have a "minimalist" UI and drop the player into a random world with no context or anything definitely favors the former rather than the latter. For example, when Satisfactory drops you into the world (literally), a voice gives you some basic tutorial-esque "objectives. You don't necessarily have to do them right away, as they are moreso to teach you the main mechanics. As you progress, they go away. (Also, hovering over interactable objects shows the buttons you need to press, 100% of the time) It's not too hand-holdy, but it still gives you context to your surroundings and introduces you to the basic game loop and game progression, and leaves you to discover more advanced mechanics on your own.
If this game really rethought its onboarding process and had more helpful tooltips (i.e. ones that explained item usage in better detail with the player's set input for it and was in proximity to the item rather than shoved in a small text box in the lower left corner), I'd consider it again. But as is, I just do not have the time nor patience to sift through guides and videos to learn basic mechanics. I apologize for how lengthy this is but I felt context is key here. I'm sure there's probably a mechanically sound game in here, especially if you learn well from and have time for player guides and videos. But oof.

This game is the king of making busywork seem fun, and it shows. There are sound reasons why builder games like this have inventories, concise UIs, aim to reduce idle cycles. Hydroneer has none of these. I had to carry a lot of stuff back and forth because of the lack of inventory and the challenges of operating the vehicles (when I don't clip against a fence or a goddamn lamppost).

My high point came when I decided to dig a pipe to an underwater aquifer, and the fact it took several days and the end result was a shitty flow of pressure shows that there are reasons consolations are made for a lot of games like this. We have no lift stations to maximize pressure, the process involves the worst excesses of constant traversal, and I stopped having fun long ago.

Also, the environment is pretty samey. See, a lot of the areas in the map are copy pasted, whole ridges, forests, so its kind of confusing. I think this game is giving me a legitimate panic attack.

Solid pass.

Love the game. Similar to satisfactory and Factorio.
But I feel the game isn't finished yet. Stuff that is in place works well, but it really misses a tutorial where it tells you how to do some basic things (fueling the car, selling items, digging (I spent hours with a shovel just to find out the pickaxe is so much more effective without having to move dirt around!!) tier 1/2 items and what the difference is, safes for items without there being anyone to steal it, etc). Part of the fun was just roaming around and figuring this stuff though. The world is empty and feels empty, you're there by yourself and alone, some random stores and homes, but nobody there.

Then some bugs. Most prominent: Resources can get stuck. Especially when the "dirt to resource" - machine breaks down. Dirt piles up in front of it and gets stuck. If you don't pay attention this builds up, turning the FPS to a crawl. Using the magnet on a stick on this pile gets it loose, but the game will freeze for a while. Anyhow, this happens too wit gold/iron, seems to randomly get stuck (splitter belt -> funnel). The "remove all unprocessed resources" button fixes this too, but it just seems wasteful, especially early game.
And then later game (20+ hours) it turns out there is nothing to dig tier 3, so don't waste time nuking the place like I did...

Looking past these few things, it is an amazing game that got me hooked just like satisfactory and factorio were able to do.  What I like better than satisfactory is that it is so simple, just a few machines that do it all, nothing complicated. Simply dig, smelt, sell, buy more stuff to dig and build more.

I am really surprised I put forty-six hours into this, at the time I'm reviewing it. It didn't feel that way. The game starts off slow, I abandoned panning for gold as soon as I could afford a fishing rod and that really helped. Fishing made me enough money to automate my claim. And that is where the fun of the game started, designing your operation and figuring out what works and what doesn't, trying to figure out why something doesn't work. The first time I tried to use logic to automatically repair a filter, it just emptied all the spanners I'd loaded the machine with because I needed a logic flip thingy. Honestly, if I were the dev I might really lower the price of the starting automated drill and harvester, the panning for gold might teach you some elements of the game, but it doesn't feel like the game really starts until planning out where to put your machines and how to connect them.

Version of writing: 2.0.8

I like the look of the game, the artstyle fits perfectly and I like the "low poly" look, though the only gripe I have in regards to that is the terrain, it's too smooth.

And I like how there is a natural flow of progression; panning for nuggets then smelting/refining them for more value, then automating the mining before eventually automating everything with enough time spent at each "stage", at least at this stage of the game. (note: I think power shards should be slightly rarer)

I do have some suggestions in regards to pacing in some areas.
1. The amount of power shards needed in pressure tanks should increase depending on how far from the pump it is, maybe with the minimum value being bigger than one.

2. Thee cost of each miner and harvester you get should increase to avoid making it exponentially easier to get more after the first forging.
2.1 Maybe as an alternative, or as well as, the forge itself could have an "efficiency" modifier starting at 100%, decreasing each forge.
To top this number back up you would have to provide resources to the forge itself, not a set value maybe, but what you need could depend on how far from 100%, with each repair increasing thee cost by a percentage, maybe an extra 10% per repair. (Example, the first repair would need 100% resources, say 10 iron for 10%, then after 10 repairs the cost is 200%, so 20 iron for 10% etc etc)

3. As I said above, to me there seems to bee a natural progression, so maybe the game progression could be centered around that?
I'm thinking you only have the castle and jewellers next to Ember Cradle at first and fund/unlock smelting/cutting there.
Then the shop down the hill opens (after funding someone who wants your help setting up shop, maybe with both money and materials) and you have access to *some* of what you can currently get at first. (maybe have a hand operated waterpump and hand filter?)

4. Power shards are only useful once you got machinery, so maybe you have to find a way to research the properties of power shards to unlock items that use them. (and maybe more items should use them, maybe as a sort of fuel?)

5. I think weight should play a bigger part in how you handle and carry items. IE 
I do have suggestions for thee controls as well.
1. The pick up/put down actions should be a short press of thee E key.
2. Using items should be changed to have a long press of the left mouse button, (this includes entering/exiting the use of all vehicles)
3. Buckets and pans should have an alt action: Right click should scoop water or items up
4. Ditch the tank controls of handcarts, please.

Pro:
 - Nice Devs! Thanks Grandma Max for this game!
 - Good Pricing and no ****** microtransactions (and all the other stuff straight from marketing-hell)
 - Good Update-Behaviour with really well-written updates - not only new stuff, but also improving old Stuff and refactoring Code for better performance
 - easy building-system
 - Workshop with mods!

Con:
 - you can easily get a small Mining-Operation which gets you a million Hydrocoins or more in less than half an hour - after that, you can buy everything
 - Tier2-Drills are worthless at the current state - you can easily build a huge Tier1-Drill-Operation which is 10 times cheaper and has a higher Coins-for-Value-Ratio - so it's not worth upgrading
 - Difference between different Mining-Spots doesn't feel great - you build a small Mining-Sorting-Rig in your first, wait a bit and sell just the bars for enough money to buy the biggest and priciest spot on the map


Neutral:
 - House-Building: don't know, because never used ist - there is no reason to build a house and after building a medium-sized-Mining-Operation you can buy everything you want and it feels like cheating
