Expect absolutely no help from no one. Save from a (self-named) "Short-video tutorial", you have no NPCs, no signs, no in-game helpers. I get that this is supposed to keep the immersion, but note to the developers: a barely-better-than-minecraft-graphic-set is NOT immersive. It's FRUSTRATING. 

Grind. A lot.
 Every action in this game requires a ton of repeating, boring, non intuitive, barely controllable-moves.
You first order of the game is to sell stuff, so you can upgrade your material. How? 
First: Search for the shovel. It's THERE, next to the lamppost, outside your view. Found it? Great. 
Follow these steps:
Pick it up (press E). Dig (click), face the bucket (mouse), drop in the bucket (click),  face the dirt (mouse), repeat. Three times. 
Now, pick the bucket (E. not click), empty it's contents in the pan (click). Oh, did you miss that? Is it because the pointer that marks where it drops is different from the mouse marker? Too bad. Pick the dirt up, place it (click) in the pan. You remembered to fill it with water before all that, right? 

... RIght, After you did all that, and went to the unmarked town, and found out it had no signs of the JEWELRY you were supposed to sell your two ores to (yeah, three buckets for two ores. Horray), go to the next town, and sell your hard, back breaking work for... 34 units of currency. Which gives you  enough money to... nothing, really. Carry on.

To summarize: Controls are non intuitive, the grinding is repetitive and exhausting.

Its a good game to kill time, missing some life to the game maybe some story quests or NPCs at the stores to make it more interesting. Overall, the art design is great, the mechanics are simple but not difficult to get used to.

This is a really cool addition to the genre. A lot of the other indie games like this feel like they are running on the same engine, with the same awkward issues. This game really feels more at home in its engine, like things work well.

Something about placement just seems much more smooth than other 3D building games. A big part of that is that the game is much closer to doing placement correctly than most. The only non frustrating way to place objects in 3D is for them to float at a fixed distance from the player, and to be able to adjust that distance by scrolling as you are placing. This game at least does the first part instead of the common, and incredibly painful to use, snap to ground.

One of my favourite bits is the lack of inventory. It feels sort of awkward at first, but having to stack stuff to move it around never stops being amusing. Plus the way containers have sticky surfaces that pick up objects in contact with them just feels really smooth. In general moving items around feels like a game, rather than a chore.

Also it is incredible how much less frustrating it is to build things when you can do a bit of terraforming. Like in satisfactory I would build huge ugly platforms in the sky so that my buildings didn't clip into the ground all the time.

[h1]Suggestions[/h1]

The game does have some cons though, it is a bit unfinished feeling and there are some fairly big problems, especially with the in game economy, that may frustrate you for a bit.
[list]
  [*] Being able to stack materials into bars infinitely trivialises factory design. I can just separate the resources into their own smelters and then just sit around and wait for them to build up. If the bars had a max size I would have to build something much more complex and interesting to handle them.
  [*] The game doesn't have great money sinks. Once you have 10 or so level one drills going you are going to struggle to spend money faster than you are making it. However you will still be struggling to get enough materials for the level 2 drills. For example the land plots could all be 10-100x their current prices without issue.
  [*] The currently available upgrades could be more significant. It is disappointing that the level 2 pickaxe isn't even better, it can just dig deeper. Similarly the level 2 drills don't seem to produce enough more stuff to justify the expense(and don't produce any new resources).
  [*] The stock market isn't worth the effort if I'm only going to get 15% more. I would say that a 50% gain is probably the floor for what I would drive around in search of.
  [*] The player character could move faster. Given that there is already a mechanic where when moving more items you generally move slower, increasing sprint speed a bunch would have few balance consequences and make the game more enjoyable.
  [*] Non-diggable terrain could be more obvious. Right now it is very visually similar to the level one terrain so it is easy to not notice until it is too late.
  [*] The magnet on a stick would be much less frustrating to use if it behaved more like a real magnet and attraction dropped off with 1/d^2 like a real magnet. Currently when I try to use it to fix clogs it makes a mess of the surrounding area. Hopefully such a change would mean that at the point where moving too quickly causes items to be dropped, they would still be on screen rather than trailing a bit outside of it.
  [*] The roof on the conveyor shop is infuriating when I'm trying to stack items for purchase. As if you jump you can't drop items because they are clipped through the roof.
  [*] Falling through the grate next to the masterwork anvil feels like a bug.
  [*] With the way the cars handle being able to drift with the handbrake would be a lot of fun. Already every once in a while I manage to bounce in a sharp turn and it loses traction and does a sort of drift and it feels great.
[/list]

It feels like the controls were designed to make everything more laborious than needed, and it's not fun. It's decidedly awful.

Here's the basic initial loop for getting resources:
1) Press 'E' to pick up the shovel
2) Left-click on dirt to fill the shovel
3) Left-click on the bucket to fill 1/4 of the bucket
4) Repeat 4 times to fill the bucket
5) Press 'E' to drop the shovel
6) Press 'E' to pick up the bucket
7) Carefully position the bucket over the pan
8) Left-click to dump the bucket into the pan
9) Press 'E' to drop the bucket
10) Press 'E' to grab the brush
11) Left-click on the pan to clean the dirt

You now have a few pieces of iron, gold, or a shard.

You can only carry one item, because there's no inventory system.
To move multiple items you have to pick each one up separately, and plunk it in a pan. 

So to earn ~300 units of money, you have to repeat that whole tedious process a number of times.  

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

But, it gets better. You're only able to do that after a figuring out awkward interactions that aren't explained. For example...

To put water in a pan, you fill a bucket. To fill a bucket you don't click on the water with the bucket, you have to physically submerge the bucket by throwing it in, or submerge yourself while holding it. And then you don't click on the pan with the bucket of water, you have to pour the water in. 

But then when filling a bucket with dirt, you click on the dirt with the shovel to fill the shovel, then click on the bucket to fill the bucket with dirt. You don't pour it in. But then you do pour the bucket of dirt into the pan.

So, initially, you're constantly confusing the controls because similar actions require different input, and it's never explained, and doesn't make much sense anyway.

Most of your initial time is adjusting to a control scheme that seems to have been defined to purposefully defy modern control schemes that were developed by years of figuring out what made the most sense.  

As you do it, you have to constantly strafe and turn to look around and make minor adjustments and find small dropped things or re-mine or re-water, and it even started to make me physically sick because it's so unnecessarily repetitive.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

So, stop and think "Why did I just read all that? It's so dumb."
It is. It is dumb. It's poorly designed. And just...not fun. It's so bad it's hard to explain. And your motivation in the game is not "Hey, this is fun!", it's "Ugh, I hope I can make this less awful."  

Well, you can, by refunding it, and playing any of the many, many, many, great simulation / mining games that already exist.

Hydroneer is a sandbox mining game, a very impressive effort for a single indie dev. It feels rough around the edges, but can be quite immersive and relaxing. You start out with a shovel and a pan, then move up to building an automated system all running on hydro power. It's worth trying if you like those kinds of games, although you'll need to be a bit forgiving. It's a very slow start and there's no inventory system, including for money - which means you have to pick up and move everything by hand, and you can't carry your money and the thing you just bought at the same time. If you do put a few hours into it, it's satisfying to see automation coming together, but there's no end game.

[b]Pros[/b]
- Relaxing background music
- Satisfying mining, once you get the hang of it
- Landscaping system
- Robust 3D building system (minus the bug mentioned below)
- Conveyor/automated mining systems
- The minimalist interface is annoying, but it is immersive and unusual

[b]Cons[/b]
- Going to town to buy things is tedious. Especially given that you have to pick up each item drop it in the cart, pay for it, pick it up, drop it in the truck, drive home, pick it up, carry the item and place them all individually.
- I was hoping to discover that there were multiple kinds of ores (other than just iron and gold), or new things you could create and sell. Unfortunately it looks like everything you find in the first digging area is everything in the game. New shops don't open, no new items to build.
- I really get the feeling that it should be made for VR - it would be perfect with the whole "no inventory" system and simplistic art style. Unfortunately not.
- Even once I got flat concrete surfaces, items often fall over instead of standing upright when you drop them
- No in-game tutorial or intro. There's a 3 minute video - but other than that you're entirely on your own
- No achievements, which might have given some goals for what to do
- It's kinda weird that everything in the game looks medieval, but you start with a modern day diesel truck. It would have been better to stick with just the wooden cart
- The towns feel really empty with no people in them. Buildings are closed. Who am I selling this stuff to? Even if there were just NPC models that didn't talk, it'd help make it feel more alive
- No inventory system at all. It's a nice idea in principle, and it does add a sense of immersion, but it becomes annoying really quickly. For example, you have no pockets so you have to carry your coin stack in your hands. You also can't pick up more than one object at a time.
- I built a water pipe system, and no water came out the end. I removed and re-built each piece one by one, then it worked. Makes me think the underlying systems are rather buggy

Hydroneer is an unusual game, even for the sandbox genre. But it is a really good game. In Hydroneer you play as a gold miner. There is no defined goal what to do and you can play the game at your pace and the way you want.
The general gameplay revolves around mining ore and gems and selling the result to the local jeweler. You do this by shoveling dirt from a land plot into a bucket, emptying the bucket into a washing pan and then adding water to the washing pan so you can brush the ore free from dirt.
The deeper you dig, the more valuable the result you get. There are mutliple types of ores you can find, basic iron ore which is the most common, gold ore, which is precious and worth a lot of money, energy shards, which can be used to power machines and several types of gems that are extremely valuable but also rare. There is also cloutium, which is more worth than gold but a lot more rare and is also used for some crafting recipes.

There is no limit on how much ore you can collect but eventually your framerate will suffer if you fill your pan too much. A common trait of the pan (and most items that serve as inventory space) is that objects "stick" to it unless you empty it with a command, which means you don't have to fear that your ressources fly out, even if the pan or the bucket would turn over. This is especially helpful since there is no traditional inventory in the game, so you cannot shove the ore in your pocket or something like that. 
The game aims for a more immersive type of gameplay, no inventory and all objetcs in the game interact directly with the game world. This makes the game somewhat fiddly to play, you have to pick up items one at a time, sort your ore by hand and cannot hold more than one object at the time. Once you get used to it, you won't mind it however.
Since all the objects are interactable inside the game world as they are, you can use buckets and pans or literally anything you find as makeshift containers. Some items are designed to work as inventory and allow you to put infinite amounts of stuff into them. 
After selling a good amount of ore at the jeweler you can use the money (which, again, you have to pick up manually, no pockets for that either) to buy additional equipment. A good investment early is to buy a furnace, a crucible and a mold. With these three items you can start smelting your ore and create ingots which are worth more money and on a plus side, also easier to carry.
There is no limit how much ore you can smelt into a single bar and the more ore you use, the bigger the ingot you get. The value of an iron bar is usally that of the used ore plus a bonus. 
But instead of selling your bars you can also craft them into equipment, which is worth even more money. But for that you need to buy an anvil and a forge hammer.
Step by step you build up a basic equipment and create more expensive products for selling. From gold and gems you can create expensive jewelry. Gems come in different tiers and differ in value with onyx being the most expensive.

At some point you want to invest into automated mining because that constant digging and brushing takes too much time and is not much fun in the long run. This is where machines come into play. You can buy harvesters, convesers and drills. Drills dig out dirt for you, harvesters convert dirt into resources while conveyours are simply used to transport stuff between those two. You can also buy sorters that will sort your resources for you.
With a good automated setup you can soon roll in money. However, if you want to get really deep into automating, you have to craft those machines yourself. You get only a limited selection of what you can buy, the best stuff is aviable at Helheim, a big underground forge. There you can use your iron bars for crafting more machines and if you use cloutium, you get really good equipment.

One thing I didn't mention before is how power works in this game. The name "Hydroneer" was chosen for a reason, the game uses a water based power system. To use machines you need to build a pump and then connect the pump with pipes to your machines. Every machine in this game needs water and even your car uses water as fuel. You can further boost power with energy shards or smelt those into bars for even more power output.

Besides mining there is also fishing and the developers announced they will also introduce farming to the game at some point. The main gameplay will however always be the mining and it clearly is the best part of the game.

I reviewed this before saying this was a great game without bugs but I'm changing that answer after having more than a couple of weeks to play this game. And I'm not gonna sugar coat it, here's my raw feelings on this game:

When I first started playing this game I was impressed by the mechanics and how picking up and dropping things was really unique and pretty flawless in comparison to other games with similar abilities (like skyrim for example, oof).

It felt like a pretty straight forward game: mine to sell to buy to mine more to sell more to buy more and repeat. That seemed relaxing and enjoyable to play. The setting sun and having to use external light sources to see at night was about the only real struggle or danger the game possessed. It was a game I could see myself getting hyper focused on and lost on for hours. I liked the simplicity...

And then I realized that simplicity was in fact boring and machines can make more money more quickly than I can without actually losing dirt. And that lead me down a rabbit hole of trying to do the best too quickly and thanks to Reddit and some YouTuber I was able to come up with a pretty elaborate design on the first dig site within a week of playing this game.

However learning that came with the realization how terrible this game can actually be and what more struggles lied ahead. That wouldn't be such a downfall if it was just *learning* how the game and each item in the game works. I mean, that's the fun part! Instead it was "how to avoid this bug and that glitch and why tf is my game lagging all of a sudden??" *Exasperated sigh*

That's not fun. Trying to avoid bugs and glitches and telling the game to delete every resource/dirt block to avoid lagging is stressful and not that intriguing. While also wondering why some setups work, exactly how the description says, and some don't even if it makes sense to. Even Reddit is dumbfounded at some of the contraptions that work and don't work. Some things work in ways you'd think they wouldn't or shouldn't work. It's complicated for a pretty simple game. Too many things in a movable item, like a pan, bucket, the wagon, or truck, makes the game lag too and the truck freak out when you try to drive it.

However, I gotta give this game some points. Its a cheap game made by a very small team of six people- like that's impressive. And to run as smooth as it does, even with all the bugs... it's a hard game not to like. I just wish they would fix some things and add some items that are better than their precursor (like better water filters). And maybe add an interactive tutorial instead of a guy in a youtube video? That'd be nice. Also the remove all raw resources and dirt blocks have helped me tremendously on more than a couple occasions. So at least they're aware of that problem.

As much as this game annoys the ever living shit outta me, I don't hate this game and would still give it a recommendation. I think I got my $10 worth of play out of it and would probably definitely continue making elaborate designs if these bugs were fixed.

Weird review? Sure, and here's where it starts: I'm actually really into Hydroneer. It's an ingenious distillation of simulated economics, writ grassroots in value per ounce rather than count and tho the machines serve a very singular purpose, getting a fully-optimized build running glitch-free does hit you with that jolt of serotonin that can only come from that perfect illusion of having done some manual videogame labor [i]right[/i], with your own two unblemished nerd hands.

But straight dope, there's nothing here beyond that. Virtually zilch. You mine the ores, you make the weps, you sell the weps, you make the coin, you buy the parts and you buff your machines so you can AAAAYYYYYYYY mine more ores. For why? Who knows! You can check out the surrounding map, (and what a charmingly alt-medieval aesthetic it is!) but it's not randomized so exploration is very limited, there's no NPCs and all the buildings are empty - so no quests/jobs/missions for you to see to. And if it were just the typically Early Access concession of participating in a slowly evolving something while enjoying what content there is in a developing state, that'd be fine. But Hydroneer is literally all just the base tech, sitting beneath a tantalizing promise of one hell of a clever sandbox game and nothing more (that and this game is no longer in EA.) The motivation wall is a mother of a revelation and when you hit it, it hits like $10 worth of wind just got knocked out of ya.

Catch 22: Clearly, you want to support a dev and see a promising idea come to fruition, but if you wanna know how much content is there to be found, well, now you know. Even against other long-gestating sandbox stuff like Scrap Mechanic, Volcanoids, etc. Hydroneer is really friggin bare.

That said, I do look forward to the day I get to change this review.

What's good about the game: 
-Tons of freedom in automation, from logic components to simple conveyors. 

-Multi-tier progression, going from Manual mining --> Tier 1 drills --> Tier 2 drills, each requiring different setups. 

-The textures fit the gameplay nicely, the textures don't try to be overly realistic.

-It's relaxing, setting up your own mining factory is nice.

What sucks about the game: 
-The item placing system is extremely inconsistent, sometimes you can place stuff inside walls, other times a speck of dirt is blocking you from placing. A great game with some absolutely miserable controls.  It's missing so much quality-of-life that would take this game from not recommended to [i]wholly[/i] recommended.  The early loop is pretty fun, there's a lot to do with logic and automation, there's some super high goals to shoot for, but just... god, the controls.  And I don't mean the keybinds, I just mean how the game controls altogether.  It's like it's [i]trying[/i] to make manual controls as irritating as possible, so you jump straight to automation as early as possible so you don't have to touch things with your clunky pick-up options.  I really want to recommend this game, I seriously do, but something [i]needs[/i] to be done about how it controls.

Firstly, if you've gotten to the reviews, still not sure if you should buy this game, you absolutely should! When I came back to the store page to write the review, I totally forgot how cheap Hydroneer actually is, for the content you get I would be happy to pay more than twice that!

I have had so much fun in Hydroneer, there's already a hundred different ways to play the game and the Devs add updates very regularly! The crafting and mining is incredibly satisfying, the world is beautiful and the Fishing is so much fun too! Not to mention you can use your profits to build your own house, or huge automated machines!

I can easily say this game can be played by every type of player, no matter what you like to do. Love mining and making lots of profit? Absolutely. Love building huge and complicated machines? Or houses where you can display that huge shark you caught? You really have no limits in this game. They're even adding farming!

The Devs are absolutely amazing people too, they really interact with their community (If you haven't seen the bridge made out of a million fish in Hydroneer on youtube, you really should!) and they listen too: they recently added an update filled with user suggestions, and add them to their own updates too! We'll soon have more character customisation options (for us ladies) which i'm very excited about! 

Technical performance: I have a pretty old computer and it still runs like a dream (GTX 960, 16GB RAM, Intel Core i5-4690K CPU @ 3.50GHz, 4 Core) . if you start having issues with frames after amassing a mountain of iron and gold, you can easily smelt them, squish gems together and they retain their combined value. Very well put together! Driving can be a bit chaotic, but they make it super easy to reset the vehicle and the chaos is a part of the fun, for me! You won't lose anything in the trucks no matter how badly you drive!

Lastly, I really want to thank Foulball Hangover for making such a wonderful game and a flourishing community! <3

Ok, so ya wanna know about Hydroneer?
It's a quite good factory building game where you mine through dirt for metals and gems to make weapons and jevlery for sale.
That's the shortest jist of it. It isn't like Factorio or Mindustry, your only goal in Hydroneer is making things for sale and optimizing your factory-mine for peak excavation.

But, there are a few buts that might break it for you:
1. game has excidingly slow start. At first you are doing everything manualy and since game allows you to only hold one item and you do not have an inventory the first metal extraction will be just you shoveling dirt into a bucket and then putting it in another bucket to sift through it for goodies. 
This plain and simple means that your start before you have even the smallest automation will take an hour (if you are not using mods to skip this part)
2. the previously mentioned one held item limit. Yes, there are items that allow you  to bypass the limit- like carts, trucks and a wooden pallet- but most of these items slow your movement, obscure your view and are overall quite large objects making them hard to put down if you are working underground.
3. Underground- the deeper you go the better the resources, but the digging system without mods is tidious and usually requires long polishing of the cave you made before you can put the machinery down, and even then it tends to happen that machinery is too big for a cave you dug up.
4 The system for building is still quite buggy- the collisions for objects you place down, like pipes and machinery, is a really annoying process if you missed even a smidge of dirt or you are too close to where you place the object. Sometimes the collissions even detect your character, especially if you wear a mining helmet
5. The machinery tends to get excidingly convoluted due to "One operation per part" rule the game is based on. This means that you will have long pipes, convoluted cables and huge assemblies even if you strive for perfection and optimization

The game iteslf seems to still be in development, even outside of the early access, and it indeed came the long way, but it still has  a way to go with more of the glaring issues- mainly the collission system and the tidiousness of starting
